reviews.review: Beautiful. Stopped in on a walk around the city. Lots of beautiful altars and art work. Nice stop on a hot day of site seeing.

Amazing marble work. A really stunning church tucked away on a back road in central Rome. The quality of the marble in the fabric of the church was amazing as well as the art and sculptures - one of my favorites in Rome
Meravigliosa!. You have to fit this in, maybe not if you have only two days in Rome, but from three days, it is a must.

Definitely include it in your itinerary. This church is really close to the Pantheon/Piazza Navona, but nevertheless it is a spectacular sight to include. Though it won't take long for you to view it, take some time to appreciate the detail and the frescos in there.
3 Caravaggios!. The church alone is beautiful but it also contain 3 painting by Caravaggio, although you have to put euros into a slot machine for the lights to come on if you want to take photos.

The Caravaggios are a must see.. With hundreds of baroque and renaissance churches to choose from this one is easily missed, but it contains some fantastic Caravaggio paintings and the memorials to a number of French writers and painters. A definite must see.

Very important Caravaggio paintings. A few minutes walk from Piazza Navona this beautiful church houses three very important Caravaggios. the church was designed by Giacomo della Porta and built between 1518 and 1589. An important stop for cultured tourists.
A famous Carravagio. A gaudy Baroque church but with a famous Carravagio. It was considered a Church for French people in Rome.

More to the eye than the Carvaggio paintings . Many people write about the Carvaggio paintings included in this chapel that does not have an entry fee, but the altar is amazingly beautiful. Catch the detail right before the altar and you will see beautiful carvings. As always look up to see the ceiling in all of its beautiful details. This church is much more than its Carvaggios.
Beautiful!!. Dragged in by the wife - so glad she did; wonderful murals and space. definitely worth a visit - even for a few minutes

Also missed on my first visit. Rome has to many places to visit, that I didn't have time on my first visit. Wnt this time. It's a beautiful barroque church worth visiting. Between Pantheon and Piazza Navona

Not to be missed. This is a magnificent church in which services are performed in French. In addition to its own beauty, it contains fabulous paintings by Caravaggio. Even if you are not a church goer, go for the art which is a treat.

Yet another wonderful church and a quick walk from the Pantheon.. 4.5 Stars. This is yet another gorgeous church and a must see if you are in the area. It is maybe a 5 minute walk from the Pantheon and well worth a visit if you have the time. The church can be viewed in as little as 15 minutes or much longer if you are inclined to truly soak up the sights.
Stunning church. This is an absolutely beautiful church with magnificent artwork and decor. A must see when in Rome. Magnificent in every respect.

Caravaggio free of charge. The church has some stunning marble works, some of the best in the history of sculpture, where shapes and figures are sculpted so delicately that they appear as if real or made of silk, Once inside go to the left side and you will be able to admire three original Caravaggio paintings you probably saw on books and catalogues all your life, now you can.

Truly breathtaking . I absolutely love visiting churches especially when they're as spectacular as this.The artwork here is simply breathtaking as is the gold work on the ceiling.I highly advise once you've walked around to just sit in one of the pews and appreciate the church for its beauty

wonderful setting to see the real Carravagio!. Take your time to watch, to read and to enjoy the beauty of this magnificent paintings of the great master! And do this in the morning, because at night there is always a crowd ;-) and it is free!

My favorite!. Of all the churches we visited, this was my personal favorite. Majestic architecture, stunning artwork at every altar inside, especially the one altar that holds the paintings of Caravaggio. Simply stunning!

An afternoon stroll. Piazza Navona has a beautiful fountain in its centre and lots of cafes, restaurants and shops on the periphery. There are artists selling their drawings and paintings of this landmark and others, others selling scarfs and of course others selling selfie sticks and water. You can sit on the many benches scattered around the Piazza and observe the beautiful fountain's detail or just watch the tourists and native Romans enjoy life! One of my favourite Piazzas!
Hard to find. Another great church. Spanish steps are located here, under repair so we could not climb them. Close to Metro station

One church not to be missed!. Artwork in the setting for which it was designed always has an advantage over that in a gallery. So when you have the opportunity to visit a chapel containing not one, not two, but three paintings by Caravaggio therein, you really should take it. The St Matthew series is profound, and a marked contrast from the paintings of the previous century that you may see in Rome. And the rest of the church isn't half bad either! Not to be missed for the art lovers.
Morning walk. Well worth a visit pantheon amazing lovely little shops and bars and there's a lady singing in the square who was incredible
for art lovers!!!. This is a great place for art lovers!!!great view of the paintings, not so many people, you must see it!!!

beautiful national French church in Rome. This church is closely located to Pantheon (and Piazza Navona) and several other worthy churches: Gesu, Santa Maria Sopra Minerva ans St. Ignacio di Loyola. Due to recent events in France this church is under heavy protection from Italian army.The true masterpiece is Caravaggio's Life of St. Matthew (3 paintings). Also, there's a prayer place dedicated to the recently murdered French priest.
Beautiful Church . An amazing church with some beautiful artwork. Lots to see, just behind the Piazza Navona and hardly within 3 mins from the centre.

Easy and Profound. Seeing Caravaggio's paintings usually requires a visit to a museum, but here they are with just a 20 minute commitment. A little dark in their chapel but that should not discourage you.
Breath Taking. This is a beautiful church that has been painfully cared for. I would recommend visiting this church for the art work alone

Carvaggio at his best. Don't loose the chance to see 3 of the best paintings of Caravaggio at his best for free. And if you are between Pantheon e Piazza Navona you must spend 10 min. inside this church.. . ..

Another stunning church. How can 1 city have so many beautiful churches? this is another example of a church that has some of the finest works of art to be found anywhere in the world, 3 darkened Caravaggio's referencing the life of St Matthew that can be illuminated for a single euro. Definitely another "must see" church.
Original Caravaggio paintings . This church is beautiful and I was amazed that we could see three original Caravaggio paintings for free right in the centre of Rome.

Caravaggio seekers here is a treasure.. the church is kept in the dark not to over expose the caravaggio paintings, but once you are there you can put a coin in a light meter to view the St. Matthew chapel which is beautiful especially when you have heard about it so much in my history of art classes.

Beautiful . First church I visited in Rome. Our guide took us here not only for the beauty of the church, its proximity to the Pantheon but the real gem the Caravachio paintings. Don't miss this hidden gem when you are in Rome!

Quick stop to see Caravaggio paintings. This church (which is free to enter) is worth a quick trip to see the Caravaggio paintings in the front, left corner. It is close to the Pantheon, Piazza Navona, etc., so isn't far out of the way. The paintings are stunning.

Real Caravaggio paintings there. Do not ignore to walk in, it is free, amazing place, close to Pantheon.. Just walked in and found real Caravaggio paintings!! What a surprise. Later, we went to modern media project exposition of his paintings and this church was mentioned there like one of the collectors of his art. Must see. Especially it gives you different feeling when you see religious theme art in the right place for it, not in museum. That was a purpose to have profound image for people to thing quietly. Very nice.
Lovely church, breathtaking paintings. Michelangelo's art would make this place worth a visit alone buts it's just a wonderful church even without the masterpiece in the corner
Church of St. Louis of the French. Church of St. Louis of the French is an excellent piece of art. You must have to visit this place and have to see this historical place.
Caravaggio. a real pearl - the best place to admire the art of Caravaggio in a very peaceful environment. Don't miss it when you move from Pantheon to Piazza Navona

Worth a Visit. Beautiful paintings! This church has impressive Carvaggio paintings. Not far from Piazza Navona. Worth the walk. Be sure to have a couple Euro coins handy to put in the machine to turn on the lights on he paintings.

Must See if you love Carvaggio. Caravaggio is one of my favorite painters for his ability to illustrate emotion via facial expressions and body language. If you don't visit this church for any other reason, visit it to see The Calling of St. Matthew, The Inspiration of St. Matthew, and The Martyrdom of St. Matthew. Simply amazing works of art you can see in quiet, off-the-beaten path church.

Caravaggio at his best!. The opportunity to witness the Conversion of St. Matthew for yourself! Even for someone who is not trained in Art History, this painting offers prime example of using light and emotion.
Take Euro coins with you!. They have an ingenious way to raise money. If you don't drop Euro coins, then the light does not come on and you cannot see the 3 paintings of Carravaggio.

Amazing paintings by Carravaggio. The three paintings by Carravaggio are the highlight of this church and are amongst the best paintings that I've ever seen.It's a bit annoying that you need to keep putting in coins to see these paintings (the lights go off if you don't put coins).However do not miss this church.Easy to miss details are:The square window bars in the first painting form a crucifix.The young merchant in this painting represents Jesus in modern clothes.

three Caravaggio paintings of St Matthew. Caravaggio must have felt an affinity with St Matthew because his 3 paintings of the saint in this church are some of his best--direct, realistic and arresting. They are located in the San Luigi Chapel near the front of the church on the left. This church is close to Piazza Navona,

Caravaggio masterpieces in the heart of historic Rome!. Like a big open museum, Rome is full of priceless art in its churches. If you are a lover of Caravaggio masterpieces, this church is a must ! Unknown to many, this beautiful church reveals three important works of Caravaggio that many art students from all over the world come to visit and study. In one nave you will find these beautiful pieces to admire and enjoy....for free! Romans are so fortunate!

A Chapel of Caravaggios. I was on the trail of trying to find as many paintings by Caravaggio in churches as I could. This church is special in that regard because you get to see an entire chapel with paintings only by Caravaggio. The theme of the three paintings is the events from the life of St Matthew, an Apostle of Christ. All the people who posed for Caravaggio were common folk, people of the streets, and when looking at these paintings you begin to understand the importance of the new, gritty realistic style Caravaggio introduced into art. Wrinkled skin, sweaty bodies and dirty fingernails and feet have never looked so fascinating!The paintings are very large, and, as is typical in many Roman churches that have famous works of art, you have to drop coins into a box here to light them up.The church is dedicated to the French king Louis IX, who became a saint. Because of the French connection, the ceiling has a large fresco by Charles-Joseph Natoire, a popular 18th-century French painter. The church is quite plain outside, and thus it doesn't invite you in. But it's worth it to go through the door to see Caravaggio's startling paintings.I'll rate this "Very Good" on the strength of the Caravaggio paintings. Apart from that, the rest of the church is similar to a lot of other Baroque ones in Rome.

Ahh...Caravaggio!. This is a beautiful church, like so many beautiful churches in Rome. The three Caravaggio's contained inside set this apart and make it well worth any extra effort it takes to make a visit. Don't miss it!

Carravaggios in Situ . Fantastic paintings by Caravaggio, Italian artist extraordinaire. Dark detailed and incredibly beautiful they make this church stand out for any art lover. Fantastic to see such rich pieces of art in situ where they were designed to be views. Architecturally it's another beautiful Roman church with impressive details and handy location however for me it's all about Caravaggio. Entry is free but donation boxes are in the church should you wish to make a donation. No need to be catholic to visit but an appreciation of art would help.
Caravaggio at its best. I cannot but mention how beautiful the Caravaggios here are. The church is not far from Navona square, and it is absolutely worth the visit.

Very nice Roman Catholic Church of French architectural design!. This church is located between the Pantheon and Piazza Navona in the Piazza San Luigi de'Francesi. Here we found this jewel of french designed baroque religious edifice. The Piazza San Luigi de' Francesi is rather small and the facade of this french church instantly attracts the attention apart from the other so characteristic Rome buildings in the ochre colour, that are situated in the same Piazza.This church is dedicated to Virgin Mary, to St.Danis and St.Louis IX, king of France. Great contribution to the building of this church between 1518 and 1589 was done by Catherine de' Medici, who ruled in France in the second half of XVIth century. As a matter of fact, it can be said that this church is the national church in Rome of France.Seen from outside, there are several statues that remind us on the french history with the Charlemagne, St.Louis, St.Clothilde and St.Jeanne of Valois presentations in the stone.When we entered inside, we perceived the frescoes on the walls, that depicted the stories of Saint Louis IX, Saint Denis and Clovis.The organ is set high above the floor of the church, over the fenced marble balcony with the pair of angels on both sides of it, as they support whole white structure of terrace.But the church's most famous treasure is the cycle of paintings painted by the Baroque master Caravaggioo about the life of St. Matthew.We stayed for a certain period of time in front of these magnificent paintings of the great artist, which showed us the biblical life of St.Matthew and all these in such recognisable dark tones and colours, always referred to Caravaggio.Great church, we liked it so much !

Very Beautiful and very French!. This beautiful, Baroque church is in the old French area of Rome, not far from the Palazzo Farnese, the French Embassy (only open for pre-booked tours in the afternoon). It is of note primarily for the St. Matthew Cycle of paintings by Caravaggio, the quality of which paintings shine out amongst the other rather duller paintings in the various chapels, though it costs only €1 to light three other chapels (and make your own decisions on that opinion) which I thought a bargain! Unfortunately, when I visited the Caravaggios they were just being readied for conservation but I was still able to see most of one, a good part of another though only a small piece of the third.The church is smothered in gold, heavily textured and has a lot of beautiful marble in various shades of red. It still offers Services and Confession in French and, being French, has chosen to offer translations only from French into Italian - except for the Caravaggios, their main money-spinners I should think, where there are explanations and translations in English as well.The church is beautiful and has a lovely 'feel' about it and, since it's so close to Campo de'Fiore, it's well worth having a look around if you're in the area - and don't forget that churches are usually free to enter and always offer that cool and quiet opportunity for a sit-down!
Gorgeous. This is a gorgeous church. The inside is ornate and has beautiful gold decorations. It is free to enter and a great find. A nice break from the heat as well.

A beautiful church between Navona Plaza and Pantheon. Somewhere close to these famous plazas is this beautiful church which was dedicated to the French in Rome. If the outside is seemingly insignificant the interior is surprisingly beautiful with very high quality scultures and paintings, paticularly the three big one by Caravaggio. You can stay 15 minutes or an hour here easily. Excellent visit.

Caravaggio!. One of the (many) wonderful things about Roma is that you do not have to pay to go into the churches (ahem, Florence!), but are able to make a personal decision about donating to help with maintenance. This is a great thing because the churches are filled with so many artistic treasures, and having them available to the public is wonderful. This particular church, located between the Piazza Navona and Pantheon, has a chapel decorated with paintings by Caravaggio, not unlike the (more famous) Caravaggio chapel in Santa Maria del Popolo. These paintings are massive, and their magnificence cannot appropriately be understood through reproductions. Since this church is located so close to many of the main sights in Roma, there is no reason you shouldn't slip in to appreciate these masterworks; you will not regret it.

A delight. We visited this church to see the three Caravaggio's which are certainly worth seeing. We hadn't expected the church itself to be so beautiful and so quiet as there were very few people on a Wednesday mid-morning. Entry is free, but the lighting to view the paintings requires the operation of a coin in the slot meter.
Beautiful church!. One of the most gorgeous churches we've seen! Very quiet and relaxing inside as well- not overrun with tourists.
Beautiful Church. Very beautiful late renaissance church with some baroque masterpieces by Caravaggio. Definitely worth the visit!
Church of St Louis. Lovely simple church, very calming feel, well worth a visit. On a warm day, welcome the cool calm atmosphere in this sanctuary.

Wonderful church. This beautiful church near Piazza Navona has 3 Caravaggio paintings (The St. Matthew Cycle). Put a coin in the light box and behold the genius in its original setting. The other artwork and decoration is similarly stunning.

Some of the best Paintings in Rome. Definitely check out this small church near the Pantheon which houses Caravaggio's iconic 'Calling of St Mathew'. This church is free to visit, and a wonderful experience.
A Trip thru History. Every time I visit Rome I discover some new attraction, So many monuments located in relatively short distance from one another.

A must. This Church is very easy to find as its round the corner from the Piazza Navone, a short walk. Inside there are two astounding paintings by Caravaggio, in a chapel. You have to put a coin in a machine to light up the chapel, and see the paintings, otherwise you miss all the details. It is also wise to go at a time when its not crowded, as you have to crane your neck over menu heads to get a good look. Well worth the time. When you compare the Caravaggios to the other paintings in the same church, you realise how original and bold he was.
Caravaggio. You can't miss the Caravaggio paintings. Just beside Piazza Navona. One of the most beautiful in Rome
Caravaggio and Bernini. The church is lovely but you go for three Caravaggio paintings and two Bernini statues. It was somewhat crowded on a Saturday afternoon but just wait a bit and it clears out.
Tranquil. Nice place to visit , busy but quiet for personal prayer , incidentally there is also painting by Caravaggio , to view

Nice paintings inside. I was looking to see this curch because there are some Caravagio paintings on the walls.They are very well preserved and lighted and i think you should visit this church.It is something unexpected but also a must see.
Worth it, try to find when open. I walked by several times before I finally found the church open. The building itself is ok as far as Roman churches go, but there are three Caravaggios in it. Three!

very good frescos. Baroque architecture. a plesant place to visit;. very good frescos. Baroque architecture. a plesant place to visit.not sure how a French church came to Rome. Staff is more 'visitor friendly' than many other churches

Exquisite church. This church is one of the most beautiful in Rome...its inside walls are gorgeous, the chapels filled with art, famous people buried and honored inside, it is awe inspiring. One of my favorites

French Cathedral; Incredible Caravaggio. Interesting history, since this church is owned by the French, in the centre of Rome. The church is right off Piazza Navona, on a quieter square and the Caravaggio painting is a must. Pay the money to illuminate it, or have your camera ready when someone else puts a coin in. Read a bit about this painter/murderer before you go--fascinating history. The church itself is delightful.
Great find!. The only French church in Rome located between Piazza Navona and Pantheon. Great art work by Caravaggio in the Contareli Chapel.

Take Time to Enjoy--It's Ahhhh-some!. This is another fantastic church that is fairly non-descript form the outside. Inside, however, it is filled with beauty and history. It's very close to Piazza Navano.Cardinal Medici (who became Pope Clement VII) laid the cornerstone in the 1500's. The church is adorned with frescos, special cuts of yellow marble and stucco. By them selves, this would be reason to visit. But wait! Wait! There's more. (Sorry, I loved this place.) The more is the the Contarelli chapel. (Families bought an area of a church and "decorate" as they chose.) This three-sided "room" contains three huge Caravaggio paintings commissioned by Cardinal Matthew Contarelli. By chance, they focus on the life of St. Matthew--The Calling of St. Matthew, St. Matthew and the Angel, and Martyrdom of St. Matthew. The paintings are amazing.The main church, each of the chapels and the nave are worth a long look. We went back several times. Once our viewing was accompanied by a violinist playing from the second story. Pretty special.
Art, art and more art.... Catholic here and was amazed to see the pillars with angels and demons fighting... Not only that, the paintings are breathtaking as well...

In Search of Caravaggio. During my own search of Caravaggio paintings around Rome, I visited the Chiesa San Luigi di Francesi which have three Caravaggio paintings plus the decor of the Chrurch was grand and decorated in the baroque style. There is also a grand and majestic chapel dedicated to St King Louis of France complete with the royal fleur de lis. This church near Piazza Navona is worth the visit. One of the hidden gems of Rome worth discovering.
Amazing!. Another amazing church hosting Carravaggio's works! A feast to the eyes and righteously so. If you are an art lover, than, you cannot miss this one!

One of my favorite churches in Rome. I had visited this church over 20 years ago, when I first went to Rome - but to see the Caravaggios again was still the utmost treat. The three paintings in the corner are so wonderful, especially when lit - that one can see the look in the main figures' eyes questioning the calling of St. Paul - brilliant artwork! We were also fortunate that they church was not too crowded and they had also put up a storyline relating to the three paintings that was written in several languages and had us focus on different portions of the paintings - very helpful!
Average. It is a small church with odd working hours. Both the interior and exterior are nice, but the size of the church makes my rating low.

Don't miss it.. We were staying just down the road from this church. I knew they had Caravaggio's so we just had to go. We weren't disappointed. The church wasn't even busy when we went. A French tour group was just leaving so we could easily admire the chapel features the three works in peace. Not always the case in some churches we constant tour groups spoil the enjoyment.

Caravaggio - hard to see in a dark corner. Unless someone has dropped coins in the illumination box, it is impossible to see these Caravaggios which are located on the side walls in a small chapel. There are always French tour groups who make the pilgrimage to "their" church in Rome who stand in front of these paintings forever!! If you happen to be in the area (maybe having a coffee at Sant Eustachio which is a couple of blocks away) do come and see these paintings. The church itself is not my favorite style. Entry to the church is free.

Caravaggio for free. There is always something deeply invocative about staring at a masterpiece by Caravaggio. When you can look at three, side by side it is something not to be missed. The Calling of St Matthew is a stunning piece of art, the painting draws you in and give a sense of the genius of Michaelangelo de Merisi Caravaggio. There are three panels side by side, lit up by a coin deposit - this is well worth a visit...and it's usually fairly quiet in there. Perfectly located between Piazza Navona and The Pantheon it should be on every Rome visitors list.
French Church in Rome. San Luigi is the place to see the wonderful Caravaggio chapel paintings....Located between the Pantheon and Piazza Navonait could not better located for a visit...
A must see. The Calling of St Matthew is perhaps one of the most striking pieces of art I have ever seen. Even for this one the place is worth a visit - but there is more.
Spectacular. Three beautiful Caravaggio panels. A must see for anyone. Free and near the Pantheon so an ideal add-on (or "Oops, the Pantheon is closed for Mass" activity. Don't miss this one.

Lavishly decorated Baroque church. The Church of St.Louis of the French (San Luigi dei Francesi) is the French National church in Rome, it is a lavishly decorated Baroque church located a short distance away from Piazza Navona. It was built between 1550 and 1568, from the front it looks more like a grand palazzo to me, the front facade is built in travertine marble. The four statues of the St. Clotilde, St Joan of Arc, Charlemagne, and St Louis were apparently added in 1747, but it is what is inside that we have decided to visit. Once inside your eye is immediately drawn to the white and gold ceiling and beautiful frescoes, but tucked inside are three painting by Caravaggio created between 1599 and 1600, they depict the life of St Matthew, when viewing you are within metres away, such valuable treasures.
Stunning Church. Well worth a visit. it's a beautiful church with many frescoes and a welcoming feeling, We spent time admiring the art works and lead light windows.

Caravaggio. It's got three original Caravaggios. So if your a fan, reviews in this case are mostly superfluous. It's also near the Pantheon. It happens to be a lovely church even otherwise. And it's free. So there's no reason not to add this to your walking tour.

Spot on Caravaggio. One of the hundreds of lovely churches in Rome - but this one can boast of three original Caravaggios. Do remember to bring some cash if you want to be sure to see them - the chapel is very dark, and you have to put change in a meter to turn on the spotlight,

Church of St. Louis of the French. This church is stunning inside, with the three Caravaggio paintings, that chronicle the life of Matthew, but also with the beautiful angel carvings that hold up the Merklin organ. As you look up at these carvings and the organ, you'll be even more amazed by the ornate ceilings and the intricately beautiful artwork overhead. It's a treasure and a place not to be missed. All of this, and it's free.

Thrilling to see the Caravaggios here. Caravaggio's first big consignment is on the right, the Martyrdom of St. Matthew. The artist struggled with this one. X-rays show 2 (maybe 3) attempts under the paint. His sponsor wanted what was standard for the time: a whole gallery of bystanders in the background but Caravaggio wasn't happy with what he was painting. So he set it aside to work on the painting on the left, Matteo's Vocazzione. This one came easily but was nothing like other paintings of its time. Caravaggio's ability to "spotlight" the drama with light and dark was way ahead of his time. (Think of it -- there were no electric lights then, no spotlights. This lighting came from his imagination and it is powerful.)Look at how Matthew meets Christ's look but also still holds onto his money with his other hand. He is still on the fence about which world he will choose. See how the other money-holders don't even seem to acknowledge Christ, and see how their clothing looks like a different era (on the left side of the painting vs the right side).After Vocazzione, Caravaggio was able to go back to his first painting and did what he wanted, just ignoring the request from his sponsor. This is a frightening painting but here's one thing to consider: Matthew is perhaps not holding out his arm in protest against his assassin but instead reaching for the palm held to him by the angel. The palm signifies martyrdom as well as deliverance. I visited this painting several times and each time got more from it. If it's dark, ask at the souvenir desk about turning on the light boxes -- it's free to see the paintings but take a few euros along to pay for the lighting.

Caravaggio masterworks.. St. Matthew paintings. Worth the trip. It's a stone's throw from Piazza Navona, so not too far afield for the average visitor. These paintings pack a punch and show the power of this remarkable painter.
Really stunning. It's a must, barroque painting and decorating and killing piano pipes. The sound is incredible. A must.
Caravaggio painting. Very nice church with Caravaggio painting and beautiful sculptures close to Piazza Navonna. Not crowded.
Caravaggio!. What an amazing church! We were staying in the neighborhood and stumbled upon it. What a discovery to find the Caravaggios! Don't miss this place.
Must see. If you are an admirer of Carrevagio, you should not miss this church. The French can be justifiably proud of this magnificent church.

A shrine of Caravaggio. When you enter the church, you will find a decent amount of people on the far left side. Needless to guess, you know what they are here for. I think after the Galleria Borghese, this chapel is a shrine for Caravaggio. These three paintings are arguable among the top 10 most important paintings this Baroque genius.Since it is free, it is also a great resting place before you visit Sant'Ivo alla Sapienza, the Pantheon, Piazza Navona, Sant'Agnese in Agone, etc.

Stunning. Visited as part of a Gray line walking tour and was stunned by the beauty of the building both inside and out.The artwork inside was absolutely fabulous and I only wish that we had had more time here to appreciate it

A di rigore stop every time we're in Rome. The church has one chapel with three wall-size Caravaggio paintings. That's enough to warrant world heritage rating. Just stand and look. Go have lunch and come back. It's unique. Lots of good eating with five minutes for that lunch. Bring a handful of 1 euro coins to trigger lights in chapel. This was the first year we sense something wrong: a bacterium or some other critter appears to be attacking the paintings and the government is trying to save the murals.

Paintings by Caravaggio. An easy walk from the Pantheon and a must for admirers of the paintings of Caravaggio, quite crowded but there is always someone who puts a coin in the box for the lights on the paintings

Amazing Caravaggio's!. Whilst the church is no doubt an absolute beauty, the main reason to visit has to be the Caravaggio's on display. There is just something about his style that is so distinct and unusual, and on display here are absolute masterpieces.
small but beauiful. I walked by this church on the way from Pantheon to Piazza Navona and decided to stop by. what a charm! Small but very rich and full of gold. See it if you can!

Great collection of Caravaggios. 3 wonderful paintings on the subject of St Matthew by Caravaggio. The Martyrdom of St. Matthew the Inspiration of St Matthew and the Calling of St. Matthew. A must see if you are a Caravaggio fan

A discrete, sober church but a true discovery!. Even if you're not French, go inside and you'll discover some Caravaggio's painting among others. Look at the messages in honour of the French soldiers.
More than just Caravaggios. Make sure you make time (even 15") to visit. And bring a coin or two to illuminate the Caravaggios -- it's amazing what the lighting does to bring them even more alive.

This Church is a Gem. I was interested in the paintings of St. Matthew by Caravaggio and they are stunning. This was a lovely small church near our hotel and the paintings are some of my favorites of Caravaggio. Do not miss these. They are stunning.
Extraordinary!. Absolutely beautiful and fascinating church. Magnificent marble walls pillars and floors and three top class Carravagios. A must see.
Stunning peaceful place. Breathtaking beyond words! You lose all sense of time in this wonderful place. I loved it so much while I lived in Rome
Stunning. Absolutely beautiful, a church not to be missed. The Caravaggio's are of course beautiful but so is the rest of this church. Enjoy some of the best art in Rome.

Gotta see Caravaggio's "Call of Matthew". I live near the Pantheon and have tons of churches around me, but this is one of the few churches I ALWAYS take people to visit. The church itself is very beautiful and prayerful, but the paintings by Caravaggio are breathtaking, especially his most famous "Call of St. Matthew" up at the front on the left. Amazing. Plus it's fun to see the Italian Army "Alpini" guarding the Centre Francese next door in their green felt hats with a feather.
Amazing. Caravagio left me speachless. Beautiful work of art in pretty church. It was a privilege to see something like this. Amazing beyond words can describe.

Aazing Carravaggio covers all of the walls. Between Piazza Navona and Piazza Rotunda, try not to miss it. A peaceful and quiet place to sit and meditate or just rest and view the fabulous art, outside of a museum. It is the national church of France, in Rome.
Worth the trip. I loved the art in this church. The history was quite interesting too. Plan to avoid 12-2 as it was closed during that time and we had to kill time till it opened
Amazing. Astonishing church with beautiful & striking Caravaggio paintings. We had no idea what we were walking into when we opened the door - just stunning.

French Church. We just call it the French Church, inside is very beautiful, however most people are only interested in the three Caravaggio paintings in the back left corner. People tend to focus on those and miss the rest of the church. Those are only on the side of a side altar not the center of the Churches focus.

Beautiful Caravaggio. Just few meters from Piazza di Navona there is a San Luigi dei Francesi - The Church of St. Louis of the French - Roman Catholic church in Rome with tree huge 16th century paintings of famous Renaissance master Caravaggio in the Contarelli Chapel about the life of St. Matthew. Specially emotional is a painting called The Calling of Saint Matthew on the left wall of the Chapel.Really worth to visit, when you around Piazza di Navona so see the church and specially these Renaissance masterpieces of Art.

The best of Caravaggio inside a church. Our concierge told us that there were three Caravaggio paintings in one church and we could not believe him. This church became famous due to this outstanding paintings which could be displayed in the best art galleries in the world. In Rome there are hundreds of beautiful churches, but you must not skip this one! Caravaggio paintings you will see: the Calling of St. Matthew, the Inspiration of St. Matthew, and the Martyrdom of St. Matthew. That is nearly free because you have to insert one euro coins to illuminate them which is much more than a fair price for these heavenly paintings.
Beautiful. One of my favourite places in Rome! you forget how full the city is of such treasures. Can't wait to go back
Don't miss the paintings by Caravaggio, 3. Don't miss the paintings by Caravaggio, 3, among the most important of his career and in history of art.

Unexpected and delightful. Just run into the church because it was open. Turn out to be and amazing baroque church. Ceiling is spectacular. And the best surprise, it contains 3 amazing paintings by Caravaggio. It was not crowded at all.

Nice church, better art. This is an easy stop if you are walking anywhere near the Pantheon. It is a beautiful church in a city of nice churches, but the real thing to see is the three Caravaggio paintings, and his mastery of using dramatic lighting
Nice paintings. Look for the three Caravaggio's - they are truly worth the visit. The difference to the other painters in the church is quite striking.

Amazing church just in the heart of the historical city. Carravaggio not in the museum. At a holy place. But a lot of people know that, of course. So you can buy souvenirs in the church and there is a croud in front of the famous paintings. At least in the afternoon of eastersunday I ' ve been there.

Beautiful church, beautiful paintings. We detoured into this church to have a look at some very famous Caravaggio paintings. The church itself is beautiful and the paintings themselves are amazing. It was very crowded in the little corner that holds the paintings, so be prepared to push through a lot of people to get a good view. If the light is off, there is a little meter on the wall by the paintings that you can pay to turn them on.

A little piece of France in Rome, with some pretty impressive art. The church of Rome's French community - it's interesting to see all the signs etc in French. Very impressive architecture and decor - possibly even more ornate than its Italian counterparts in the city. Three Caravaggio paintings form the centrepiece of the art on display.

A Caravaggio Special. While most churches in Rome are Art Galleries, San Luigi del Francesi has three Large Caravaggio Paintings. They are exquisite. His revolutionary use of light is simply fantastic.

Worth a visit if you love art or you are in the area. We popped in here to get out of the rain & wondered why there was a crowd at this one painting ( we thought 1 ) at the far end on the LHS. It was a huge Carravagio & I particurly liked all the information freely available to explain the depiction of St Matthew with Jesus & St Peter in the custom's house. There were plenty of people paying the 1 euro to light uo the painting & I would've been very happy to pay the small proce myself if needed. Apparently there are 2 other Caravaggio's too.

Worth seeing if you like art and architecture. This is a small but very ornate church with some fabulous Caravaggio frescoes. Yes you have to pay to light up the paintings but it's the same in most of these churches. There is no entrance fee so I think the 'light toll' is completely acceptable when you consider what it must cost to maintain such a place. The ceiling is beautiful as is the organ. Don't let the outside fool you!

1 Euro coin needed to appreciate the Caravaggio paintings. The Caravaggio paintings were dark and unidentifiable until someone put a 1 Euro coin into the machine that turns on the lightswitch to shine onto the three paintings. Either bring some coins or hope that someone else does!I would not necessarily go out of my way to see this church; I happened to be in the area.

a fantastic place where to admire two Caravaggio paintings in situ. It is one of my favorite places in Rome. There are always very few tourists and you can have an almost intimate encounter with the great Caravaggio. The church is very central and a bit anonymous from the outside but do not miss it!
Worth a visit!. 3 Caravaggio paintings together, The Calling of St Matthew being the most known. Church is full of paintings from lesser known artists though that are rarely given much attention.

For the Art Lovers. Not much to see besides Caravaggio's "Calling of St.Matthew," "St.Matthew and the Angel," and "Martyrdom of St.Matthew." If you're an art history buff, come to see these works because of the free entry. Otherwise, the landmarks nearby like the Pantheon and Piazza Navona are a better use of your time.

Breath taking Caravaggio trio. We visited this Cathedral today. The Caravaggio triad on the left side at the end are absolutely breathtaking. The entire Cathedral is beautiful. It's a short walk from Fontana di Trevi.
glorious Caravaggio en situ. this often overlooked church has the most astonishing Caravaggios as ment to be displayed on site. Then head over to sta maria del popolo for more C's

Astonishing Caravaggio masterpieces in a lovely small church. It is rare to see one masterpiece of Caravaggio in a church. This church has 3. An amazing collection in charming church between the Pantheon and piazza Navona. A must see.

Wow what a treat .. .. carravaggio!. This is worth the trip as you get to see some masterpieces but without a doubt everyone comes to see one artist the Baroque master Caravaggio! This little gem has three great works of art dealing with the life of St. Matthew: The Calling of St Matthew, The Inspiration of Saint Matthew, & the Martyrdom of Saint Matthew!Worth the visit!

A real museum, but free entrance. What a great church in the vicinity of Piazza Navona. It's only possible in a few cities for churches to display art of world splendor.The 3 works of the Italian Rembrandt, Carravagio are just magnificent.
Little France in Rome. This wonderful church is very close to piazza Navona.It is the French church in Rome.It is well known for Caravaggio's paintings.
Wonderful Carravaggios. Very close to Piazza Navona and housing three fabulous Carravaggio frescos. (Can be lit up by putting a euro into the slot.)
a must see. went for the 3 Caravagios- stunning but not easy to find even with a map. Its close to the Pantheon but so many churches in Rome it can be very confusing.

Caravaggio. I happened to be meeting a friend on the steps after a trip to the Borghese and I was lucky that the Church was open at the time. I had been hoping to see the additional pieces that te church has of his work and it did not disappoint.

Love Caravaggio? Then this is a must. This church is a pilgrimage whenever I'm in Rome. But then I adore the depth and individuality of Caravaggio's characters; how I would have loved to see him at work. And you can almost picture that happening in this delightful church.
Trip to Rome. Another lovely place to visit, lovely huge paintings, so many nice churches to visit in Rome, you couldn't get round them all but a few a must.

Make a day of visiting churches in this area. You won't regret it.. This one has incredible paintings by Caravaggio, beautiful ceilings, beautiful floors. It's free and stunning, and one of many incredible churches in this neighborhood.

With masterpieces by Caravaggio!. This church is a must-see if you are a fan of Caravaggio's paintings. It's incredible to see his masterful work in the location it was designed for, and how each painting in the small side chapel is in conversation with each other and with the space.
A real gem. Visiting the Panthenon and had fortunately read about the 3 Canaletto paintings. Exquisite. The church was quiet and entry free.
Amazing place. I have seen many monuments all around the world but this place is different, my recommendation is : don't miss it .

draw droppingly beautiful. We were attracted by the fact that some of Carravgio's best works are held in this church. However we did not realise the splendour and beauty of the inside. The marble pillars are worth going to see alone; what amazing work.

A must for art lovers. I came to this church to view the Caravaggio paintings housed within the Contarelli chapel. I had never seen this great artist's work first-hand before so this was such a great experience. The chapel is the last one on the left hand side and although it says in all the guidebooks that you must put a coin in the slot to light up the chapel and view the paintings, you will probably find, like me, that it's almost constantly lit up already from the many visitors gathered around taking photos.
Beautiful Church. We came for the Caravggios, and SO glad we did. It is breathtaking. Very peaceful and I will definitely be back-wonnderful experience.

Not one of the most popularized,but!. We actually came across this church by accident. It's a wee St.Peter's like. We were impressed by the architecture and the individual pews/small places of worship for different saints.Stunning artwork etc. a must see; you won't be disappointed.
Nice place visit. The place is superb and good for persons who love paintings. I would love to celebrate Mass there. It is a place of worship

If you love Caravaggio, don't miss this church. Here you'll see the Contarelli Chapel, where Caravaggio made his reputation as Rome's newest bright light for his dramatic lighting and down to earth figures. Not far away in the interior is a chapel painted by Domenichino, a slightly younger artist with a completely different use of color and light, but a similar interest in making things seem convincing, showing everything from little kids pulling on their mother's clothes to hurry them out, to a little kid peeing, in paintings in Rome and surrounding Lazio. Since this was the church of French expats, many later French painters came to this church to study these examples of Roman accomplishments. Bring small change, as you'll need to pay for the lights to really see the paintings, even on a sunny day.

Homage to Caravaggio. Our second church on a cold rainy fall Rome day. Security was tight all through the area as the Paris attacks had occurred just two weeks earlier. There was no one there in the early morning hours. To see suck spectacular works of art in a side chapel to a quiet church makes one realize how rich in culture Italy is.
Spiritual experience. Enjoyed the peace and serenity of the place and the energy. One must visit the place to really have that special experience.

Recently renovated, and a wonderful Caravaggio set. This church might not be one of the main Basilicas, but it really is nice for a visit. It has nice paintings, but the trio of Caravaggio"s paintings on the left side (St Mathew`s Chapel) are certainly a must. In particular, The Vocation of St. Matthew deserves the visit. The church is just a block from Piazza Navona
Great!. This church is amazing a must visit! The interiors are beautiful with lovely paintings and carvings!

Heaven on Earth. I could visit this church daily and not get tired of it. Take your time here. It's not that there is a lot to see, there is a lot to take in. Let your eye wander and you will discover small gems. Once you are done feasting your eyes, then head over to see Caravaggio in all his glory: art like that has a way of imparting the beauty of the Divine.
Caravaggio for free. The great paintings of Caravaggio all in one chapel in they lovely church between Pantheon and Piazza Navona
great. It's a great church, in it it's possible to admire paintings by Caravaggio, this is simply great !!!
Caravaggio. If you want to see some impressive Caravaggio, swing by this magnificent church close to the italian senate.
For the fans of Caravaggio. Great masterpieces of Caravaggio: The Calling of St Matthew, The Inspiration of Saint Matthew, The Martyrdom of Saint Matthew.
beautiful and has Caravaggio paintings inside!. Definitely worth the visit for the Caravaggio paintings inside it and also because it's a beautiful church. It's the French people's church in Rome.
good art collection. very cheap and not in good spirit to make visitors pay for the light (which we did) to illuminate the paintings. i would have made a donation anyway.

Rome visit. Popped into this incredible church on our walkabout, just one of many that as a historian and a person who really loves art and religious history appreciates the incredible sights that Rome delivers. truly amazing places we will back to find the ones we missed.
Gordon&Julie Bournemouth

Hidden Church with Caravaggio's masterpiece. If you around the city centre, between Piazza Navona and Pantheon, you cannot miss a little stop in the church, it is on the side not a major street, but it has inside the three world-renowned canvases of The Calling of St Matthew, The Inspiration of Saint Matthew, The Martyrdom of Saint Matthew by Caravaggio. If you are going towards Via del Corso and you want to have a free look of Caravaggio, I can also recommend Santa Maria de Popolo.
A true hidden gem. I lovely church with a great surprise three Caravaggio's in a real setting. Absolutely perfect, and a must see.

Our Concierge said, "three Carvaggios." We responded, "impossible!". When our hotel concierge told us that there were three Carvaggios in one church, we struggled to believe her! We could not stop wondering how this church could freely display paintings that are the envy of the greatest art galleries in the world. Even though you will walk by hundreds of churches in Rome, this is one you must not skip! Keep in mind there is no admission, but you will need a 1 Euro coin to illuminate the paintings. Carvaggio paintings you will see: the Calling of St. Matthew, the Inspiration of St. Matthew, and the Martyrdom of St. Matthew.
Dedicated to the Virgin Mary. Nice little church built in the 16th century and dedicated to the Virgin Mary. The inside contains some very beautiful artwork. Worth a look

3 exceptional Caravaggio paintings in one place. More than most great museums in the world can offer. This central located church is famous for there outstanding Caravaggio paintings. it is hard to decide wether the paintings in Santa Maria del Popolo are better or these ones, you have to go to both churches anyway . so you get 6 world class paintings for free , that is nearly free because you have to insert one euro coins to enlight them which is much more than a fair price for these heavenly paintings.

Caravaggio's Monumental Works!. This small Baroque styled church was built for the French community between1518-89 and is two blocks from Piazza Navona. It's the national church in Rome of France. The façade includes some French statues like Charlemagne, St. Louis, St. Clothilde and St. Jeanne of Valois.The interior contains a series of frescoes from Domenichino's masterful depiction of the "Histories of Saint Cecilia". The most famous contributions, however, are the three paintings from Baroque master Caravaggio (1571-1610) in the far left Contarelli Chapel where most of the visitors gather. These somewhat controversial works at the time are about the life of Apostle St. Matthew. The "Calling of St. Matthew" dramatizes the moment Jesus and Matthew confront the toll collectors. Check out his trademark light and shadow technique! "The Martyrdom of St. Matthew" shows the moment the executioner is forcing him to the ground. "The Inspiration of St. Matthew" was also painted between 1598-1601. The other highlight is the frescoed ceiling by French artist Charles-Joseph Natoire.

Terrible PR. I might be a bit subjective here, but some things I find terribly hard to understand. I can understand the need to have a private mass, undisturbed by visitors etc. After all, we, visitors, are being privileged to be allowed into these beautiful churches for free. In particular when we speak about Carvaggio's paintings etc. But I can't understand the reason someone would say "get back at about 1" (to a larger group) when they clearly plan to have it closed at 1.
Such a gorgeous surprise. Beautiful church where you can feel French heritage. Gorgeous pieces of art everywhere, not only the Caravaggio paintings. Worth a visit.

Caravaggios!. Ask a Roman about art, and he will mention Caravaggio. Even if you ask about Michelangelo or Bernini, the Romans always talk about Caravaggio--the artist has a special place in the hearts of Romans. In this small church near Piazza Navona, you can see three paintings depicting the life of St Matthew. Whether you are religious or not, you will be struck by these powerful paintings.

Another great Gem. After seeing the big 4 Basilicas, I started to see some of the lesser know ones. This one was a great find. Got me looking for more like it, which is not hard to find. Each of these churches has so much in the way of amazing art. It is like visiting a free museum. This is worth stopping in for a short visit. Breathtaking.
Admire some Caravaggio paintings in a Church. Near piazza Navona a very nice church with some famous paintings of Caravaggio. Also the church is worthwhile the visit.

A must, and not just for the three Caravaggios!. I've lost count of the number of times I have visited this amazing church, and I still see something new every time.Most people will do this Church for the three Caravaggio paintings in the side chapel on the Left nearest the Altar. And the story of Matthew in these three paintings is fantastic. (If you like Caravaggio then you also need to do the Chiesa di San Agostino between here and the Piazza Navona, and then the Basilica di Santa Maria del Popolo on the Piazza del Popolo)But this church is the centre of the French community in Rome, with some art works and monuments worth seeing just to learn a little about this important story - the French in Rome. Moreover, there is an extremely good French bookshop almost next door to the Church, with a good Art history section. It's such a short walk from the Pantheon that it really is a crime to miss this place.

Carravaggio. That is all.. The greatest thing about Italy is popping into a random basilica and finding artwork from a master painter. Carravaggio's work in the Contarelli Chapel is stunning. This was truly, likely my favorite part of Rome. Admission is free, but you need a few euros if you want to light up the chapel. Totally worth it.

Caravaggio paintings are superb. Thoroughly appreciated seeing Caravaggio paintings within the environment of the Church where natural light through the window was consistent with the direction of light in the paintings.

BETTER THAN MANY ART GALLERIES. do yourself a favor and visit this church , there are some of the best examples of CARAVAGGIO's works in the world , you will not be disappointed. It is right between Piazza Navona and the Pantheon a lovely walk.
Beautiful Paintings. I was pleasantly surprised at the paintings at this Church. Was really beautiful and would recommend all visitors to go.
place to go if you love Caravaggio. i visited the churcu 3 times during my stay,as i was staying walking distance from the church.3 great painting of st.mathews by caravaggio is just a delight to see

It's Caravaggio. Nuf Said. One could spend their entire budget on coins dropped in 2 minute intervals in to the light machine so you can remain transfixed at these three paintings. Is there anything else in this room? Or is it a Church? I don't recall... Because when you stare at Caravaggio you lose all sense of space and time... you are unable to think. All you can do it feel. Feel things you've never experienced from a painting: love, fear, dread, horror, hope. Please read about them before you go. Don't go blind and think "why the funny hat?" Dedicate a few minutes to some research... and then go. Look. Feel. It will change your life.
Great place. The outside this ordinary looking church tucked away in a back street of Rome is a true gem waiting to be discovered.

Amazing art inside. This church is home to three large oil paintings by Caravaggio, all in a single chapel in the northeast corner. All tell the story of St. Matthew. One of them, The Calling of Saint Matthew, is probably the best known of all his works. Invest one Euro to turn on the lights, and prepare for an experience of awe.

Caravaggio outshines the church. San Luigi dei Francesi is the church of the French in Rome but famous most of all, because it houses three works of Baroque painter Caravaggio. Walk up to the chapel to the left of the apse, and you'll see three paintings highlighting the life of the evangelist Matthew-----that is, if you're art lover enough to donate 20-50 Eurocents to illuminate them, or patient enough for someone else to do that. The Vocation of Matthew is the most evocative image, showing the future Saint in an everyday setting as the divine light strikes his face. Worth the detour to this church. Nothing else in the church stands up to these masterpieces, though there are quite a few other paintings to be seen. Some ornamental marble work is interesting.

Baroque with decorations and Caravaggio. You can easily miss this church between many interesting architectures and more important historic places in Rome. But, when you are tired, go to this church ant look at the last chapel on the left side, Contarelli Chapel. There is an automatic machine to turn on the light and you will look at the masterpiece. Three paintings of Caravaggio, legend about St. Mathew hang there. Take your time even when crowd of tourists look at the painting just for a second; they will leave soon. You will not need any explanation when you will be alone with this master. Colors, figures, light speak independently. You will know that you must go to Galleria Borghese and to Capitolini Museum to see some other paintings of the same painter.
Go there for the Caravaggio. Great opportunity to see some of Caravaggio's work since this church houses 3 of them. Located in the centre, just a short walk away from the Pantheon.

Caravaggio!!. We walked right past this church at least three times until a friend messaged me about this church after reading my posts. If you want to see Caravaggio, go visit this church. It's small and won't take a lot of time, especially if you're already in the area getting a gelato down the street. By the way, the people standing at the door with a basket asking for money are not part of the church. There is no fee to visit these churches but there are donation boxes "inside".
Beautiful place: a must in Rome. The church from outside looks like any other chirch in Rome but the paintings of Caravaggio deserve a stop. A place easy to reach that should be visited in Rome

Beautiful church, especially the Caravaggios. The church really is beautiful, and it was worth the visit just to see the Caravaggios. The church was a little crowded, but we didn't wait too long to see the paintings.
Three Caravaggios. This is a very interesting Baroque church. The highlight for us were the three Caravaggios. Make sure you have some small coins to turn the light on.

Worth the visit just for Michelangelos paintings. OK, not the original Michelangelo, however, the three paintings accepted by the church are fabulous, make sure you do your research before you arrive to get the most from the visit.
My favorite church in Rome. I could spend hours looking at the Caravaggios here, the detail that he included is amazing and really draws you in to the scenes he is portraying.

Beautiful but poignant. Visited this French church on the morning after the terrorist attacks in Paris. Poignant visit - lit candles and prayed for all concerned. Caravaggio paintings are beyond compare. Read the details on the panels first to better appreciate them and have some €1 coins to feed the meter for the lights.
For Caravaggio lovers. The church is magical, but the Caravaggios are simply superb. I would go early so you can take your time and enjoy without the mass of tourist standing around!

If you are French.... But also if you are not French, it's a beautiful church to visit. There aren't enough superlatives to describe the beauty of these churches all over Italy. This one has three Carravagio paintings, so if you're a fan...and if you're French...go visit!

Here you'll see some oif Carravagios famous paintings.. We were in Rome mainly to see the Carravagios, I knew little about him before I went but having seen them in situ at this Church and other I'm completely moved, converted and stunned by this amazing artist. Go and look at them and keep looking, looking, looking you cannot help but be bowled over. The only boring thing is that you have to pay €1 for the lights for 2 mins so you need change and lots of it.

More than just the Caravaggios. While the three Caravaggios are the jewel in this church's crown, the whole is a riot of colour and, of course, gold. Perhaps not the quietest of the churches in Rome but a very pleasant stop close to the Pantheon. Don't be a skinflint - put a coin in the slot and view he Caravaggios in good light.

Breathtaking Caravaggio paintings in this beautiful church. The three Caravaggio paintings, focusing on St. Matthew, are in the Contarelli Chapel of this beautiful church. You will need to insert a coin to have lights shine on these paintings, because the chapel (and the paintings themselves) are dark. The rest of the church is filled with more frescoes, statues, effigies, and the ceiling is exquisite. Admission is free. If you have any interest in Caravaggio, do not miss this.
Masterpieces close to the Pantheon. If you're near the Pantheon stop in here. It's close & free fabulous Caravaggio paintings in its chapel.

Visited as part of our Caravaggio tour. We are not doing a formal tour, just walking from Caravaggio site to site and seeing all the Roman highlights n between. The Chapel of St. Matthew was stunning and well worth the wait. If you are visitng make sure you check the opening hours and the hours for masses as it is not open all day for visitors. Bring a euro coin to light up the chapel or the paintings will be in the dark.
a gem. hidden from the main path, you will enter to discover a true gem with frescoes from Caravaggio. A must see
Caravaggio site. Beautiful art by Caravaggio, the most important painter after Michelangelo is displayed in this church. it is free of charge, just inform prior to visit about opening hours.

Baroque Gem. The church of San Luigi dei Francesi is located close to Piazza Navona. It is a real gem of Baroque art and architecture. It houses two works by Bernini and three (!) by Caravaggio including his famous and inspiring "The Calling of St. Matthew". There are many other wonderful works by other artists and the church itself is a work of art.
Underrated, still great. You don't always hear a lot about this Church...... That's unfair, cause this is as good as anything in Rome. Check this out!

Awe-inspiring Caravaggio paintings. This church has three masterpieces by Caravaggio that illustrate events from the life of St. Matthew. The Calling of St. Matthew is mesmerizing--the way the light falls on St. Matthew, his expression and those of his companions. Be sure to bring coins to put in the timed light meter.

It's all about the St Matthew Caravaggios, and they alone are worth the trip. To Rome, that is!. We had a fantastic guide, Giulia Chapman, who does business via word of mouth alone and has no website -- sorry! -- and she made all the difference. I already love Caravaggio, read up on his work, etc., but like all amazing tour guides, Giulia knows a ton and is terrific at imparting her knowledge.

Caravaggio's St. Matthew. Open in the mornings and in the late afternoon and early evening. Left-hand side chapel with three Caravaggio paintings of St. Matthew, with the especially famous painting of his vocation on the left. All agree of its importance for the history of art but experts still argue regarding the simple question: which one is Matthew?

Caravaggio Heaven. The Church of San Luigi dei Francesi is the French church in Rome. It is dedicated to St Louis and masses in French are celebrated here.It contains a series of paintings by Caravaggio on the life of St Matthew. Filled with light and dark shadows so typical of Caravaggio's art, these are a must see for admirers of this great artist.
Great sight to behold!. The colors and decorations of this church will blow you away! To top it off Caravaggio's paintings just make the whole experience complete.
Love it. The place was awesome I have not enough word to describe it, Caravaggio's paints make the place a treasure on Rome. It's easy to get there once you are close to the phaeton only 5 min walk.

Fantastic Discovery. Free...but a goodwill offering is requested. Great visit. Very historic and colorful. You can see this quickly, low-cost and easy access. Quite a nice surprise. Do this! inspiring and humble at same time.
Caravaggio...... If you know and appreciate the painting of Caravaggio this is the place to visit when in Roma....you will love it.

Beautiful Ceiling, and Caravaggio. Situated between Pantheon and Piazza Navona, it's a church with heavy French traits. The ceiling is beautifully painted and decorated. On the 5th chapel on the left side, there are 3 paintings by Caravaggio. Remember to bring some coins to turn on the lights, or wait for somone else to do so.

Incredible art. I'm a total art history geek, so it was exciting for me to see paintings by Caravaggio in the church they were created for. While his work shines in museums, it's awe inspiring in a church setting. Very moving if you are an art geek. Kids may get bored going in and out of churches, but this is one to see.
Lovely church near Piazza Navona. Another church with an amazing ceiling. The artwork is really good. I'd recommend getting a look inside when you're close.
Caravaggio. This church is small but mighty. There are three beautiful Caravaggio paintings that are a must see.
must see for Caravaggio fans!. Three Caravaggio paintings for free! There is a fee to light up the paintings but if you wait long enough, somebody will throw an euro in to light them up.
A highlight.. Great Caravaggios, baroque splendor, easy access and free. Read up on Caravaggio before visiting to get the full impact of his genius.
3 Caravaggio, no waiting. For the cost of a few coins for the light box, three masterpieces. You are not allowed to visit during a mass. A few minutes and well worth it.
The art work is amazing!. This is an amazing Church! So beautiful and peaceful! The artwork is just breathtaking! Be sure to visit this Church!

Church of San Luigi dei Francesi: Go for the paintings and so much more.... If only to see Caravaggio's The Calling of Saint Matthew and Saint Matthew and the Angel, it will be worth a visit. There is so much more. The interior of the church is breathtaking, as it Saint Matthew's Chapel. Via S. Giovanna d'Arco 5.

Beautiful Church. A very nice church and very unique in the art and alter. Something that could never be built today. The painting is very sensitive to flash cameras, however, if you place .10 Euros in the machine on the right the picture will light up

Must See. very close to Piazza Narvona. I went there in particular to see the Carravggio's and wasn't disappointed. The church isn't very big ( by Rome standards) nor was it busy. Obviously most in attendance was there also to see the Carravaggios. Well worthh the time as most everyone will be near by @ theNarvona and/or the Patheon, which is a 5 minute walk away.

Stunning Caravaggio Pieces. This is a beautiful church but the real jewel is the number of Caravaggio paintings that are hung in the smaller chapels off to the sides. You might have to wait around to be able to get a good view as the place can get busy. Plus you also have to put the odd euro 'in the meter' to get the lights to shine on the paintings - but it is free to get in...

A must see church. A much visited church with splendid Caravaggio works that are a must see if one cares about such things. We also attended a musical concert here last year - presented by the French Embassy which was a very interesting experience.

Stunning hidden Gem. Great hidden away gem, fairly quiet buy stunningly beautiful with 3 Caravaggios as well. Stunning, well worth visiting and if the paintings are in darkness put some coins in the box for the light to come on.

If you are not sure who Carravggio was, this church will change your view of art. stunning to have a 'normal' Church with 3 Carravaggios. These tend to distract from the other gems there, just make sure you check out teh ceiling before you leave.

Uncrowded: A Great Find. I would have missed this church and its beautiful paintings and architecture without reading about it in the Tripadvisor guide about "prior research". It is so convenient and almost empty of tourists. You can make any offering into the little machines to turn the lights on the major paintings. I had forgotten that the King of France had been made a saint, and this entire church is full of references to French history. Lovely.
Art Stop. Easy to happen upon this gem of a church in your wanderings of the Centro Storico. Loved the Caravagios!

Oh the paintings!!!!. To be honest, I can barely remember what the church looked like because I was swept away by the paintings hidden in the back corner. Caravaggio!!!! I was mesmerised and I did stare for a while. You should definitely visit, because it is a beautiful church (I don't recall seeing any dull churches in Rome!) and you should not miss Caravaggio!!

Caravaggio!. This wonderful church has so much to offer but more than anything, one must see the three magnificent Caravaggios in the last side chapel to the left. The works are stunning and worthy of a long time in contemplation and study.

The paintings!! . Gorgeous church and definitely a must see. I went there looking for the caravaggios and there are three paintings tucked away at the back of the church. Absolutely stunning it's surprising how there is no notice or sign next to them. They light up after you donate a Euro but it's worth it.

Breathless !. From the outside this ordinary looking church tucked away in a back street of Rome is a true gem waiting to be discovered....if you are a fan of Caravaggio, there are three works that will leave you in awe.The ceilings rival the Vatican as does the alter, it is a truly Spiritual space where you can sit quietly due to the lack of tourists and contemplate the beauty that surrounds you.

Worth going to see the Caravaggio paintings.. A quiet church with no crowds and worth a visit even if you are not religious. Totally off the tour bus route, which means that you can spend time looking at these masterpieces by one of Italy's great artists.Take a couple of euros with you to put into the machine to activate the lights so that you can see the pictures better.

Has anyone mentioned Caravaggio?. Haha. Yep, there are three Caravaggio's located in the back left corner. Yep, you have to pay a euro to light them up. Stand back as there are more than enough tourists willing to part with their euros. Read up on the meaning of the paintings to really enjoy the experience.

Three master pieces by Caravaggio one of my favorit painters in history. Another free access to three Caravaggio fantastic paintings! Highly recommended to ART lovers, three paintings in this church, worth while your time!
Stunning Caravaggios here. The Caravaggios here are wonderful.Decor restrained in this interesting church with French connections.
Don't rush by stop and take this in.. Beautiful quiet church just off tourist trail and therefore missed by the crowds so well worth the stop to reflect and enjoy.
Memorable. To visit churches in Rome is a heart lifting experience . A must see. The interior was spectacular and holy.

Caravaggio fans, come here!. I'm a huge Caravaggio fan - and this place is simply amazing! I remember studying these works in art history class, and wow! I made this a must-see on our visit to Rome. Bring some coins and feed the light meters inside. These lights illuminate each piece separately, otherwise it's very dark.

Just stunning. Absolutely stunning and when we went,t there weren't that many people there. It was very quiet as everyone was just stood ogling the amazing pieces of art on display. Really good place to sit down and have a think and avoid the constant beeping of traffic or bustling of tourists. Absolutely worth going!
A Caravaggio 'must stop'. A wonderful example of baroque architecture and a mecca for the followers and lover of the Master of the 'Chiaroscuro' Caravaggio.

Caravaggio!!!. Free to the public, beautiful church, excellent example of works by Caravaggio. Note: the lights shining on the paintings are set on a timer which is linked to a donation box. Meaning, if you want to see the paintings, you drop a euro or two into the box and the lights will turn on. Gotta love the French.

Beautiful and peaceful. My boyfriend and I spent a whole day touring the churches of Rome, and the Church of San Luigi dei Francesi was a definite highlight. Impressive from the moment you enter, there is gorgeous gold detailing on the underside of the arches and on the ceiling, and in general a peaceful and soothing atmosphere.The Church is most famous for its Contarelli Chapel, which houses three Caravaggio paintings. The fact that you get to view these beautiful works of art for free makes a visit to this Church worthwhile, even if you are not that interested in the architecture of the building itself. Large crowds do tend to gather at this Chapel though (the rest of the church was quite empty), but you only have to wait about a minute in order to reach the front and get a good view.

One of the Prettiest Churches We Saw. We stopped by this church as recommended in Rick Steve's Mediterranean Ports book. It was part of his "Heart of Rome" walk which begins at the Spanish Steps and ends in Piazza Navona. This church was almost completely empty. It was the first church we saw in Italy and is one of the prettiest we saw all trip. Definitely worth a stop in.

Come for the Caravaggio and spend 10 minutes on French soil.. One of the best places to see the powerful work of Caravaggio. This church is right around the corner from the Parthenon and Piazza Navonna. It's worth the stop to take in the national Church of France, the first chapel is dedicated to the French soldiers who fell at the siege of Rome in 1849. Once you cross the threshold you are on French soil. You'll need 1 Euro coin to operate the lights.

Moved us. This should be on your list of "must do" in Rome. The church is stunning, and not heavily traveled by those pesky tourists. There are three Caravaggios, including the calling of St Matthew. You will be moved. We did this in a morning along with San Pietro in Vincoli (Saint Peter in Chains) via taxi before leaving Rome.
Beautiful surprise. Stumbled upon this church and it is magnificent. The Caravaggio painting are worth a visit to this church alone.

One word...Caravaggio, breathtaking!. This is a must see in Rome, humbling. It's all about Caravaggio, and worth multiple visits if you have time. We visit every time we are in Rime! Make sure to check the open hours.

A hidden gem Renaissance Art. This little gem is tucked away. It contains 3 Caravaggios, including the calling of St Matthew. The church itself is much like many others, but as the famous artist is obviously responsible for its draw. And it is surprisingly not busy, compared to the Pantheon, which is only a stone throw. So combine the two!

Be aware: Closed Thursday afternoons. Check church hours. Closed on Thursday afternoons...Good information to know when you are searching for this church on a Thursday afternoon - in ferragosto heat. Thankfully it is close to Piazza Navonna and Pantheon, so you're nt out of the city center.The one-star TA rating is simply so I can write a TA review and inform fellow travelers of this fact. :)

The French National Church in Rome. This church is worth visiting mainly for its paintings,including three masterpieces by Caravaggio,namely The Calling of St Matthew;The martyrdom of St Matthew and St Matthew and the angel.Painted between 1597 and 1602 these were the artists first great religious paintings.They all illustrate the artists use of artificial lighting which puts much of the background into deep darkness,but focuses attention on the remarkably everyday figures in the foreground.

Calling of St Matthew - a Caravaggio gem. Go to the back, on the left. One of the paintings is Caravaggio's Calling of Matthew. Notice Jesus' hand as a perfect imitation of God's creative hand in Michelangelo's Sistene fresco. But unlike Michelangelo's Adam, Caravaggio's Matthew inverts his pointing finger as if asking 'what, me?' Your eyes will try to settle on the boy in the centre, the most illumined character. Matthew and Jesus are in the half-light, and some others continue to count money not even noticing Jesus' call.
Free Caravaggio!. Lovely church, impressive interior. Located between Pantheon and Piazza Navonna. Take a pew, quite down and reflect.

Caravaggio Up Close. Caravaggio paintings, close up! What more could you ask for? You may need some coins to light up the paintings, but that only adds to the excitement. If you love Caravaggio, you won't miss this small, beautiful church in the heart of Rome.
A must see in Roma. Between Piazza Navonna and Pantheon, you could discover beautiful paintings of Caravagio inside.Discover Piazza Navonna and visit the Church (after 3pm)

Caravaggio at his best. Close to the Palazzo Farnese (French Embassy), a nice little Christian Church where they serve Holy Mess in French. Famous for three paintings of Caravaggio on permanent display

Stop in if you're at the Pantheon. This church is near the Pantheon and is free to visit. We stopped in to see it for about 15 minutes as we were walking past it. The highlight are the Caravaggio paintings of St. Matthew that are in the church, hugely detailed and unusual scenes. It was worth it to pay a euro to turn on the lights so you could see them better. The church itself is pretty and gilded, but tended to run together with a number of others we'd seen in Rome.
Wonderful Caravaggio paintings. A lovely church in the centre of Rome near the Pantheon. Three wonderful paintings by Caravaggio depicting the life of St Matthew.

My favorite church for free art. The Caravaggios in this church are truly remarkable (last apse on the left). His painting of light is beautiful. If the lights are not turned on which accentuate is work, pay the 1E to turn them on (there is a little machine). While the paintings are in a U shape making the side paintings a little hard to see from the right angle if it is crowded, his genius still shines through.

Go for the Caravaggio pantings. This church is all about the Caravaggio paintings; free to visit (bar a donation) though you do have to pay to turn the lights on! These Caravaggio panting rather overshadow the rest of the church but still a tranquil escape from the madness of central Rome.
