Nice church to visit . The Caravaggio panting are amazing and it is free to view is a bonus ,the 1500 church is really nice is it a extra place to had to your itinerary very close to Piazza Navona

Caravaggio. The second best Caravaggios in town (after the Deposition in the Vatican Pinacoteca), and they are free and uncrowded. Although difficult to appreciate due to their placement, you feel like a local visiting an old friend (this is my third visit to Rome and to these paintings).
Very nice church. Churtch of Luigi dei Francesi is beautiful with nice wall painting and statues .It is free and very close to the center.
Remarkable. Stunning Caravaggio masterpieces. Truly a very spiritual place to sit and reflect, perhaps pray and light a candle.

Good place to relax your soul..... Although im into meditation for a long time but i dont know still whenever I visit some temple or church or some holy site I feel something very different from inside . I cant explain it in words but kind of very subtle....
3 Carravagios with no wait. For an attraction that was not on my radar screen, I am glad we found it. There were 3 magnificent Carravagios.

Caravaggio masterpieces. A wonderful church in itself and with some exceptional art. The Caravaggio pieces are breathtaking, some of his best art. Even if you are not a fan of his art, they are worth seeing to understand why Caravaggio influenced so many of his peers and others who followed him.
Church and Caravaggio. You cannot miss this Church dominated by the Carvaggio, even if you have to pay to put the lights on.....it's whorty!!!
Caravaggio !!!. Here you can find some of the masterpieces of Caravaggioi !!!. You must visit this church and discover the beauty of the paintings of Caravaggio...

Stunning Caravaggios.. If you are near the Pantheon it's worth slipping into this Church to see the Caravaggios at the front (left of the altar). A bit chintzy that someone needs to put in coins to light up the area where the paintings are mounted to take a proper look. But so worth it. They are stunning. Superior paintings that you can gaze upon for a long time.
For fans of Caravaggio. The church is very near to Piazza Navona and is renowned for housing three of Caravaggio's paintings, the most famous being "The calling of St. Matthew".
When in rome. Old ornate and full of beautiful paintings. Attended during the day a very paeacefull private place of worship.

Caravaggio. So nice to see art in the place it was intended for rather than crammed amongst others in a gallery. People do obviously congregate in front of the chapel but if you wait a bit admiring the rest of the church until a group leaves you'll easily get a good view of three of caravaggios best paintings without any queuing or crowding. Be careful about opening times like many churches in Rome it's closed early afternoon
Take the Time!. This was so very beautiful. I think everyone should see every church just to get the feeling of respect and awe that they project.

A special Church. Most people would go here because of the Caravaggio fans. But we were staying in Piazza Nico so stumbled upon it. It is not only cool, beautiful , with a kind guardian but the French Military Inscriptions are pretty interesting

A must for Caravaggio fans. You never know when you look at the facade of an Italian church what treasures await you inside. When I was there, there was a beautifully worded explanation of the message behind The Calling of Matthew - the paintings are powerful in themselves, but this explanation helped me see the deeper meaning.

Caravaggios just a few steps from Piazza Navona. This like seemingly all churches in Rome is beautiful. Finding it is easy because every tourist must visit Piazza Navona and "dei Francesi" is just behind. Just like the subject line says, 3 Caravaggios are on display. Amazing.

The tourist crowd usually skips this church, but the few inside do crowd around Caravaggio's St. Matthius story. Worth the stop to see the beautifully-done conversion.

Top ten churches in Rome. As you are bound to go to piazza Navona, it is well worth visiting this church as it is just behind.
Fantastic paintings by Carvaggio

Visiting the Chapel of St. Matthew you can't help but get a sense of the artist's understanding of his own sin and how he related to the story of a man called from sin and ultimately killed by sinners. Just an amazing place to visit and take in.
Carvaggio. I have walked by this church many times and didn't know that there were famous paintings by Carvaggio inside. Definitely worth a look Between Pantheon and Piazza Navonna.

One of the best little churches in Rome. It was wonderful to see the three Caravaggio paintings depicting the life of Saint Matthew and there were not too many tourists inside this church at the time we visited.
Follow the Path. Amazing Church in Rome and may be part of the Angels & Demons tour. Churches are a must see in Rome.
Caravaggio!. Caravaggio, of course! but the church is beautiful as a whole!yes do visit it! it is in the very centre, just behind piazza Navona

Caravaggio The Life of St. Matthew. Close to the Pantheon, you'll find baroque architecture and great art...for the cost of illumination. Entrance to the church is free, but you'll want to illuminate the art series in the back left Contarelli Chapel.

Caravaggio Paintings. This church was amazing, howe=ver so are all the churches in Italy. It's incredible that there is a beautiful church on every block. Named in honour of canonised French King San Luigi's is the French centre of the Church in Rome.. Each time we have attended Mass here the congregation has been friendly, welcoming and the Mass is a combination of mellifluous French and Latin. Oh and 2 Caravaggios are an added bonus if you are not there for the Liturgy.
A Visual Feast. This church is an outstanding example of Baroque art and architecture. From the marble work to the Caravaggio paintings, it is a feast for the eyes.
Go to see the Caravaggio's!. Three Caravaggio's tell the story of St. Matthew from his call to his death. Make sure the paintings are lit to see the detail.
Check Out The Caravaggio. One of several churches in Rome that houses a masterpiece by Caravaggio. Beautiful and well worth a visit while exploring the Piazza Novona area.

San Luigi dei Francesi houses three outstanding paintings by Caravaggio.. San Luigi dei Francesi contains three of the greatest and most influential paintings ever produced in Italy by Carvaggio. The painting on the left, The Calling of St. Matthew, takes place indoors where Saint Matthew, then a finely dressed moneychanger, sits with a group of common types. Jesus has just entered the dark room, raised his arm, and uttered the words "Follow me," (Matthew 9:9). The saint looks up, incredulous with an expression as if to say, "Who, me?" The composition contributes to the drama of the scene. A source of light above and behind Jesus' head slashes the darkness and slants down to illuminate the saint's face. As in many of his religious works, Caravaggio's subjects are depicted at the moment of a miraculous event. On the opposite wall hangs The Martyrdom of Saint Matthew and the third painting, above the altar, The Inspiration of Saint Matthew, is not the painting Caravaggio originally created for this location.
Amazing. A must see if you are in the Pantheon area. Free entrance. Caravaggio paintings everywhere. A gem in Rome. Please remember it is a church, so mind a discreet attire

In the steps of Caravaggio. Caravaggio was here painting in person. 3 of his paintings here the most of any church in Rome. St Matthew writing his gospel with the help of an Angel in the photograph here

LET BEAUTY INSIDE OUR SOUL. all churces arround Rome are free for visiting but it is good to know that women need to cover shoulders and all need to be proper dresed to go inside. This church is so beutiful and like others you need time to preper for beauty. We always sit down for a few moments and prey and then just look arround and let all that art to go inside of our soul...
Do not miss it. As all the great churches you go to at Rome, this holds lots and lots of magnificent religious art. And of course the piazza is a great complement.

Beautiful church. One of the many beautiful churches you will find in Rome, simple from the outside but inside you find great art and wonderful architecture. Its Always another experience when you go in the churches of Rome because you know you will see the beauty of the ancient Rome. Must do when you have time..
Wonderful Caravaggio's. Wonderful Caravaggio's... do not miss these excellent paintings. I love the conversion of St Matthew. Who is really being converted. Go and enjoy these great paintings.

Stunning church with spectacular artwork. Gorgeous just to sit and look at. I'm atheist but the beauty of this church was not lost on me and i could appreciate what went in to create something so lovely. Go and see the beautiful paintwork and the ceiling is out of this world.
Ou love art and more??. Then go on in! You gotta do alot of walking to get to these beautiful churches but take a seat and just enjoy!
Caravaggio. Nice church generally but you go for the great works by Caravaggio. Better work than in the uffuci in Florence. Watch out for the up themselves yanks analysing the works - so annoying.
Must see. Just a few minutes from the Pantheon. Plain and simple on the outside but amazing artwork inside. Must see while in Rome!
Beautiful works by Caravaggio. This is a really beautiful with 3 works by Caravaggio, well worth the time to visit. Very close to Piazza Navona.

Church of Saint Louis of the French. Beautiful church near Piazza Navona. The 3 paintings of the Life of St. Mattehw painted by Caravaggio are worthwhile seeing. We attended a wonderful Baroque music concert at the church and an art historian took us to see the Caravaggio's. It was a great combination of the music and art of the Baroque period.

Amazing, but bring change to keep the paintings lit!. Caravaggio's first major commission in Rome. The middle painting, St. Matthew and the Angel, is the second version, the first having been rejected for what are still unknown reasons (don't trust the biographers). Several of his contemporaries also have works in this church, and so it makes for an interesting comparison and meditation on how taste changes over the long haul. Truly gorgeous, but what is most interesting is seeing the extent of the contrast between when the paintings are lit and when they are dark. Also, check the hours, as they are not consistent with other churches in Rome.
caravaggio at its best. the church is famous because of 3 painting of caravaggio, real masterpieces. bring coins to get more light
Caravaggio. What more can one say. It's one of the places I visit every time I go to Rome. It would have had an excellent score if the church opened earlier

Must see the Caravaggios there!. This church is an absolute MUST for the Caravaggio fan! The three huge paintings of the life of Saint Matthew are breathtaking! Note...the paintings are kept in the dark, which must account for their beautiful condition. You have to plug a euro into the light machine to get a few minutes of light on the paintings. Take lots of Euros, because you'll want to drink these in.
A must-stop on your Carrivaggio tour of Rome. Visit the St Matthew chapel (first on the left) for the three great Carrivaggio paintings depicting the life of St Matthew.
Stunning !. The church is just fantastic, well worth a visit. Check the opening hours before going because it isn't open all day.

The Greatness of Caravaggio. For me, this is a "must-do" every time I'm in Rome. The church houses three of the most beautiful paintings of Caravaggio; "The Calling of St. Matthew", "The Inspiration of St. Matthew" and "The Martyrdom of St. Matthew."Hopefully you are going to be there when there are not that many tourists in order to enjoy the paintings because they are really extraordinary; the colours, the movements, the capture of the moment tell stories, atmospheres. You don't pay nothing for getting in the church as for instance, to many of the monuments in Rome, but I recommend you to have some change with you to light paintings, they are worth every penny you spend nourishing your soul.

Ceiling.. When you step it you see how amazing everything looks. So much work was put it to build this beautiful Church. And you could look for hours into the ceiling. Really close to Pantheon and Piazza Navona so you cant skip it.

BEAUTIFUL church with Caravaggio paintings. Honestly, every church in Rome is prettier than the next! This one was no exception. It had great Caravaggio paintings that you should pay the euro to shine the light on. It's a short walk from the Pantheon and definitely worth stopping in.

A must for art lovers. A must do for lovers of art or Caravaggio. It is truly a privilege to experience these most amazing works of art in situ. Have some change handy in case the lights go out. Closed between 12.30 and 3, but you won't be short of things to do nearby if you need to wait!

Go for the Caravaggio's. The chapel on the front left side has 3 Caravaggio masterpieces together in one place. Be sure to drop 1 Euro in the machine so the lights shine on the paintings. Also, there is a pretty good set of descriptiosn highlighting the paintings. Definitely worth 15 minutes stop.

Caravaggio is why you go!. Stunning paintings in of course a stunning church. Not a huge fan of Caravaggio but whoa.... stunning paintings, 3 of them. Well worth the visit. I loved the money changers painting.

FOR ART FOLOWERS. The church does not seem so promising from the outside but hides some real masterpieces of art and not to be missed . No entrance fees to the churches of Rome, but we expected them properly and keep your voice (and phone ) low .

Went to worship Caravaggio. A sumptuous interior, although not overblown. But the three Caravaggio paintings are the main attraction. There is access to a small crypt beneath the altar, and a pair of columns by the main door are ancient Roman. Quite interesting if you don't visit lots of churches. You can buy postcards of the paintings and other views of the interior in case you can't take photographs (no flash allowed).
Original Caravaggio's. An out of the way beautiful Church with original Caravaggio's - magnificent to behold. Few tourists were there allowing plenty of time to view these masters.

Breathtaking. The entire church is amazing but the three Caravaggio masterpieces are breathtaking.
Be prepared to put euros into a slot machine to illuminate the paintings. This applies to the other works as well.
Please respect the request for silence and note also that no flash photography is allowed. The number of people we saw ignore these simple rules was astounding.

Three Caravaggio masterpieces on display at San Luigi dei Francesi. San Luigi dei Francesi is church near Piazza Navona where you can view three of Caravaggio's masterpieces. Opening Hours are 10-12.30pm and 3.30-7pm (as of March 2015). Note that the church remains closed on Thursday afternoons. Within San Luigi dei Francesi you will see a decent nave with an attractive gilded ceiling. The ceiling fresco by French painter Charles-Joseph Natoire is well worth having a look. There are nice chapels on both side aisles of the church, each featuring paintings and frescos that are worth viewing. However, in the end, the main purpose for including a stop at this church is the Caravaggio masterpieces. The Contarelli Chapel is located at the front right side of the church nave. This is where you will find the trio of Caravaggio works. You will probably find a large crowed gathered here as well. Just take you time and you will soon be able to make your way to the front where you can see the masterpieces - 'The Calling of St. Matthew', 'The Inspiration of Saint Matthew' and 'The Martyrdom of Saint Matthew' painted by Caravaggio between 1599-1600. The three paintings are incredible and demonstrate Caravaggio's mastery of light and darkness which evolved into an entirely new style of painting known in later centuries as Caravaggesque style. They are a real treasure that will be easily appreciated by all who have an interest in fine art and seeing the works of Old Masters. Note: There is a coin operated machine at the chapel which can be used to illuminate the masterpieces if you want to take pictures. There is also a small kiosk area in the church, selling bookmarks, postcards and other images of the Caravaggio masterpieces at San Luigi dei Francesi.Note: If you want to see more Caravaggio paintings, consider also visiting Santa Maria del Popolo where there are two more of his masterpieces on display.
Incredible!. Be sure and see this one! Of all the great churches in Rome, this really stands out. The Caravaggio paintings alone make it a "must do" if you are at all interested in art.

S. Maria degli Angeli is even better. If there wouldn't be the Caravaggio paintings few would visit it as the church is quite average and even a bit dark. There is also a wonderful perk: with a bit of luck you could have a glimpse of Tebartz-van Elst during the functions (I've seen him during the eastern function). Everybody knows him in Germany and beyond.

Caravaggios. You have to see the chapel with the Caravaggios and there is another one at nearby Sant Augustino. No charge except for the lights. This is the church for the French in Rome so some nice cafes nearby.
Beautiful Church - Great Artwork. Really lovely church, now most famous for three Caravaggio's, in a side chapple, depicting the life of St. Matthew. Breathtaking!
Incredible. It's massive on the outside and incredible inside. Remain quiet and walk around looking at the art work and statues and the paintings. It's incredible.
beautiful Caravaggio paintings. The church is located 2 blocks away from the plaza Navone. The church is beautiful outside. Inside, you can see Caravaggio paintings.
Take time to see it.. There are Caravaggio's of St. Matthew's life and it's nearby the church of Sant'Agostino and the Pantheon.

amazing beautiful chirch. this church is located not far from Piaza Navona. Very beautiful and impressive inside. wormly recommended . There are so many churches in Rome , but this should be visited .

Lovely. This church is worth a visit if only to see the Caravaggio paintings. We were off season so it was not too busy.

Just Beautiful and full of Art. Incredible art, the Caravaggio's I believe are some of his earliest religious paintings. Close to Piazza Navona, don't miss this church. Beautiful baroque church, incredible ceiling's

Exceptional art and cloistered sanctuaries. It's free and beautiful and sacred and if you appreciate any of those three things don't miss it.
Beautiful. Did not know what to expect, we were pleasantly surprised. You can take pictures so grab your camera.

Frankly Franconard. IL FAUT...you must see the Call of Matthew in this church.
OK..it costs a Euro for lights... but maybe some other tour group is there. It will be as captivating for you as for Levi, now called Matthew

Caravaggio Masterpieces. Lovely to chance upon these superb Caravaggio paintings in a corner of this old church. His mastery of light is shown to captivating effect. Of course while gazing in rapture you could end up with someone's zoom lens in your ear but people are mostly polite in the crush to view.

Do not miss this for the Caravaggio's.. This french church is beautiful inside ( like most churches in Rome) but what makes it really special is the housing of three of Caravaggio's greatest works. Not to be missed.

A french church in rome. This beautiful church is really unexpected.
It's on the way to piaza navona and not easy to find.
Donìt miss it, it will give you an idea of the grandeur and beaty that roman churches preserve.
Caravaggio. Great Caravaggio paintings. Check out the schedule on internet. They have a long closing time at midday.

Hop into the church to admire 3 Caravaggio paintings. - You walk in, turn to your left and see a crowd of people all standing before the Contarelli Chapel, housing 3 masterpieces of Caravaggio. Due to the central location of this church, there is no reason at all not to come in and admire the works.- It isn't too hard though to reach the ballustrade, and be able to take in the art without someone obscuring your view.- However, the lights turn off every minute, until someone decides to donate 1 euro.- You aren't supposed to make pictures, but nobody will take offense if you do.

The church of Caravaggio. Although San Luigi dei Francesi is dedicated to France and to its glories - like Charlemagne, King Saint Louis and Sainte Clotilde - this church is worldwide known for the three astonishing masterpieces of Caravaggio hosted in its Contarelli Chapel.The vocation of Saint matthew, Saint Matthew and the angel, and the martyrdom of Saint Matthew.Located closely the magnificent Baroque square of Piazza navona, it is definitely worth a visit.

Caravaggio's baroque. This church is visited by many because it has a chapel with three paintings by Caravaggio. I love baroque art, and I could stand and look at Caravaggio's "Calling of St. Mathew" for hours. It's just an amazing masterpiece!

Caravaggios for free! A must-see church. San Luigi dei Francesi is the French church in Rome that contains two of the greatest Caravaggios in the city. A few steps from Piazza Navona, I always drop in for a visit just to see the paintings in the two chapels in the back on the left. You only need a few euro coins to turn on the lights (make sure you have them because the French tourists are usually too cheap to bring any!). One of the most beautiful experiences in the city.

Carravaigo!. This church was a bit crowded when we stopped in (we tried on a Thursday and it was closed). You do need to pay for the lights to come on to see the paintings. There was enough of a crowd that the lights stayed on long enough I never saw how much you had to put in.
Great stop!. Finally got to see Carravagio's "The Call of Matthew"-awesome!! Church hours can be difficult but can be worked into a visit to Trevi Fountain.
Caravaggio. Quite wonderful. Very special to be able to view Caravaggio's original work for real. Worth waiting for the church to open!

Caravaggio for free (so long as the sun is shining). Wonderful set of Caravaggios detailing the life of St. Matthew. We were there in the evening when you had to pay a Euro to get the lights to turn on. But it was certainly worth it.

Caravaggio and impressive church. In beautiful decorated Church of San Luigi dei Francesi you can find briliant painting from Caravaggio, which is the main point of interessent in church. It is quite shame that place where the painting is located is very often crowded as well as the whole churche, so the atmosphere is not so spiritual. But it is definitely worth to visit!

beauty that leads to silence. I try not to review Rome's most famous attractions because.....it is really not needed. It's a wonder, an open air museum, a marvelous walk through time and history. Rome has to be experienced, and by feet. Sights, sounds, smells...everything belongs to the experience. I make an exception for San Luigi dei Francesi because i am "in love" with Caravaggio and here is exhibited my favorite painting: the calling of St Matthew. There are no words to describe it: this painting speaks to your heart, "talks" to you and shows that when the eyes of faith enlighted the genius amazing, unbelievable things can happen. Two more Caravaggio paintings are there: martyrdom of St Matthew and St Matthew and the Angel which complete St Matthew cycle. However, here is much in this Church such Domenichino paintings, another giant of Italy's art. Read aboutbthis Church prior visiting it: you'll enjoy it much more
HIGH place OF french christianism. in a small street with many guards...We are in war!small church witout any interest except the reference of french touch in Romeyou should forbid it!

awesome is the word. this church is a must, the decoration is overwhelming but perfectly balanced and the Caravaggios are truly awesome,surely amongst the greatest paintings in world.strongly recommended

Wow !!! Don't miss Caravaggio. This was a place that I was taken to by a client while in Rome, He said if I had only enough time to visit one place then this should be the one, well I won't argue with a local but I would say that I'm glad I did these paintings were fantastic and it has filled me with the desire to come back to explore more of Rome when not on business, highly recommended to anyone looking for something special

Carravaggio Treasure. It is on the way, if you take that walking route which includes the Piazza de Spagna, Trevi Fountain, the Pantheon and the Piazza Navona. It has at least three Carravaggio paintings, but even if you can just see one, the Call of St. Matthew, it is worth the stop.
Caravaggio. Caravaggio paintings are large and well lit, and the location is central though it can get crowded..

Caravaggio! Caravaggio! Caravaggio!. Why would you want to visit another church in Rome? For Caravaggio! . The church houses three of Caravaggio’s famous works and for that itself many fans flock to this tiny space. Yes it is crowded and cramped that other s and most would be actually found standing with change in their hands. You could flick on and off the lights around the paintings with the change to see the true glory of Caravaggio’s works. Well worth the experience if you are an art lover since they have other works apart from Caravaggio

caravaggio lover. the Caravaggio hunters will love it .Peace and quite in the church free entrance ,and of course the three Caravaggio paintings, you can admire, for as long as you like .One of the best spots in Rome ,near Pantheon and Piazza Navona
Don't miss the Caravaggio's!. Beautiful church, bring change to operate the lights to see better! It seemed to stay open fairly late.

As Good as most other National Churches in rome - but I Guess I expected more of France.. A few years ago I visited this church and was a bit disappointed. The name 'France' and 'Beauty' being almost synonymous. However, recently I found myself standing outside San Luigi dei Francesi again and as I entered I was hoping to improve my first opinion. Unfortunately, I didn't. It is very nice, of course, but so are dozens of similar churches in Roma.But, see for yourself, I hope you really enjoy it.Brian, from Perth W. Australia

A master piece. I was lucky enough to find the church on my way to somewhere of room.. I didn't understand why there were so many tourists in the little space.. then once the light was on, I saw those master pieces.. I am so glad I went in and witness of the beauty..
To see the Caraveggio paintings. Such a lovely church with three Caraveggio paintings. Well worth a visit. Between Piazza Navona and Campo del Fiori

Beautiful artwork in a lovely church. This beautiful church is a must visit in Rome. Locates just a five minute walk away from Piazza Navona, it contains Caravaggio's works on the life of St. Matthew. Beautifully decorated.

Beautiful church with great artwork!!!. San Luigi dei Francesi is easily a top ten, likely a top five church of Rome. It is still in operation for the French community in the area, and houses some absolutely spectacular artwork. Their 'collection' (I say it as such because I don't really consider the church as having a collection, instead having more of a structure of artworks) includes three works by Caravaggio that are among his best. It is well worth a trip to visit this church. Like other churches in the area, it has eccentric opening times to the public, so make sure you plan ahead and are well aware of the hours. The only issue I saw with the church was the €1 it costs to light any side altar long enough to admire the artworks. You feed your €1 coin into the little tin box and the lights come on for 45-60 seconds and then go off again. Although there is no cost to visit the church in the first place and €1 isn't particularly steep, it would cost €10-12 to light all of the side altars to see each of them, and almost every other church in Rome is free entry, including St. Peter's Basilica at the Vatican (not including the well worth it €5-7 each to go to the top of the dome). The artwork is part of the church. Don't call it free entry to the church if you're going to charge to see something other than darkness. The €1 for a church still very much in use was quite off-putting, especially as people feed their money into those machines all day, every day. We went in low season, and I don't think one full minute ever passed without someone putting a coin in the Caravaggio altar box. Still, it's a great spot and well worth a visit.

Be sure to see this church. The Caravaggio paintings here are the reason for a visit to this church. They are absolutely amazing. Hard to photograph, although they do allow it. But the lighting is not cooperative. So just stand and gaze and absorb these inspiring works of art. The church is lovely too - but it is the Caravaggio paintings that you MUST see.

Top Ten in Rome. Not a place on every agenda, but spectacular basilica that includes three masterpieces by Caravaggio, portraying scenes from the life of St Mathews. These are wonders of art with vibrant colors and dramatic presentation. Believer, or non-believer, the artistic impression is incredible. While dated from the 16th century, the church is beautiful with a fantastic ceiling. Put this one n your list when planning a trip to Rome.
rome art. The Caravaggio's are close to his best. Easily accessible, bring a euro coin to see them well lighted

Amazing - one of the nicest churches in Rome. Halfway between Piazza Navona and the Pantheon so no reason not to visit.This church was amazing. Like most churches in Italy, the plain frontage hides the sumptuous interior. Extensive use of guiling in the ceiling and archways plus the light from the high windows creates a richly ornate and spiritual interior. This church also has a wonderful dome with an alabaster frieze of angels. I even like the organ terrace held up by angels.And then this setting becomes the perfect backdrop for the Caravaggio paintings.For some reason, when we went it was quiet.. Not sure why but when you go, plan to savour the rich interior and paintings.
Three free Caravaggios. This is a lovely church half way between the Pantheon and the Pza Navona. The real treat is the three Caravaggios in the side chapel

Caravaggio's first major public commission. Unfortunately the church is almost always packed ever since Caravaggio has become a super star. All the same this church which is home to the French community in the Holy city, could also be considered the first home of modern art. The Contarelli Chapel that is the name of the chapel where the Caravaggio's are displayed. I suggest one takes a little stroll around the church before going to the C chapel to get some sort of context. Once one his seen the Leandro Bassano or the Domenichino wich are great paintings in there own right, one can move on to Caravaggio. The artist thrusts you into the mist of the scene just like a great movie director, there are no barriers, just you and the paintings. A unforgettable experience.

Impressive church with 3 Caravaggios. Very large church near to Piazza Navona. If you like hunting down Caravaggios then there are three beauties here. Don't miss St Agostini, just a few steps away, where there is another
Caravaggios galore. The church is baroque and therefore too ornate for my taste. The 3 Caravaggio paintings make this a must visit however!

Beautiful artwork and church. Both the church and the artwork are magnificent. Crowds are large - but we went to the opposite side of the church from the more famous paintings, and we were able to enjoy the paintings much better then in the midst of the crowds.
Caravaggio leaves you speechless! . No one should miss these beautiful work from Caravaggio inside the church of San Luigi! Just 2 minutes from Pantheon, it is a must visit for everyone!

Who would actually pay Viator $95e for a "tour" of this?. That's a joke right? This is a public church, no tickets needed. The paintings are there for all to see, as are the other artifacts in the building. I think these ads for guides are as annoying as the "selfie-blue tooth" sales sharks.

Caravaggio's paintings!. How can I say anything but "Wonderful!" after visiting, once again, Caravaggio's triptych of St. Matthew? This is the French national church in Rome and is tucked between Piazza Navona and the Pantheon. The church itself is worth exploring, but you'll find it hard to avert your eyes away from the Caravaggios.

Free Caravaggio? Yes please. How could one miss this? It's smack in the middle of the city (well, near the Tiber, not far from where you cross to get to the Vatican), it's a beautiful church at it has two (I think) Caravaggios on display, completely for free, including the famous "Calling of St. Matthew". It's a GREAT ten minutes.

Do not miss this!. A stunning church in between our planed walk we did from Trevi Fountain to Pantheon to Piazza Navone. The Caravaggio has to be seen and the alters and sculptures are stunning and a really special place to stop in for a while. You can light a candle here for an offering and there is seating for quiet contemplation. Often large tourist parties or school trips come in and sadly don't observe the silence but do not miss this on your way to Piazza Navone

Caravaggio. Rome made me discover Caravaggio and it's been in search of his work since. He just amazes me. The realism of the people in the scenes brings out the emotion of the moment. The saints look like real people with real emotions. Anyway, that's not all there this church has to offer. The marble, the scuptures, especially the one on top of the main entrance door, the chappels....... And, it's right beside the Pantheon. Enjoy!

Secret Rome at its best . . . not for the rushing tourist, but a treasure for the rest. On a Sunday morning when Pantheon crowds were just too much, my wife and I wandered just a couple of blocks and ambled into this serendipitous discovery. Fronted by a small square, San Luigi dei Francesi is a small, magnificent find: a stunning triptych by Caravaggio on the left of the main altar, a Raphael hiding elsewhere. But the surprise for us when we wandered in on the Sunday Mass service was hearing the liturgy in French . . . this is the French national Catholic church in Rome. French . . . in the most Italian of cities . . . of course! What a testament to the diversity and vitality of Rome. Put San Luigi on your "Rome for Locals" list . . . it is absolutely worth a Sunday visit.

Amazing Church. Very beautiful Baroque time church with amazing Caravaggio's paintings! We visited it during our shore excursion to Rome, even if is not one of the most requested tourist attraction to see if you only have a few hours in Rome but it's worth seeing it!
Caravaggio. Great paintings in a great setting. Much more thrilling that seeing them in a museum. Just insert a coin to switch on the lights and enjoy!

Always on our list to visit. Carravaggio. God's gift to the world. Pretty much enough said. Do look around the rest of the church too, don't just dash into the corner and dash out as there is much to be seen here.
Great discovery. You will see some of the most gorgeous Caravaggio paintings .They are on the inside left side of the churchall the way at the end.
Free Caravaggios. Another impressive Church.Fairly close to Piazza Navona and another Church with Caravaggios AND Raphael, namely Sant'Agostino.

Caravaggio Paintings. This small church in the Pantheon area has a chapel with 3 paintings of St Matthew by Caravaggio. They are amazing and should not be missed. Lighting of the paintings requires feeding a meter but there was never a shortage of people willing to feed the meteer to see the Caravaggio masterpieces.
Art of Caravaggio. St Mathew in three paintings. During the evening service (vesper) lovely vocal music in live. Good postcards.

Caravaggio 3 times!. This is the church to go to if you like the painter, and the Calling of St Matthew is simply amazing. Always try and come here when in Rome as admire Caravaggio tremendously, pure drama! Do go down the road to St Agostino for his Madonna of Loreto, if you are also a fan, as the church is so pretty with its blue painted ceiling and a lovely atmosphere from the monks.

Not to be missed. Any fan of Caravaggio must visit this church to see three of his finest works. They are simply spectacular. Make sure you bring some one euro coins to light the paintings. You's be surprised at how many people stand in front of a darkened chapel because they won't part with a euro.Light the chapel and drink in the beauty of these works of art.

Do not miss Caravaggio paintings. We visited this church during our private tour with Vivi from Rome Private Guides. We loved the incredible paintings by Caravaggio. The story of St. Matthew came back to life. The church is an art treasure . Do not miss this church when in Rome

The Caravaggio Chapel is a Stunner. There is nothing to dislike in the chapel with the three dramatic Caravaggio paintings. They are some of the master's best work. The church, built in the Baroque period by French merchants working in Rome, is dedicated to the French national patron saint, St. Louis of Toulouse. You don't need any directions to find the chapel because there is nearly always a small crowd around it. If the lights go out, be sure to have a 50 cent piece to feed the "luce box" to renew the illumination.
Stunning. Very simple on the outside but a shockingly stunning view inside. so many paintings and pieces to look at, it is a must see. The Italians do this so much better than anyone else.

Stunning Caravaggio paintings. There are many beautiful altars and paintings in this church but the most important art on display are a series of magnificent Caravaggio paintings depicting scenes from the life of Saint Matthew. "The calling of Saint Matthew" is an especially moving painting, but the martyrdom of the saint and his visitation by an angel while attempting to write the gospel are equally impressive. A must for any art lover.
Very impressive church. Not much on the outside but very impressive inside. Caravaggio paintings, and everything else astoundint pieces of art.

Worth the visit. The church doesn't look so promising from outside, but it hides some real masterpieces of art and shouldn't be missed.There are no entrance fees into the churches in Rome, but you're expected to dress properly and keep your voice (and phones) down. The interior is pure fuel for your soul and joy for all your senses. I'm not into art myself and have difficulties to tell all the artists from each other, but it doesn't prevent me from just enjoying this place. The outer didn't promise much which makes you wonder how different the interior can be. My neck got tired of all the staring at the fantastic frescoes in the ceiling. Being in the church you quickly realize where the most famous paintings are, the three paintings by Caravaggio, as that's where the crowd get stocked. Even me got thrilled by the The Calling of St. Matthew, to see if its the real sun that reflects on the painting through the window or is it's painted! Who's St. Matthew on thepainting is still being argued.

Beautiful. A very nice collection of beautiful paintings, and dedicated to King Louis of France, an interesting taste of the French and the cosmopolitan in a city so universally appealing to begin with!
Caravaggio at his best. This church deserves a visit simply for the Caravaggio paintings that are preserved inside. Stendhal would not come out alive from here!!!!

Wonderful art. There are about a half dozen important, lesser known churches within about a five-minute walk of the Pantheon. This is one of them. The "Calling of Saint Matthew" hangs in the San Luigi dei Francesi Church, built in 1589, along with two other well known Caravaggio works on the life of Matthew.

ONE WORD: CARAVAGGIO. This marvelous church is the shrine of three masterpieces of Caravaggio. My favorite, the conversion of Saint Matthew is unbelievable : something like a snapshot of the real moment in which Jesus enter a tavern to make the saint-to-be follow him. But Caravaggio depicted just one minute before Matthew appoint his eyes on Him, at the contrary he is still counting his coins. A Polaroid.

amazing art in an amazing location spoiled by iphone users,. This church, near to the pantheon holds a real treasure in Caravaggio's remarkable St Matthew paintings which when illuminated by a euro recieving light near the alcove that holds the paintings are really something to behold, However it seems that some people are incapable of 1. obeying the church's simple rules about no photography and keeping silent and 2. looking at the works of art on display other than through an iphone or similar device. Not only is this very annoying to those of us that just want to look with our eyes but it is more importantly very disrespectful to those in the church who wish to sit in the church in silent meditation. This particular group of happy snapping philistines didn't even have the decency to put their phones on silent! It could be argued that an unenforced rule might as well not exist but given that there seemed to only be one man working in the church he really couldn't be expected to be everywhere. I really wish that Caravaggio himself had been there to see the utter disrespect shown to his work and given his prepensity for violence I wouldn't give much for their chances! It seems ridiculous to take a photo of a painting as it will obviously be inferior to the profesionally taken ones available in post card, poster and book versions in the church. So come on selfish snappers, don't spoil what should be should be an amazing experience with your crude attempts at photography, leave it to the experts and try just looking for once.

a Must See Church. I think is one of the most spectacular church I have ever been into. The paintings are amazing though if you want to take a better look, you have to pay additional small fee, to light the paintings. But it is usually in Rome. The church itself is unique and so baroque, that I got the feeling my eyes gonna pop out of my head / just stunning!

Amazing Caravaggios. Beautiful church located one block over from Piazza Navona. When you exit the Piazza down one block look to your left. Absolutely amazing display of three of Caravaggio's greatest masterpieces "Life of St. Mathew" altarpieces. Well worth the effort to locate. From here head to the Pantheon maybe a 5 minute walk. Follow the signs.

A Must Visit. this small church near the Pantheon is a must visit while in Rome. The three Caravaggio painting, especially commissioned for this church, are exquisite and make visiting the Church of San Luigi dei Francesi an important stop on anyone's Rome itinerary. Easy to get to from either the Pantheon and Piazza Navona.
Caravaggio paintings are amazing. St. Luis of the French is a spectacular baroque church with spectacular paintings by Caravaggio and DomenichinoWe highly recommend to visit the church

Not the most spectacular but one of my favourites in Rome. Go early when it opens at 10am (closes over lunch from 12.30pm - 3pm). Free entry. That way you can walk up to the little chapel at the left side of the alter and view the Caravaggio paintings in peace. This church is known for a couple of things. Most notably, the cycle of three Caravaggio paintings on the life of St Matthew, namely, the Calling of Matthew, the Inspiration of St Matthew and the Martyrdom of St Matthew. It was also where Martin Luther stayed when he came to Rome for his trial, which was held at the church of Santa Maria Sopra Minerva on the other side of the Pantheon. This place gets very crowded due to the Caravaggios and its close proximity to Piazza Navona.The Caravaggio paintings are magnificent and are worth six stars alone but this rating is for the church as a whole. You are allowed to take pictures, but only without the flash. If you have an Iphone you don't need the flash to get your picture. There is no excuse for people to turn theirs on (as so many do). Get there before these people arrive and spoil the atmosphere. You'll need to have the light turned on the get a good photo (1 Euro). There is also a nice ceiling inside the church.

Amazing amazing. we loved it very warm and very busy when uYou get inside, just plan to stay a while as it's not something to be rushed. Just sit and gather your thoughts in such an amazing place. amazing . . .

Strobe effects. Everyone goes to see the Caravaggios. Fine. Despite requests NOT to take photos or use a flash it gets like a disco in there as hordes of people do exactly that. Visitors are also reluctant to put the money in the machine spotlight the works and wait around to freeload! But the pictures are worth seeing.

Three Caravaggio paintings. Besides the fact you can appreciate Caravaggio's paintings the church has a beautiful central nave with lots of gold leaf edging, sculptured angels near the arched openings. Very inspiring!If there is a mass service going you are not supposed to be walking around taking pictures of the church you need to respect the mass being served

Nice church with amazing Caravaggio's. Located just minutes from Piazza Navona, the church is beatiful, but for Rome not that spectacular. But the three paintings by Caravaggio are amazing - you just rarely can see such masterpieces at no cost. Well - perhaps at little cost since they're located in a dim corner of the church and to see them you have to spend 1 Euro to turn on the lights.Must see in Rome.

three Caravaggios. There were many interesting things to see, but the three paintings were fabulous. Unfortunately the electric light for the pictures was not working so we had to do what they don't like, use a flash to get a picture.
Amazing paintings by Carravaggio. The church has several of Carravaggio's paintings in a corner - you have to put a coin in the box the lights to go on - a must -see for an art lover.

Great Church. Great Church to see. Very mystical. See St. Francesca's remains beneath and behind the altar. Walk up the stairs to the elevated altar (it is allowed), and then walk down the stairs on the side walls. You won't regret it.
Caravaggios in the corner. Recent restoration so everything is beautiful. There are three fantastic Caravaggio paintings in a chapel in front to the left of the altar.
Masterful Carravaggion. We went to San Luigi dei Francesi expressly for the Carravaggio paintings which were not a disappointment. You have to be prepared with coins to light the paintings.

Three Caravaggio Masterpieces. Not far from Piazza Navona is this gem of a church for the French speaking community of Rome. Our teenage son claimed he was churched out, but he changed his tune when we entered and could glimpse the opulent interior and the three magnificent paintings by the mannerist master Caravaggio. Illustrating episodes from the life of St. Matthew , the paintings are dimly lit but intermittently a light comes on and the paintings seem to come alive. Check opening times and mass times as visitors cannot view the Caravaggio's during services.

Try to catch a concert in here. This has been the church of the French community in Rome for centuries, full of fine art and history. Too much to recount here. There are often free evening concerts given (especially in late Spring), so if you don't go to Mass, catch a concert to see everything lit up. It's right in the center of the Centro, by the Piazza Navona, so you will pass by it--if you see a poster for a concert, note it's day and time.

If you love baroque artist this is a must. This place has some beautiful paintings by Caravaggio I would not want to miss. The building itself is covered in gold, marble, and gorgeous paintings. I can't wait to go back.

Caravaggio for free. If you admire the dark and magnificent paintings of Caravaggio you absolutely have to visit this church. The 3 paintings are in the back of the church at the left site. There is no entrance fee. Don't give any money to the people who stand at the entrance, holding a little basked. They are beggars. In front of the paintings there can be a crowd but if you have the time to wait a little you can see the paintings on the first 'row'. When the entrance to the paintings is blocked it means that mass is going to start. This is a French church so the mass is in the French language. You have to wait untill the mass has finished before you can approach the back of the church. Don't miss this unique opportunity to visit the church and see Caravaggio for free.

Chasing Caravaggio. A short walk from Plazza Navona. In the church are three superlative Caravaggio paintings on the subject of St. Matthew. The place in front of the paintings can be crowded at times, but soon enough one always finds oneself alone with the paintings. Being a fan of Caravvagio's works, this was at the top of my list of places to visit.

Caravaggio!. It was a little difficult to find so we asked several times en route from the Pantheon. It was amazing to see the works of Caravaggio in this beautiful little church. My friend had been several times before but it had been closed so I'm guessing opening times are generally only at weekends. There is a box to put a Euro in to light up the paintings and photography without flash is permitted. Please be respectful and quiet despite the emotions that will arise in you. It is a church, not a museum or art gallery. But to see the Caravaggio paintings was an amazing experience. With the Pantheon in front of you walk to the right and ask often for directions.
Caravaggio and St Matthew. My heading says it all. Three Caravaggios in one chapel. Go. Take 1 euro coins so that you can illuminate the art. Splendid.

Those amazing Caravaggios. This is the church of the French in Rome, dedicated to St. Louis, King of the French. Inside are memorials to various Frenchmen, such as the artist Claude Lorraine, who is buried there, and Joan of Arc, as well as numerous others. It's an ornate, large Baroque church, with much to catch the eye. Make sure to see the lovely frescoes of the chapel of St. Cecilia. A visit to this church is worthwhile, however, just for the magnificent three Caravaggios depicting St. Matthew in one chapel. Breathtaking does not describe how amazing they are (bring some coins to light them up). In St. Matthew and the Angel, you can almost hear the flapping of the angel's wings and the sound of his robes swirling as he flies down to the saint.

Caravaggio !!. Whether you are religious or not you can't knock the churches and the art that they contain. For me this particular trip became a bit of a Caravaggio hunt. To be able to walk into a church and just see one of the greatest artists ever work is just wonderful.
Breathtaking paintings. Be sure to wear appropriate clothing, i.e. no shorts and shoulders covered. Fantastic paintings. Located between Piazza Navona and the Pantheon Square.

Another historical landmark. Rome is the perfect place if you want to visit churches ... a few hundred years old church is at every corner! I discovered the San Luigi as I was moving from one Piazza to another ... not the oldest or most beautiful however definitely worth seeing.

A must see. It's that simple, even if you are on a limited time, that is where you should go. It may not fall into your stereotypical what-people-immidietly-think-of-when-they-think-of-Rome, but it will make your jaw drop.

Beautiful paintings in several chapel. Near the Piazza Navona, and not far from the Giolitti gelateria, is this church, the national church of the French (Francesi) in Rome. Inside are chapels filled with fine paintings. The most famous are by Caravaggio, the stormy personality who had new ideas about conveying the drama of religious subjects. He often used spotlighting to emphasize the stories, and painted figures who looked like real people rather than versions of ancient Roman statues. He shows the Calling by Jesus of St. Matthew in a basement where Matthew has been hanging out with his disreputable buddies, by illuminating the hand of Jesus calling and by Matthew's hand that seems to be saying "Are you calling ME?" But do not neglect the paintings in other chapels, such as those by Domenichino and others.

Best church in Rome!. This small and difficult to find church about midway between Pza Navona and Pantheon is my favourite in Rome. It is beautifully decorated with gold and marble - all in the shape of French lillies. Plus there are the famous Caravaggio paintings.

"Caravaggio". The three Caravaggios are worth the visit to this church. Make sure that you put some coins in the machine, otherwise you will miss the beauty of these great paintings (watch the dirty feet of St. Matthew).Don't forget to see the tomb of Pauline de Beaumont (first chapel on the left), mistress of Chateaubriand.
Caravaggio masterpieces. A 'must' for anyone who likes Caravaggio.Take along coins to operate the lights - try to take it in turns with other art lovers!

Must see if you are a Caravaggio Fan. This church is beautiful, like many in Rome. But the Caravaggio paintings are a must see. They are in the far right hand corner as you walk in. Bring some coins to view the paintings. They have a metered light box that turns on the lights over the paintings. Not sure how long per Euro. We fed the box a few times, and so did some others.
beautiful. I am a Caravaggio fan - have been to this church many times and never tire of going there over and over again. also well taken care of.
Great Art, If You Can Get In!. The Caravaggio's in this church are fabulous. Unfortunately, in July I tried to go 4 times and it was always closed. What's up with that!!!
Caravaggio. You must see these paintings. It is easy to stop by, as it is placed between the pantheon and piazza navona.

Absolutely beautiful. I am a Caravaggio fan - have been to this church many times and never tire of going there over and over again.
also well taken care of.

San Luigi. I guess people go there to see Caravaggio paintings. Besides them, it is pretty ordinary church and nothing spectacular inside. Some basillicas (like Pressede) are 10 times worth the visit. But if you are near by, why not go inside.
Carvaggios Galore!. Calling of St. Matthew, Inspiration of St. Matthew & Martyrdom of St. Matthew - 3 masterpieces by Caravaggio in one unassuming Baroque church! Need I say more? Amazing!

Loved it. Everyone goes to the church to see the three paintings of Caravaggio which are absolutely breathtaking, but what made my visit special was a free guided tour by French theologian in French, since this is a French church. Hearing about the construction of altar pieces and the history of France and its religion made me see the church in a completely other way and gave soul and meaning to the sculptures and paintings.
Well Worth a Look. The paintings, architecture were inspiring, and it is convenient to Trevi, Pantheon and Piazza Navonna and can be seen along the way.
Caravaggio!. Came in for a quick peak at the Caravaggio and while it was stunning, the church in its entirety is absolutely beautiful. Well worth a quick stop in to view some magnificent art.

Caravaggio's "Calling of St, Matthew". Don't skip this if you are walking nearby - worth the stop. Make sure you have a few coins with you as the artwork is very dark if the light is not on. 1 euro gives you about 5 minutes of light and it does the work justice.

Worth 30 minutes to see three Caravaggio painting go near the Pantheon in Rome. We ended up with some time to kill near the Pantheon, looked up what was nearby and came up with this church. This was on an evening following a visit to St Peter's, so obviously the comparison is tough, but this church is beautiful, and it has three Caravaggio paintings. Well worth the time.
Caravaggio. Is there anything more to say? The St Mathew triptych is magnificent. I visit every time I'm in Rome.

Not one, not two but three Caraveggesi. Like so many of Rome's wonders, you could pass this church without giving it a second glance. But take a wander inside this Church of St Louis with its French connections, and after admiring it's baroque sumptuousness, the wonderful space, its fantastic ceiling and its many side alters, tiptoe to the chapel to your left of the main altar. There are three pictures of the life of St Matthew, one on each of its walls, all by Caravaggio. Just as he planned them with the light coming from the window and painted into the works. They are a little startling - partly because they may have been recently cleaned but show off the dramatic brilliance of the artist wonderfully.
amazing art. Went here to see the 3 Caravaggio's and was overawed by the experience, the rest of the church is well worth seeing as well.

breathtakingly beautiful. The church is absolutely gorgeous on the inside. The ceiling is quite awe inspiring but the real sight to see are the Caravaggio paintings. Remember to have change so that you can light the paintings for a better view and for pictures.

Not just for the Caravaggios!. San Luigi was among my favourite churches in Rome (the others being The Gesu and Sant Andrea della Valle) and not just because of the Caravaggios. They are spectacular of course and draw the crowds. You can spend a euro to light them up or let someone else in another group do it. They are all splendid but I think the 'Martyrdom' was my favourite - there is just so much going on there! Otherwise, the church is rather beautiful in itself. There is a splendid painted ceiling but the whole is offset with lots of white and gilt decoration. There are some lovely side chapels including a superb one to the Madonna with moulded drapes and a stone angel spearing an unworthy through the throat - very dramatic! Probably best to go late or very early as the Caravaggios do make this little church very popular.

Caravaggio at his best, church rules very strict. This church houses 3 of Caravaggio's best paintings on the life of Saint Matthew. This church has stricter hours than other churches in Rome and you need to pay to illuminate the paintings.

go again and again. Go for Caravaggio's St. Matthew cycle in the Contarelli Chapel -- you must see these paintings, in their originally intended place. It can be quite a challenge to visit when it's not crowded. I visit in the winter just so I can have a shot at some quiet, alone time with paintings like these. I have also visited on Christmas morning (the service is in French) -- the chapel was off-limits until the end of the service when more than half the attendees immediately stampeded to the Caravaggios.
Three Caravaggios. Three of the great Caravaggio's are in this stunning church dedicated to the Virgin and St Louis IX. It's also the place where Martin Luther stayed in Rome while on trial.

Caravaggio fans stop here. The Calling Of St. Matthew, my favorite of his paintings lies inside this beautiful church. The whole cycle of St. Matthew is worth seeing. Make sure you have some 1 euro coins for the light box!

Take a flashlight with you!. In this church I first saw one of the stupidest ideas on earnings. You need to pay an € to light the painting of Caravaggio for a one minute. Really? I have a proposition for churches like this- pay 2 pray! Interest of the millennium!But back to topic, church is nice, but tricks like this make this place frivolous.
Caravaggio paint is inside !!!. Amazed because we discovered that in this small church, few meters far from Piazza Navona is a Caravaggio paint inside !
You have to pay for the light to see Caravaggio.... Besides his paintings there is not much more to see and I really felt it is not ok to expect a fee for this. Take a flashlight with you:D

Caravaggio. This church was worth going just to see some of the most famous works of Caravaggio. We went to this church the day that we had a private tour guide and it was nice to have her expertise when viewing the works.

Beautiful interiors and 3 Caravaggio's for free. This is church is centrally located in Rome, nestling between the Piazza Navona and the Pantheon. Every street in Rome seems to contain churches and other hidden treasures. From the outside the church seems to offer nothing to the casual observer. In fact it is almost Methodist chapel in appearance.However, take a walk through the doors (open 10.00 to 12.30 and then 15.00 to 19.00) and you will find the Catholic church at it's most opulent. Even if it did not contain the 3 Caravaggio paintings it would still be worthy of witness. The walls and ceilings are covering in gold paint, fabulous stone work and murals of the highest class. To me this compares favourably with much of what you will see in the Vatican, including the Sistine Chapel.If it is the Caravaggio's that draw you in, they are located in a chapel at the front left of the church.
Wow. What an amazing church. Three Caravaggios don't disappoint. Plus the church's interior is simply amazing. Don't miss!!
A truly masterpiece!. With three of the best Caravaggio masterpieces, San Luigi dei Francesi it is not to miss up! A really enchanting experience!

Beautiful Caravaggio paintings!. San Luigi dei Francesi is a beautiful church containing a few spectacular Caravaggio paintings. Like many of the churches in Rome, San Luigi has specific hours, so be sure to check those online before you visit. Also be wary of the massive amounts of tourist groups who come to visit this church due to its artistic value, usually around the opening and closing times.

The Caravaggios make this church.. A lovely church. The Caravaggios are beautiful, if a little hard to really see because the chapel they are in is roped off. Stop in between the Piazza Rotunda and the Piazza Navona and see for yourself.

Caravaggio's triptych in the Contarelli Chapel. Rome really is a living museum.In this church are displayed the three provocatively modern masterpieces of the great Baroque master.Entry is free (the church closes at lunchtime), drop a few coins to light up the paintings to see how Caravaggio infused his own light into Saint Matthew calling and martyrdom.Simply beautiful.

rating is for what the church is. we tried to visit this church because it has Caravaggio paintings but it is open only 3 days a week for limited hours. no where is this info given.. the facade is lovely and we had to be content with that

A lovely church without all the crowds. My husband and I thought this church was the second most beautiful we saw in Rome (St. Peter's being the first) but unlike the Vatican, you don't have to pay for going in this one and there are no lines or crowds. Carvaggio's paintings are just gorgeous. We enjoyed looking for all the little touches that reminded you this was a church of the French--the lovely French blue colors on the ceiling, fleur de lis everywhere on the ceiling and stained glass windows. There is a great deal to see at this church and like I said, since there are no crowds bearing down on you, you can spend as much time as you want admiring the paintings, frescoes, sculptures and beautiful pipe organ. Don't make a special trip just to see this but if you are in the area of Piazza Navona, you really should see it.
emotion. a great place, plenty of emotion with the Caravage paintings and the architectural façade on the street

Less than we expected. Having seen almost a hundred churches in Rome, we expected the national church of France to be over the top. It was nice but not exceptional. Don't pass on it if nearby unless short on time but there are better IMO such as S. M. dell' Anima or San Andrea Della Valle.

Caravaggio Hunt. Something that I love doing when I come to Rome is to visit all the Caravaggio's. It's like a treasure hunt, and just about all that you may find in Rome (some 1/2 dozen or so) are in churches so there's no entrance fee.
Caravaggio. some of the most beautiful Caravaggios for free! If you love painting, if you love Caravaggio, if you love theatre, you must see these paintings!

Beautiful. This is the national Church of Rome and is dedicated to St. Louis and one of the famous work in the church is that of Caravaggio who painted the three paintings that depict the three major incidents from the life of St. Mathew which is displayed in the chapel and another famous work is the ceiling done by Domenichino depicting the story of Cecilia. The whole chapel is not far from piazza Navona. Keep coins handy so that you can get the lights on
Caravaggio's art. With my random visit into the church of San Luigi while was still open I seen there real art of Caravaggio! So fascinating

My favorite church in Rome. It may not be the biggest or most elaborate...but the art and feel of this church made it my favorite of all the churches we visited. The location is close to the Pantheon too so you can hit two birds with one stone.

Wonderful Carravaggios.. We stumbled across this church, as we were by the Piazza Navona, absolutely beautiful. The Carravagios are very special, even to someone that knows nothing about art. This church has gorgeous statues, marble, and the ceilings are stunning. Wonderful!
Oh the Caravaggios!. Three Caravaggios in one small chapel. Divine. Worth the wait for the church to open. Overall both magnificent and soothing.

If you want to see Caravaggios for free. Just a few blocks from Piazza Navona, the Church of San Luigi dei Francesi is just one of a number of French churches in Rome. It is perhaps the most famous because of the paintings by Caravaggio in the Contarelli Chapel (first chapel the left of the altar.) The paintings depict scenes from the life of St. Matthew. Take euro coins to turn on the lights in the chapel. There is plenty more to see in the church including the magnificent ceiling. This is one of more popular places in Rome with tour groups congregating around the chapel as soon as it opens. Your best time to visit for unimpeded viewing is about an hour before closing time in the evening.
Caravaggio. Reason of coming here, of course are fantastic paintings of Caravaggio. Need to put coins for lighting, but so many people here that light never goes out!

A moving Caravaggio. Most people visit San Luigi dei Francesi to see the Caravaggio, "The Calling of St. Matthew." It is worth seeing but bring a 1 euro coin or two to light up the chapel it is hanging in. I have seen the painting many times, but the day we were there it was very crowded with Italian school children. Even though it was a stretch to get near the chapel, it is wonderful to see the children enjoying some of their own treasures. The painting is quite moving.
Caravaggio. If you love Caravaggio's work you should not miss this. It was a bit to crowdy because of the canonisation of the popes but you should go in if you love Caravaggio.

I absolutely loved this church. This may have been the most beautiful and tasteful church I have seen. We came near the end of the day and the church was packed for a service ( almost every other church was sparsely attended ). This limited our roaming around and that was disappointing. I would have loved to have minutely examined the place, because it was stunning and I will repeat myself, remarkably tasteful. Even if you are extremely limited for time, if you are going to visit the Piazza Navona, stop in here for a few minutes. It is fabulous.

Nice church and great Caravaggio paintings. I like Caravaggio as a painter, so I would go there to see his works. Out of the two present in the aisle of the chirch my favourite one is the one depicting Jesus calling Matthew to serve (You. Me? You!)
A true masterpiece. Caravaggio... What else? Still, do not forget other frescoes such as domenichino's and siciolante's : they are also great. A must see visit!

Do not miss this church!!. I had planned to visit this church because of the Caravaggio paintings but there were also so many other things of beauty in it that even without the Caravaggios it would be spectacular. The St. Matthew Caravaggios are fabulous and should not be missed - see also those in Santa maria del Popolo in the north inner city. Right next to Piazza Navona and the Pantheon this church is truly spectacular.

Some of the most beautiful art I have ever seen!. The Caravaggio paintings are incredibly gorgeous, but the rest of the interior is also spectacular. The church is close to other attractions such as the Trevi fountain and Piazza Navona. It is not to be missed.
superb paintings by Carravaggio. I liked the way the paintings were lighted in their chapels .The church standing in a lateral street, it is quite calm

Enjoyed it!. Yes most people stop in to see the Caravaggio paintings here and it is really worth it. Being free is always great and the information boards which explain the art work really adds to it. There is someone on duty to keep visitors quiet so although there are many people, it can be peaceful. Put money in the coin box near the front to get the art work lit up - it's worth it!
Caravaggio and San Matteo. wide paintings by Caravaggio are extraordinary, don't miss the visit, and have some coins to light them
Great Caravaggio paintings. Everyone basically just goes here for the Caravaggio paintings. The church is also nice but the paintings are just great. Very worth visiting.
Caravaggio pictures are stunning. Provided someone keeps feeding the lights meter, these pictures are not to be missed, the books don't do them justice.

Caravaggio!!!. we was there in the evening of a rainy day (note it's closed on Thursdays).it was dark inside and at the left corner there was a chapel that needed a coin to turn on the light.and after that,it was just breath taking! 3 Caravaggio famous paintings together.don't miss it at all.

Caravaggio inside. 3 magnificient painting by Caravaggio:
Calling of St Matthew
St Matthew and the Angel
Martyrdom of St Matthew

Stand and stare in awe at the genius of these artisans. No other way to put it -- the beauty and technical ability to create such amazing ceilings, paintings, and everything here is unbelievable. Worth a stop even if just to see the deeply moving caravaggio paintings. Don't forget to look up, often - a knockout.

Can't-miss-Caravaggios. Church itself is pretty enough, but the big draw here is the Caravaggio trio. Steps from Piazza Navona, zoom in and admire Rome's greatest artist in the first commission that enabled him to make a name for himself.

Beautiful church. We always go to see the Caravaggio paintings but if you can go during the evening, sometimes you can catch music being played and the church is lit up so you can see the spectacular ceilings.

Caravaggio lover must-see. An exquisite church right off the Piazza Navona. The Caravaggio of St. Matthew's calling is striking. Others have mentioned a queue to see it; I went in the early morning and there was no line, and only a small handful of other visitors. And don't wait for others to light up the chapel, do it yourself; the small donation goes for upkeep, and you'll be glad you contributed!Be aware that most churches in Rome close for 2-4 hours mid-day; the larger basilicas are usually open all day.

A stunning church, not just for the art..... This church has a stunning interior with some fine marble work. The highlight though is of course the three Caravaggio's hung in the fifth chapel on the left - make sure you have a spare Euro coin to illuminate the works which then really come to life.

Magnificent Artwork. We so enjoyed the breathtaking artwork that fills this little tucked-away church. If you are a Caravaggio fan, this is a must see! It took two trips in a taxi to get us to the right church, two different days, but it was well worth the trip back to try and find it. The entire church is filled with a sense of peace and the awe-inspiring architecture is not to be missed.
Beautiful. Not only are the Caravaggios beautiful but the church was stunning! I loved that I could light some candles! Visited in February and there was no queue to enter. Marvellous!

Caravaggio. Worth a special trip just to see the Caravaggios, which are (of course) stunning. Bear in mind that there's a queueing system as the area where the Caravaggios are placed is cordoned off, and no photos are allowed.

A beautiful church. Everyone goes to this church to see the amazing three Caravaggio's but don't miss this really lovely church. The interior is very peaceful and beautifully appointed. I just enjoyed sitting in a pew and taking in the whole church from the magnificent organ to the breathtaking altar. It may be my favorite church in all of Rome.

I went for the Caravaggio pieces but opulent interior makes it worth it for others. Three SPECTACULAR Caravaggio pieces (of St. Matthew - Vocation, Martyrdom and visit by an angel) filled me with absolute wonder. Of course when has to put in 1 euro to make the piece light up but chances are there will be a stack of tourists there to see the piece too, so let them do so. The inside is SO grandiose, made for the French taste perhaps? A gorgeous church overall.

Okay. All of France would be this beautiful were it not for its revolution which scoured if not destroyed everything. Everyone talks about the Caravagio's there. But notice the diamond shaped coffers of its parachute vaults.

Carravaggio in Rome. Well you must go to San Luigi dei Francesi if your an Art lover...and if you adore Carravaggio as I do this is the place in Rome for you. The church has the very 1st painting by the master....as he lived just near the Church near the Piazza Navona., the French were the first to place his work in a church and they are a fabulous trio of the master in situ doen the left hand side of the church. The church itself is a typical French style nothing to rave about except for Carravaggio's paintings.Simply stunning.
Caravaggio paintings. This is a must see if you are interested in Caravaggio. It is in close proximity to other attractions. You need to visit if you are a lover of paintings!

Art and the devine. This church has a wonderful somber glow, a lot of charming little altars, and of course, in the Contarelli chapel there are the three Caravaggio 'cycle of St Matthew' works. "The Calling of Saint Matthew," "Inspiration of Saint Matthew," and "The Martyrdom of Saint Matthew." It is the best place to see Caravaggio in Rome. Also it is in one of my favorite neighborhoods, near Piazza Navona and the Pantheon!
Loved the Carravagios of St Matthew. The location of the church is on the way to the Pantheon. The paintings were most beautiful and not to be missed.
Caravaggio!. To see a Caravaggio just by accident is what Rome is all about - the best art and culture in the world is placed in this dear city and this is just an example of this - great!

Possibly better than Sistine Chapel. My wife and I literally stumbled on this place while walking near the Pantheon. It was free, took only 15 minutes to see the place, the crowds were manageable, and the paintings were stunning. Perhaps I am jaundiced by the massive crush of people at the Sistine Chapel, but I thought that Caravaggio's paintings were better than Michelangelo's at the Sistine Chapel. They were much larger than Michelangelo's and more visually impressive.

The most modern, scandalous and mystic Caravaggio's masterpiece. Passing by, Jesus saw Levi, the son of Alpheus, sitting in the custom's office, said to him "follow me". And, standing up, he followed him.In the custom's office painted by the Caravaggio we see two groups of people and we can distinguish them by their clothing. On the left, around Saint Matthew, they are dressed as in the Caravaggio's contemporary fashion period (a very modern and extreme way to represent a classic sacred scene, the same that nowadays we can experience in lyrical operas by the most avantgarde directors!) ; Jesus Christ and Saint Peter on the contrary are dressed as in their time period. In this manner, Caravaggio put the scene out of any historical moment, allowing his contemporaries and us to enter into our own evangelical story.Jesus Christ, lending his hand in the same gesture as Adam in the Michelangelo's fresco of creation, extends God's creation of man into vocation to follow his calling.This same extended hand crosses over the "emptiness" which separates the two groups of people, the separation between man and God, human and divine, sin and mercy. This crossover becomes the opening of an alliance between God and men realized by the gift of mercy. With this gesture, Christ has begun a dialogue in which Peter and Matthew both participate.Even the light coming from outside the painting has the meaning of the light of God. We can not see Him but we can see and feel His warm touch.If you pay attention to the simplicity of the shape of window, you can see that it is anticipating Jesus tragic end: the wooden Cross.Even if you are not Christian or religious at all and you will decide to enter this church ONLY to see “The Saint’s Matthew’s vocation” it will surprise you so much that you will recognize how modern and scandalous Caravaggio was at his time.

Do not miss. This wonderful church, close to the Pantheon, Is a "don't miss." In a city full of wonderful churches full of amazing art, San Luigi dei Francesi houses three glorious works of Caravaggio in the Contarelli Chapel: The Call of Matthew, the Inspiration of St. Matthew, and the Martyrdom of St. Matthew. The Call of Matthew is a glorious visual realization of Christ's call to service. The church was fairly close to our hotel, and my husband and I returned to see it almost every day.
my favorite one. the church has the best paintings,of Caravaggio.the church has free entrance.is situated in the main square,behind the navona square. do not miss it.

One for the tick-list rather than the heart. In a city so full of treasures this is an unremarkable church with two OK paintings by a wonderful painter.If you were on a splash-and-dash tour you could "do" this in 5 minutes: in, front left-hand chapel, €1 in the light machine, crane your neck to see two carravaggios either side of the main altar (or, like me, embarrass yourself by looking at the main painting and saying it's not his best, only to be told it's not even his... ahem!). Sure, the paintings are nice enough, and so is the church, but compared to other delights this is "just ok". I cringe to say this, I'm sure it's sacrilege, but if time's short I'd skip this.That said, it's such an easy stop off between Patheon and Navonna that you may as well stick your head in if it's open.

An Easy Stop for Art Fans. OK, the church isn't extraordinary, EXCEPT for the St. Matthew Caravaggios. That said, it's so close to the Pantheon and Piazza Navonne, both of which are must-see, you might as well stop in and see these wonderful paintings. For free. In "The Martyrdom," check out the observer in the back-left. It's the artist himself!

For Caravaggio Desperadoes Only. This church is not extraordinary save for the presence of some Caravaggio artwork. In my view, if it didn't contain items from a big name artist, it wouldn't get a mention anywhere when compared to so many other Roman churches.S is it worth going to see the Caravaggio's?
