I say not, as I find Caravaggio's art very dark and not pleasing to the eye (when I say dark not because it isn't lit, because of how it is painted). Don't go just because of the Caravaggio name. If it's your taste, drop by. As usual, take your money with you to light up the pictures.

A must for Caravaggio fans. We only had a few days in Rome whilst visiting friends and seeing sights so it was impossible to do everything. Although this wasn't one of the places we had chosen to squeeze in, it had been picked out by one of our friends (local guide/architect) who's favourite artist is Caravaggio.I've not studied art at all and so probably can't appreciate the full beauty of his work in this Church but despite this you can't fail to find the paintings truly stunning - the depth created by light, dark, colour etc is breathtaking.One of those places where you come away feeling very privileged to have had the chance to visit.

CARAVAGGIO. Very nice church taking in consideration that you can see here paintings belonging to Caravaggio. If you insert a coin in the special machines the lights are open and you can have a better look of the paintings.

not to be missed. if i remember well in this church are the famous paintings.the most important of all is that all churches are worth a visit for many reasons.some are architectural interesting,others for art lovers etc.and all churches have a free entrance.
Caravaggio paintings. For me the main reason to visit this church was to see the three paintings of St. Matthew by Caravaggio. There is also a chapel decorated by Caravaggio.

Don't miss...A must visit!. This church is my favorite in Rome. There are several paintings by Caravaggio that take your breath away...in particular, the "Calling of Saint Matthew," with the juxtapositon of dress from Christ's time and Caravaggio's time. Often crowded, but just stand there for a while and take it all in.

Caravaggio. church is not too far from Piazza Navona and the Pantheon, so my family and I walked there when we were around the region!! this church is truly beautiful and has 3 gorgeous Caravaggio painting in it. free entrance!! definitely should visit

Caravaggio. Don’t miss this church not far from Piazza Navona and the Pantheon. The building and its interior is worthwhile visiting. However the most important that this church houses Caravaggio's magnificent paintings. You can enjoy them in relatively quiet atmosphere and for free.

BEST CHURCH IN ROME. Like most Roman churches, pretty yet bland exterior. BUT once inside... WOW!!! Truly beautiful with three gorgeous Caravaggio
paintings inside. Look up at the ceiling and be truly amazed. And it's free to enter. Check hours because most churches in Rome close at noon until four o'clock (consult your guide book)

Caravaggio. This is one of my favourite Church in Rome, free entry and not far from Piazza Navona and the Pantheon. It houses Caravaggio's three magnificent paintings of Saint Matthew, they are at the Contarelli Chapel on the left side of the beautiful French Church.The Calling of St. Matthew is especially powerful and engrossing. The Martyrdom of St. Matthew facing opposite it, and the Inspiration of St. Matthew in the centre are just as striking, and we were happy to admire them in peace on a weekday morning without the crowds. If it is dark you just need to put in a euro coin in the box nearby to trigger a light to come on.If you like Caravaggio's other works too, don't miss the Galleria Borghese.

Not just a chapel.. Admittedly, this is a pretty building but, one does not visit this chapel because it is some kind of architectural masterpiece but to admire the four Caravaggio paintings found there. These are the masterpieces and for anybody who loves Art, this chapel is definitely worth a visit!

if God really exists, he lives there. What a great church in Roma (and there is a tough comptetition !). The Carravagio paintings are wonderful, but the rest of the church is so nice as well. You have to admire the red marble pilars along the chor.
Caravaggio. Just fantastic, to be able to see Caravaggio's work in a local church, without fees or queues. Wonderful.

On a visit to view the paintings by Caravaggio. Thrilled to see the three beautiful paintings of Saint Matthew . They are on the left hand side at the top of the church. If they are in darkness you can put a euro in a box and a light will illuminate them.

Stumbled across a Caravaggio. On our way from Trevi to Navonna we just stumbled across this perfect little church. The decoration is just wonderful and of course a chance to see work by Carravagio in a small scale setting.

French Church in Rome. I went to diferent churches in Rome, love them all, this one was a bit different if you love architecture, barroque, details and colorful art, this church has it all.
Amazing interior decoration, was one of my favorites around Navona sq. worth visiting and its free!!!

Beautiful church and beautiful paintings. As noted by other reviewers, this church doesn't seem to be on the tourist track and accordingly isn't too busy. To see a Caravaggio in such as setting was pure magic. Highly recommended.

You must go!!!. The church of San Luigi dei Francesi does not not appear to have many tourists; I was there twice during my recent visit. But, that certainly is not indicative of the powerful paintings that are contained in this beautiful church. The paintings are so large and so powerful and incredibly beautiful. They are an absolute treasure and a must see site while in Rome.
Beautiful church. In a city full of beautiful churches, this one is a must see. Make sure you see the Caravaggio paintings inside.
Stunning. This church is one of the most impressive for art. We visited lots of churches while in Rome (including St Peters) and this was one of the most memorable

Three Caravaggios!!. My favorite artist in history is Caravaggio, a Renaissance artist who introduced chiarascuro (dramatic lighting technique) to painting. There are only around 15 of his paintings that can be seen, and three of his most popular paintings are here in a side chapel, and were commissioned for this church. They're enormous, stunning paintings, well-lit, and free for walking into the church. The church itself is lovely, definitely worth a visit. For more Caravaggio paintings, the Borghese Gallery has 6...magnificent!

A must see church in Rome. There are many churches in Rome but if you like paintings then this church is a must see. It contains three of Carravagio's most stunning works and those you gaze at for hours. I visit this church each time I visit Rome (now around 18 times) and I always marvel again at these stunning works of art. The church is located in a street called Via Santa Giovanna d'Arco. It is not stunning from the outside and you might walk right past it if you are not aware of its location. If you are sightseeing in Rome you will almost certainly go to Piazza Navona at some stage and then want to see the Pantheon and this church is on the way there. If you are in the middle of the Piazza Navona satnding at the magnificent fountain of the four rivers, exit the square by the middle exit to the east. Follow the street to the main road (Corso del Rinascimento) and cross at the pedestrian crossing following the signs for the Pantheon. You continue east along a lane on the other side of the main road and the first street that you come to is your destination. Turn left into the street and the church is on the left. The Carravagios are on the last side chapel (the Contarelli Chapel) on the left before the main altar. To get a good view you have to deposit a coin in a box which activates the lighting but there are so many visitors that this can often be on for long periods. My favourite painting is the oil on canvas called "The Calling of St. Matthew" which depicts the moment when Christ calls St Matthew, who was a tax collector, to follow him. The way the artist depits light in the painting is incredible. I have a framed print of this painting on my office wall - I advise people on their tax affairs and if I have a meeting with a tax inspector I like to make sure that he sits where it is in full view. It is such a stunning picture that it often prompts a question from the inspector about what it depicts and I enjoy explaining its significance. If a cheap copy can illicit that sort of attention then imagine what the original is like. If the church happens to be closed when you are there make a return trip. You will be well rewarded for your perseverance.

Caravaggio, Caravaggio, Caravaggio. although opening and closing times are a little harsh, it's worth it. just a step from Piazza Navona is one of Rome's gems - this church houses three extraordinary paintings by Caravaggio. make sure you read the information and story of the pictures on the boards positined near the chappel

Beautiful Caravaggio's. The most amazingly beautiful Caravaggio's, not to be missed, but very crowded around the paintings which rather made the experience feel rushed and didn't give sufficient time to study them in detail.

Carravagio is the Star. If you're like me, you will have seen about a thousand churches by the time you leave Rome. This one is worth a visit, in my opinion, mostly due to the Carravagio paintings. There are three in a side chapel. You can't go all the way into the middle of the space, but you can see them pretty well from the entrance. There is a pay-to-play lighting, meaning that you can't really see them without donating a euro or so. I have seen this elsewhere in Rome. Some of them are free, and there's a chance this one was. I can't remember. But just be prepared to use a couple of coins. It's well worth it.It's hard to mistake Carravagio. He has a very distinctive and beautiful style. For more, go to the Borghese Gallery (a few smaller ones). There's a lot more to see there too, especially in the sculpture arena.

Church of San Luigi dei Francesi. It is really hard to choose which churches to visit in Rome and which not. They are just so many! But this one is definitely in my top 5! Not only because of its central location, and lavish decoration but also of course because of the wonderful masterpieces of Caravaggio, depicting St. Matthew.

Incredible artwork... Gorgeous church.. Paintings inside are breathtaking and so is the church... Awesome experience overall and well worth a visit if you love art. Coin machines are near most paintings if you want to turn on extra lighting.

Worth visiting for the Wonderful Carvaggios. Another one of those lovely churches that you stumble across in Rome that hides its own masterpieces.3 Carvaggios based on St Matthew in one of the side Chapels make a visit to this church worth your time and effort. (and its free)

my favorite church. loved this church,is in the centre of the town,beside of the church is the famous piazza navona. inside the church you can rest a while from the walking and you can admire the paintings,the ceiling, the air.
Do yourself a favour. The Calling of St Matthew is a stunning painting. It only takes a few minutes, and is free! Only in Rome.

I'm not big on churches but I liked this one. I'm not really a religious or "churchy" person, but this was a very impressive one and I am happy that I saw it.Unfortunately we were told to leave since my girlfriend had bare shoulders, so be warned female churchgoers - shoulder-showing not allowed! Bare bellies seemed to be okay though.We saw many women with a scarf around their shoulders, and you can buy these for around 3€ in many shops in the area.

For Caravaggio fans. If you like Caravaggio, this is not to be missed. Three masterworks, all together in one small side chapel. Only problem is it can be difficult to really examine those on the sides, but let's face it, these are magnificent works.
The French Church in Rome. As a fan of Caravaggio, the Mathew with three of his works is a real treat. The rest of the interior is a bit over the top.

Carravaggio, Carravaggio, Carravaggio. After a while, it can get difficult to tell all Rome's amazing churches apart. This one stands out for its incredible gilded interior, but even more importantly, it's outstanding and rare Carravaggio paintings. Worth a stop!

Caravaggio paintings (plus Church) g. The three St Matthew paintings by Caravaggio hanging in the Contarelli Chapel are really the principal reason for visiting this little church adjacent to The Pantheon. It's perfectly pleasant but there is no denying the power of Caravaggio's art, so go with the flow. For the price of (somebody else's) coin in the slot, the paintings appear from the stygian backdrop of the church interior and it is a jaw-dropping moment. Fabulous.
Total surprise. worth the visit. if you like Carravagio, this church is not to be missed. It's close to the Pantheon and a nice respite from the crowds of the piazzas and bustling streets.
good place to pray. We love church and this one reflects Roman style with lots of sophisticated maners. It is really a masterpiece in town. If you have time, just visit it.

Caravaggio's paintings for a coin!. The church is quite heavily baroque, as expected. However, here you can admire several stunning Caravaggio paintings (almost) for free. There is a coin-activated illumination system, which allows to admire the magnificent paintings. It might look like a cheap priest trick at once, but one should consider that museum or admission tickets in other places are way more expensive!Make sure you bring your own guide and documentation on the paintings, since the one displayed next to them is scarce.A must-see in Rome.

Best Caravaggio painting (The Calling of St. Matthew) and only 3 minutes from the Pantheon. Take about an hour and visit the Pantheon, San Luigi dei Francesi and St. Agostino. They are about 5 minutes apart and will give you a glimpse of just why Rome is such a fantastic city: combine the greatest Roman temple with two churches with 17th century Caravaggio masterpieces. It is an easy walk between the 3 sites. Check the opening times of the churches - they close for the noon hour.There is no fee to enter San Luigi but take a few euro coins with you to put in the light machine to illuminate the works of art. Often there is a crowd and other viewers may put a coin in but it is always nice to pay your share of the lighting. (Look for a small box against the back wall of the church by the Contarelli chapel).You may have to wait your turn to get to the front of the railing. I believe you can take photos without a flash, or at least many were taking photos on their phones. There is usually an attendant - especially true of San Luigi -who ensures proper behavior, that is, no talking and wearing appropriate clothing. This church, more than any other, will ask that you cover bare shoulders. Short shorts are not appreciated. There are plenty of restaurants (for traditional Roman dishes, Armando al Pantheon gets good reviews by locals) and little shops in the vicinity and there is a taxi stand not far away (check your map).Travel tip: If you visit during the hot months, stop at the Tazzo d'Oro adjacent to the Pantheon and have one of the city's best frozen coffee drinks, a granita. You will get a clear plastic cup with shaved, sweetened, iced espresso topped with delicious whipped cream (pay at the register first - at far left - and then give the server behind the bar your receipt). Eat this on the portico of the Pantheon and then visit the 2 churches.

Get away from the crowds and discover a moment in art history. Famous while he lived, Caravaggio was forgotten almost immediately after his death, and it was only in the 20th century that his importance to the development of Western art was rediscovered. This little gem of a church, off the main list of must sees in a 2 day whirlwind tour of Rome, will be a welcome respite from the press of the touring masses. Get ready with some coins to light the Baroque master.

Its a church with some pretty lovely paintings.. On the trail of the Carravaggios, drop in here when you visit the Pantheon, its just around the corner. we enjoyed a break from the heat and bustle of the city to see the works on display here. well worth it.

Visit to see the Caravaggio hanging in the Contarelli chapel. I won't claim to know a great deal about Basilicas, or Art for that matter, but the Basilica of San Luigi dei Francesi was a very welcome respite from the 37 degree heat of Rome and the 3 Caravaggio canvases hanging in the Contarelli Chapel depicting my namesake; The Calling of St Matthew, The Inspiration of Saint Matthew and The Martyrdom of Saint Matthew were an added, and inspirational bonus.
Magnificient little church. This was one of the best free churges we have seen in Rome. Beautiful paintings and a nice ceiling. Nearly every spot is decorated with eye for detail.

Beautiful church. Lovely interior. Be careful of the beggars out the front though add they like to intentionally stand in your way it seems. Very sad. Church is swiftlet worth a visit- beautiful marble and art. Very peaceful.

A Wedding? On a Peak Tourist Date and Time?. I wanted to see the Caravaggios here, and so I timed our Campo Marzio walk to bring us here when the church reopened after riposo. We arrived, and they were just starting a wedding. If you're going to hold a wedding at this, one of the biggest attractions in Rome, do it outside of July, and/or do it during riposo. A lot of people traveled a long ways to see this church, relying on its stated orari, only to be disappointed this day.

Ornate. I stopped into this Church on a tour with a guide and he provided many interesting insights into the story behind the famous paintings. The golden ceilings and ornate sculptures make for a beautiful cathedral.
Caravaggio treat. Fantastic Church - the Caravaggios are amazing and the explanations given were interesting. The Church itself is well worth a visit
Great art venue.. Full of pefect art: Caravaggio & Domenichino. What more needs to be said? One of the great churches in Rome to visit.

Stunning - take a couple of coins for the lights. A breath-taking spectacle and well worth the visit. You need to put a coin in the donations box next to each chapel to put the lights on to see the paintings properly. It's well worth a few cents to see them.

I found this by accident... What a treat!. I'm still amazed that I found this place. We popped into the Church whilst we were wandering through Rome. Although we do love old churches, and those in Rome are seemingly all amazing, I have to admit that getting some shade was at least part of the reason for visiting!What a lucky fund this turned out to be. The church itself is an old French church in the typical Roman style, and as you can see in the photos is absolutely beautiful. Beautifully decorated ceilings, and wonderful artwork, just typical of most churches in Rome. However, as I walked through, I saw a cluster of people in the bottom left hand corner; naturally this piqued my interest. As I got closer, the lights dimmed and I didn't know what people were looking at. Once someone decided it was up to them to put a Euro "in the meter", the art in this small chapel was lit up, revealing the famous Caravaggio paintings. What beautiful, amazing, well maintained decorations these are! They are incredible paintings, beyond words, and really must be seen to be believed. Find your way here; it's just off the Piazza Navona and it's definitely worthwhile.

Great art in sito.. Seeing the Caravaggio paintings where they were intended was great. It was quite dark, and you had to pay a euro to turn on the light for a minute or two. Beautiful church overall.

Great art and stonework. Virtually all the churches in Rome have great art and stone work. Most of the colored marble had to be imported hundreds of years ago. Yu will see work from several major artists on your visit.
Carvaggios amazing. The church was typical of the others in Rome, but if you are a Carvaggio fan, don't miss the chance to pay the obligatory Euro to light the painting(s) for a couple of minutes.
amazing architecture. so peaceful and beautiful,a must see, so much that pleases the eye in here,amidst a serene setting

French church, 3 Caravaggio. The first of Caravaggios great religious works hang in this church, Calling of St Matthew, Martyrdom of St Matthew and St Matthew and the angel. A must visit just to see these paintings.
Spectacular!. Beautiful church with impressive dome and ceiling and paintings by Carravagio. Nearly walked by without going in! That would have been a shame!

Caravaggio. Two massive paintings by Caravaggio in this church is worth a coin or two to light them. It took my breath away since I was almost alone and could get up close. Remember that most churches in Roma close at noon for about two hours.

Sightseeing. Enjoyed everything but especially the restaurants not close to tourist attractions. Gelato is must and walking is discouraged if you are not in good condition as the sidewalks and streets are cobblestones

Simply stunning. We visited to see the three Caravaggio's which are located in the last chapel on the left. What great works of art. A 'must' if you visit Rome, can be very busy, so get there early, we arrived just after 4pm, when it opened for the afternoon. You have pay one Euro to light the paintings, so try to let someone else pay for it!
Great church!!. An Elegant and beautiful church particularly inside. It’s a real hidden gem with no cues or charges for entry. I would highly recommend a short visit to this hotel.
Wirth a visit. This nuce little church us well worth a visit. Some fair art and a nice Caravaggio that is mussed byist people. 1 euro will see it well lit fir a few minutes. Money well spent!

Savor this. These masterpieces by Caravaggio have an interesting backstory, as does the history of the church. Take some time while here to find out more about both. It might help if you can read French, although the gift shop has a number of books in English.
amazing site!. Must see attraction in Rome! So beautiful.I love churches and this place was full of history. Take a stroll through the church, light up a candle for a special one and be greatful.

My favorite church in Rome. Gorgeous church in the heart of Rome. Features a wonderful painting by Caravaggio. Not much not to like but the church is open strange hours and closed on Sundays except for mass.
lovely and free. Lovely church and artwork in one setting. They have 3 Michelangleo Merisi da Caravaggio pieces on display.
To be visited. Don't miss this church and its beautiful Caravaggio's works. It is free entrance and central, just behind pz Navona.

A gem of a Caravaggio for the right price: free. The Church of San Luigi die Francesi is a wonderful attraction: free, not over-crowded, cool in the summer and over-the-top ornate. Plus, it has three fine Caravaggio paintings depicting the master's darkness and use of light perspective. I am not a church fan, much less an endless amount of churches in Rome fan, but this one is worth the trip.
Don't Miss This Church. If you interested in art history, than this church is one that cannot be missed. The Caravaggio's are truly amazing. Don't miss them.
Carvaggio in context. Nice to see Carvaggio paintings in the place it was intended and not a museum. You have to put coins in a machine to keep the lights on-quaint

The spirituality of incense. Very beautiful church, few steps from Piazza Navona, contains masterpieces by Caravaggio: The Martyrdom of St. Matthew, St. Matthew and the Angel and Calling of Saint Matthew.
During religious ceremonies is burned incense and often hosts choirs of sacred music really enjoyable.
Stay tuned, it's worth it.
3 Carravaggio. Exquisite church... Full of intricate history! Pls read up on its origins before you visit. Next to the churc, there is a french library and many little stores...

Caravaggio In Situ. Caravaggio was a fierce genius and noted rabblerouser, so it's a bit odd to consider that he may be best viewed when he has played by all the rules. commissioned by the French clerics who owned this church, he produced an incredible triad of paintings depicting events in the life of Saint Matthew. For those unwilling or unable to spend hours in major galleries hunting for their favourite paintings, this is must-see viewing. Three works of genius placed where they were intended to be, so that the strategy of the painting's composition becomes evident. the rest of the church is pretty spectacular, too--really one of the most enjoyable tourist sites in Rome as it's never over-crowded.

St Louis of France. I particularly enjoy viewing art in the location for which it was created. In the last chapel on the left in this church are three large canvases of St. Matthew painted by Caravaggio for for just this spot. Awesome!

A must see. We enjoyed touring this wonderful church, especially because we are Caravaggio fans. The entrance is free, but take a few small coins so that you can turn on the lights at the Carvaggio section. Take your time and enjoy all of the beautiful art work.

Caravaggios !. One of the best places to see Caravaggio's! There are 3 paintings in the chapel and the entrance is free. The church is small, a bit hard to find, but is a few blocks from the Piazza Navona and the Pantheon, so you will probably pass nearby, when visiting Rome. Entrance is free.

Amazing Caravaggio. This humble church (in the shadow of the nearby Pantheon and Piazza Navona) houses some of the most amazing Caravaggio paintings. Take the effort to walk the extra 2 minutes from the Pantheon to visit this church.
Caravaggio. I love Caravaggio and this small church has three wonderful paintings by him that cannot be missed. It is very close to Piazza Navonna and easy to find. Please go and see for yourself.

Priceless artworks for free. The church is situated between the Pantheon and the Piazza Navona, adjacent to the Italian Senate. Inside and in the last chapel on the left hand side you will fine three major works by Caravaggio. As in many Roman churches you can illuminate the paintings by putting some coins in a slot. The paintings are stunning and apart from paying a few cent to switch on the lights, are totally free of charge to view. This is one of Rome's greatest treasures and one of my favourite places to visit when in the city.
Beautiful Caravachios. Near Piazza Navona and the paintings are beautiful. Deep meaning in the chiaroscuro. The life of St. Mathew in three paintings.
The ceiling will take your breath away!. Beautiful Church, not the biggest in Rome, but the ceiling is undoubtedly the stand out feature! Take your time walking round - you'll want to take it all in!
Visit the Church of San Luigi del Francesi. Beautiful church. Very ornate. Cool inside on a hot day.Caravaggios are worth the trip. Look up at the ceilings all through the church.
Wow!. To see the carravagios lit up wait for auto light to come on - it seems to come on at timed intervals - the paintings are amazing

Three beautiful paintings under your eyes. This art is a must see up close. It is hard to believe it is right there for all to wander in and see for free. Good for young kids as it is a single focused event.

amazin caravaggio insite. Go just to see the chapel with the caravaggio masterpieces. it is amazing how the ligh inside makes it even more beautiful. It is a short walk from the Pantheon and Piazza Navona.

Great Paintings. If you know anything about Caravaggio, this is the church to visit. His 3 paintings of St. Matthew are worth the trip inside. Remember to bring change to feed the lights. Yes, you must pay to have the lights turned on for a few seconds.
The paintings!. There are amazing paintings inside, three beautiful paintings of Caravaggio, and a beautiful architecture, totally worth it!

The Master for Free. Three Caravaggio's in the side nave of a church. What could be better? Go early or late. Beautiful interior. These churches are all amazing; the facade is right on the piazza so you do not get any feeling for the shape of the buildings, until you get inside.
C'est excellent !. Carravaggio's fantastic ! Church beautiful, a hidden little gem ! Walked there espescially to see Carravaggios works. Quiet and beautifully kept.

One of many fabulous churches in Rome. Don't miss this one! It lies between the Pantheon and Piazza Navona, very easy to locate. Remember to check opening times. (This one is closed noon til 3:30). This is the French church in Rome. Stunning marble, gold, art. Absolutely worth putting on your calendar!

Wonderful artwork in an interesting setting. I really like this church, but of course the highlight is the artwork. Recommended. It is between Plaza Navona and the Pantheon, so unless you are an unusual tourist, it is not out of your way at all.

Make sure you visit. When you've visited the main sites of Rome you want interesting places where you can take your time and really look at the history and architecture. This is a wonderful place to do that.
Must see Caravaggio!. One of a dozen or so must see churches. It is absolutely stunning and by the other comments, you know it is holding some true treasures.

Beautiful and FREE. A friend recommended this church, which is home to three Caravaggios. It is stunning and all of the paintings are beautiful. Amazingly, visiting this church is free. Definitely a don't miss if you are in Rome.

Stunning. What a beautiful church. The frescoes by Caravaggio are the main attraction. Be careful not to use flash-photography as the lights in the chapel are turned off when the sensors detect any flashes and everyone will turn and stare at you!
This is a must visit in Rome
Fortunate find. Came by this church by chance. Lovely Caravaggio paintings inside. If you find yourself in this area do not give it a miss.

Beautiful!. 3 Caravaggio paintings. Beautiful church near the Pantheon and piazza Narvona. Bring a coin to turn the lights on at the Caravaggio paintings or they will be dark. It is a coin operated light system. Ladies remember to cover your shoulders and knees.
Go Carravigio. A must see if you like this painter whose name I have most likely misspelled. Truly beautiful to see.

A Baroque Church with 3 Caravaggios. This gem is located in the Piazza Navona, perhaps Rome's loveliest. The Church was built in remembrance of the French who died in Rome. Its Contrelli Chapel contains 3 Caravaggio paintings, the Calling of St. Matthew, Matthew and the Angel, and Matthew's Martyrdom. You will have to put some euros in the coin machine to see them as the Church has figured out how to monetize visitors. San Luigi is Italian for St. Louis, the patron saint of France. The church and the Caravaggios are well worth seeing.

Caravaggio for free. Yes, it may be true: this is an opportunity to see two Caravaggio paintings for free. Unfortunately the one shown here is not among these two. However, you may be surrounded by hundreds of other tourists and you should be a real expert and/or Caravaggio lover in order to judge the importance of both paintings.
Try not to miss this Church.. We are glad we included this church as one of our places to see in the Piazza Navona area. The Caravaggios are amazing. Try not to miss this one.
Caravaggio. If you like Caravaggio this Church is a must. Particularly the Martyrdom of St Matthew is spectacular.

See Carvaggio without queueing for the Vatican Museum!. A pretty little church, hidden between Piazza Navona and The Pantheon. Definitely worth a look in, the artwork was amazing and admission is free!

The best place to see Caravaggio. Lovely church, convenient (right near Piazza Navona) and the best part of course are the Caravaggio paintings - 3 of the very best ones. Love it when it's not too crowded....

Wonderful!!!!!. Like most of the beauties in Rome, from the outside, this small church, situated in the Piazza San Luigi dei Francesi, next to Piazza Navona, ...seems unimportant. When you have a look inside, though, ...you might have a huge surprise!!! As it shelters 3 Carvaggio paintings, one more beautiful than the other. Even though next to one of the most crowded hotspots of Rome, ...here you will find a little bit of peace.

You must go!!. It is one of the churches you should not miss at all!It is a very moving experience..
You can take good photos there..
Caravaggio. Have to seek out the places that have his work. Well worth the effort. Fun to explore on your own and find the places that have his pieces
Caravaggio. Went there to see the Caravaggio paintings. The paintings are astonishing, and overall the church is nice.
A Caravaggio chapel; French national church in Rome. Large, extensively decorated. Caravaggio in front left chapel. Mass in French. Easy to find between Piazza Navona and Pantheon. Worth seeing.
beautiful church. it´s a romantic chucrch placed in the city center, one of the largest ones I have seen in Europe. beautiful barrocque decoration and nice floor design.

Even the postcard seller spoke French. The three wonderful paintings by Caraveggio of the Vocation of Saint Matthew are simply breathtaking. But there is so much more to see in this church which has been looking after the French in Rome since 1589. Lots of memorials to French citizens who spent time in Rome and other French religious memorabilia

Obviously to see both Caravagio. Just next to the French bookshop La Procure, close to the busy Piazza Navone & Campo de Fiori, quietness with beauty of the paintings. Even though Caravagio is not the one to lift you up, worth the visit.

A must visit for renaissance art lovers. This is the first review I have written on a church in Rome. I expect this will be the first of a number. I have visited 569 churches in Rome, which became a passion of mine. There is no better way to understand the history, the art (mosaics, painting, frescoes, sculpure, tapestries, vestments, sacred art), the architecture and the very essence of what Rome is all about. Whether it's bald face politics, wealth gone wild, or simple spirituality, it's all there within the walls of Rome's churches, shrine and chapels (which by my personal count, number more than 1800).I never come to Rome without stopping at San Luigi, and I will do so again four days from now. I am always drawn back by the Caravaggio paintings, each different, each unique, each (as the Italians say) suggestivo. The closest translation I have come across for this word is evocative, but that does not do the word justice. Make a beeline for the painting, in the far left forward chapel from where you enter the church. If no one has paid to turn on the spotlight, don't be a nerd: pay to turn them on. It's worth it. There are excellent signboards behind you with good enough explanations of the art for the casual visitor. If you need more, google the church and you will find plenty to read. Or simply google Caravaggio. I often hold conferences in Rome, and I always conduct a walking tour myself. If the church is open, I take the visitors there, usually after a nice espresso at the nearby Cafe St. Eustacchio. For Caravaggio devotees, I always then take them to the church of San Agostino, also close by, to see my favorite work by this artist: The Madonna of Loreto (or the name I prefer: the Madonna of the Pilgrims). I can gaze at this painting so intently that I can forget to breathe. Once again, pay to put the spotlight on it if others don't. As your eyes move around the painting, and you inevitably linger over the tired Mary holding a very robust baby boy, you feel as if she is carrying the future of the world. And for devout Christians, she was. I can think of no other painting of the madonna (and there are zillions) which captures this so well.

See Caravaggio's "Calling of St Matthew". This church is well worth a visit if you have the time and like Caravaggio. If you bring coins you can even light up the painting for yourself and everyone around you.
A couple of Caravaggio paintings. Pretty little church near Piazza Navona, there are two Caravaggio paintings. If the light is not on the paintings, there is a timed machine for a couple of euros.

BEAUTY AT ITS BEST!. Not only are the paintings a vision of their own, but the embellished vaulted ceilings are truey a sight of it's own! My husband and I decided to tour France and Italy for our 3 week honeymoon in late August. One word describes my honeymoon...Amazing!!! There is so much culture, history and breathtaking art to take in...3 weeks just wasn't enough time..so we're planning another trip back! Sightseeing throughout Rome takes a bit of walking around by foot, so start your days early and make sure you wear very comfy shoes and DO NOT forget your camera and your bottle of chilled water,...bring an umbrella if you go during the warmer months...the sun's a killer.

Caravaggio fans don't miss this, everyone else- eh.. But if you aren't a Caravaggio fan, it might not be worth braving the crowds to glimpse these three wonderful paintings displayed in the front left corner. It's a real squeeze with all the groups and classes. It's a lovely church, a bit overdone, actually, but hey, this is Baroque.
Must see church!. This was the first time we saw this church and it is one of the most magnificent in Rome! It's massive and the altars, especially the one of the Ludovici family, are beautiful!

impromptu organ concert. This was a stumbled upon oasis which was not very busy. It was a reprieve from the heat and ended up being a wonderful time of listening to someone practice the organ. Being a musician myself I loved sitting and listening for a while (free concert!). The Carvaggio paintings are stunning but I also enjoyed the chapel which a female artist and architect created. Worth a visit!

Stunning Caravaggios. 3 fantastic Caravaggios in the Contarelli Chapel - the St Matthew paintings. 'The Martyrdom of St Matthew', 'The Vocation of St Matthew' and the stunning 'St Matthew and the Angel'. Painted between 1599 and 1602. A 'must see'.

Caravaggio at his best. We will travel long and far to see his works, San Luigi's 3 pieces doesn't disappoint. The church is open to the public and is a popular site in Rome, so be prepared to deal with some crowds. Worth the effort for sure!
Oh, the Caravaggios!. Just gorgeous - don't miss them! Its definitely worth your while to put a coin in the slot so you can fully appreciate the Caravaggios. Don't miss the Inspiration of St Matthew!

In between Pantheon and Piazza Navona. I saw tons of tourists walk by this hotel without stopping as they made their way from the Pantheon to Piazza Navona - don't make the same mistake. Step inside for a rest, the ceiling is beautiful and there are 3 Caravaggios inside!
Nice. The feeling inside. Visited in my last day and Washington happy to choose it among the hundreds churches in Rome
Beautiful Church. Amazing, beautiful church that we stumbled into to get out of a hail storm whilst walking through Rome. A definite must see.
Well worth your time!. Go for the Carravaggio's, but take time to enjoy the rest of this beautiful church. Don't forget to look up!

A French church in Rome. Beautiful interior and they have the Caravaggio here! The neighborhood has the French library for the French community and they were very nice to my daughter. They gave her a nice book bag. The area is well-guarded by police. My daughter thinks the Senate buildng is next door, hence the security.

The Best of Caravaggio. There many famous churches in Rome, but this one is more famous for the art it contains rather than the building itself. From the outside, you may wonder why you see so many people coming and going into this rather ordinary façade. The reason is Caravaggio, arguably the most (in)famous painter to ever live and work in Rome. His reputation as a hooligan and troublemaker is only outdone by his talent as an artist. He didn’t produce that many paintings during his short life, but the very best of what he did produce is here (for free) in this church. Don't miss it. Of course, there are many masterpieces by history’s greatest artists scattered throughout this incredible city. But Caravaggio manages to stand out, even among this cast of all-star talent. In the words of one critic: “There was art before him and there was art after him—and they were not the same.” One look inside this church and you'll see why.

Don't skip it. It's in the Centro Storico (near Piazza Navona), you can visit it any time you're walking around. There were much lesser crowd than in other famous churches, and it was interesting that almost all the other visitors were french. The paintings of Caravaggio are also beautiful.

Caravvagio!!!. A very interesting Church with a french touch. I've seen so many epitaphs there that I fell like visiting a cemetery. But what bring most tourists here are 3 of the most renowned Caravvagios that can't be missed. They give you a great idea of the sense of perspective and colours of this striking artist.
Wow wow wow. Maybe the best work of caravaggio. What can you ask for more? 3 paintings that will just take your breath away. If you are art lover dont miss it.

A must for the Caravaggios. Closed for lunch from 1230 - 1500.Beautiful church interior. And art from one of the real masters (that you have to pay to have illuminated, so bring change, max coin is 1euro).
Beautiful. Nice church, small and really well decorated.But what's amazing are the Caravaggio paintings.Wonderfull, take a look!

an amazing church - some of Caravaggio's most famous paintings can be seen here- well worth a visit. Anyone interested in Italian art must visit this church to see the wonderful dark, deep paintings of Michangelo Merisi (Caravaggio) in the last chapel on left side of altar. The church itself is a typical baroque splendour - don't miss it.
Do not miss !!. Il Caraveggio = Michelangelo !!, St Matthew's vocation. We almost missed it so plan accorindgly to ensure you add that magnificent step in your Rome planning :-)

Awesome. This place is fantastic but for sure not the best thing to do in Rome. I can tell you the best thing to do is get a bicycle and go everywhere and see everything in the eternal city center. You are in a open-work museum free of charge.
One of Rome's not-to-be missed churches. When in Rome, pop into as many churches as you can -- you will be astounded by the amount of art tucked away in these little churches.

money for light. three of the most beautiful painting by Caravaggio are here, but it is very inconvenient that people have to pay to get some light, I would suggest the church to ask for money in a less vitious way

Beautiful Carravaggios, well worth the visit. San Luigi dei Francesi is a must see for Carravaggisti. "The Calling of Saint Matthew" is worth the trip on its own. As an added bonus, you get the other two pieces of the St. Matthew cycle while you are there! The church itself is a lovely small basilica dedicated to the French community in Rome. It has an interesting history with the Medici family, if you are interested in exploring that sort of thing.
Caravaggio's Best Hang Here. Very nice quiet church near the Pantheon. Caravaggio's three work on St. Matthew hang here. Be sure not to miss them while you are at the Pantheon.

Check out Caravaggio's paintings. A very nice church located near the pantheon, bring some 50c coins to see the three Caravaggio paintings of the Calling of St. Matthew! (It's on the left side, close to the altar). You will need to put 50c into the box to illuminate the paintings for a min or so.

Beautiful painting by Caravaggio. Each time I visit this Church I am blown away by the life like Caravaggio which even the darker colours he has always used do not appeal to all. This painting is though really beautiful and lifelike. Caravaggio is a real master and this painting showcases his talent.The church has a wonderful decorated ceiling. Well worth a browse . Obviously as we are in Italy the entrance to this church is free.This church is near Piazza Navona and the Italian Senate.

Fantastic Caravaggios!. There are 3 beautiful Paintings from the life of St Matthew by Caravaggio in this church. These paintings are still hanging in the chapel for which they were commissioned over 400 years ago.

Wonderful. We found the reviews of this church on trip advisor and decided we would visit. Trust me you will not be disappointed, it is a thoroughly beautiful church containing and wonderful painting by Caravaggio and a beautifully decorated ceiling. Worth checking the opening times before you visit.

Caravaggio's best work makes this Roman Church a "Must-See". The best Caravaggio painting can be found here. "The Calling of St. Matthew" was a pivotal work in the artists career and Caravaggio's mastery of light has never been better showcased.I strongly recommend a visit to this church, if only to see this one painting. The church itself is also beautiful and worth a visit but the Caravaggio pieces (this one in particular) make it stand out amongst other Roman churches.
hidden gem. one of many beautiful, ornate churches; noteworthy for 3 large Caravaggio paintings in one chapel. Right on Piazza Navona, behind the larger fountain.

I liked the Church St. Louis of the French in Rome. I liked it, is worth a visit during a stay in the Eternal City.
The church St. Louis of the French in Rome is not far from Piazza Navona, in the district of Saint Eustace. It is the national church of the French in Rome from 1589.
Splendid. Beautiful church, splendid painting. We arrived there in the catholic Easter Friday, in the evening, it gave us an amazing religious feeling, even though we re orthodox.
Beautiful church. Try to listen to a "missa cantata", it's a wondeful experience. Beautiful art also. Too much tourists - try to avoid weekends.
Beautiful. A must going church.In the central area.Not crowded and free.Fantastic.Must be quiet and show your respect.
Beautiful church and paintings. Beautiful church and paintings. Have to see the Caravaggios! Liked it very much! One piece of art after another...

Must See for Caravaggio Lovers. Context for my review: I travel the globe to see works by Caravaggio, which gives this church for me the rating of 5. In a small chapel in the back left of this otherwise lovely church are three magnificent Caravaggio paintings depicting the life of St. Matthew. It is just a few steps from the Pantheon, so even if you are not (yet) a Caravaggio fan, do stop in. This is a church, so there is no charge. LIke most churches, though, it is closed mid day. Bring coins to illuminate the chapel, which is otherwise too dark to see the paintings. Serious viewers -- binoculars recommended to see the wonderful detail.

Beautiful church with wonderful paintings. A wonderful church to visit, though it was difficult to see the famous Caravaggio paintings as everyone just migrated to that corner and it was difficult for all to see.

Magnificent Caravaggio's. Came upon this church by accident and found three enormous and important Caravaggio's of world renown. There were guides leading private tours but mostly uncrowded. It's a beautiful church as well with a French flair, lots of blue and gold.The Caravaggios are of St. Matthew with three major works, well worth a visit if you are in the Centro Storico.
wonderful. Please go out of your way to visit this beautiful church.The Carvaggio paintigs are fantastic but not the only reason to visit!
3 Caravaggios. The French church in Rome contains the chapel of St Matthew, with 3 Caravaggios. Worth a stop in the Piazza Navona neighborhood.
Well worth a visit. Amazing place that you must visit if you are close by. Beautiful church with wonderful artwork and decoration

Great Caravaggios!. The external façade does not call your attention, but as everybody said, this church is not to be missed for three paintings by the old maester in the Contarelli chapel on the left corner right, before the main altar (you will see a lot of people staring). The Inspiration of St. Matthew, the one in the middle, is simply breathtaking. You should also pay attention to the Ceiling, by Domenichino. I recommend going there while you're walking in the region of the Piazza Navona.
Beautiful. One of the many beautiful churches that were open to share their treasures with the visiting public. Everywhere you looked it took your breath away.

Go for the Caravaggios!. It's extraordinary to see 3 magnificent Caravaggios still hanging in the church in which they were originally hung. There are posted warnings not to go beyond the railing in front of the niche in which the paintings hang, but one can get close enough to get an excellent look (enhanced enormously by paying 50 Euro cents, if I remember correctly, to activate the lights). A definite must-see in Rome.

Home of 3 Caravaggio's paintings. Best way to identify this church is saying that is the Home of 3 Caravaggio's paintings. Is a church dedicated to Virgin Mary, to St. Denis the Areopagite and St. Louis IX, king of France. Is relativaly close to Piazza Navona. It's a very beautifull inside (like most of all churches) and have 3 paintings of Caravaggio: "The Calling of St. Matthew", "The Inspiration of St. Matthew" and "The Martyrdom of St. Matthew". Definitely deserves a visit! Visited March 2013

Three of Caravaggio's fine works.. I am sure that many people who visit Rome find time to visit some of the famous churches and art museums but few people know about the Church of San Luigi dei Francesi which is very close to Piazza Navona. In this church, in a chapel to the left close to the altar, one can find the Contaralli Chapel. This chapel is blessed by three large Caravaggio paintings, one for every side. Here a visitor can enjoy THE CALLING OF MATTHEW, THE INSPIRATION OF ST MATTHEW and THE MARTYRDOM OF ST.MATTHEW. Every time I visit Rome I always find time to go to this church and just gaze in wonder at these wonderful works of Caravaggio.I hope that if you are in Rome you too will visit this church and enjoy these three paintings.
Caravaggio. In this church there are 3 magnificient paintings of the unique baroc master Michelangelo Merisi - Caravaggio.
It was emotional!. Small Church, closed Thursday afternoons and between 1230 and 1500hrs other days. Worth a visit.Stunning Caravaggios and a sense of peace,

Three Caravaggio amongst the best. Worth a walk when in Rome, beautiful location (apart the close vicinity to Italian political life which to most Italians is somewhat disturbing!) wonderful masterpieces by Caravaggio. You could spend hours admiring them. I live in Rome and every time I pass by I go there and look at those marvelous paintings.And then a suggestion: 50 mt walk to the near Caffè Sant'Eustachio, where one of the best coffees of Rome (probably worldwide can be drunk.

A trio of Caravaggio's finest. If you happen to be in the vicinity of Piazza Navona, you must view the interior of this church. From my research prior to our last trip, I knew there was a reason I wanted to visit this place but couldn't remember why. Once inside and in the far left corner I knew! Three of Caravaggio's finest paintings. I was surprised at the size of them - for some reason I thought they were of a smaller scale but they were large and fantastic. We lucked out that there was a very small group of art students there and they shared their knowledge with us. One of the highlights of the "culture" side of our trip.
Carravagio murals!. Make the effort to see the Carravagio murals which are excellent. Take 1 euro to turn on the lights.
Loved this. Loved this place. It was very well signposted too suprisingly. The ceilings were very impressive indeed and one could definitely have a moment of reflection and a feeling of peace in here
Close up on Caravaggio. Three paintings in one place. Just stunning. Starts you off wanting to find out more and more about the painter and the history of the time.
Caravaggio. Wonderful Caravaggio. Stunning, a must see. Get there early so as not to be tripping over groups. Also visit the church of sSan Agostino nearby for another Caravaggio experience.

Go for the paintings. The church itself is of limited interest. But the chapel at the rear left has one of the greatest masterpieces of Italian Art -- Caravaggio's "The Calling of St Matthew." Remember to take some coins. The paintings are in a dark chapel. You need to put coins in the meter to turn on the lights.
Lovely,indeed.... Another lovely,lovely,church to tour and see and feel the beauty and take time to look at each and all in this lovely building.

Great paintings but you have to keep "donating" to see the. Do not miss this Church if you are near Piazza Navona. There are 3 famous paintings by Caravaggio. Be prepared to bring along some coins as the paintings will only be lit if you put in coins! And the lights go off pretty fast which can be quite frustrating when you're admiring the amazing paintings :(
Beautiful Church. A French Catholic Church near Piazzan Navona. Worth a trip if in the area. There are several paintings by Caraviggio about the life of St. Matthew.

Three great Caravaggio paintings - for free!. This is an attractive church in its own right, and it's worth strolling round and looking at all the little chapels. But everyone really comes here for the three Caravaggio paintings in the Contarelli Chapel (the last chapel on the left hand side of the church). It can get very crowded, especially as it has limited opening hours (1000-1230,1600-1900), and you can't actually go into the chapel - you see the paintings on the side walls from an angle.The three paintings are:The Calling of St Matthew (left wall): Matthew the tax-collector is sitting in a dingy room, the setting is the Rome of Caravaggio's own time. Christ enters on the right and points at him. It's not totally clear who Matthew is.St Matthew and the Angel (behind the altar): a younthful angel is dictating the gospel to the elderly Matthew. Matthew is balancing precariously on a stool and looks like he's about to topple over!The Martyrdom of St Matthew (right wall): Matthew is attacked during a Mass service. A very chaotic work, perhaps the least successful of the three. Possibly a self-portrait of Caravaggio, in the background to the left of the supposed assassin.

Art!. One of the richest Roman churches,a lot to see and admire, but soooo crowded and loud. Since admission is free I went there several times because during my first visit I couldn't see anything but people blocking my view :(

Must see. With hundreds of churches in Rome you must be a little picky. This is one is worth every second. Right in the center of Rome (between Pantheon and Piazza Navona) it is the house of extraordinary paintings and architecture
Beautiful Church and Artwork inside. There are so many churches in Rome that it is hard to keep track! This is a very beautiful church with wonderful artwork inside. Make sure to cover arms and legs.

Caravaggio, Caravaggio, Caravaggio. Just around the corner from Piazza Navona is this attractive Baroque church housing one of the greatest set of Caravaggios, his breakthrough paintings of the Calling & Martyrdom of St. Matthew & his slightly later image of the saint penning the gospels. You can sit here for hours feeding coins into the lightbox and noticing new details with each illumination. The tax collectors poring over their coins. The way Christ's feet have already turned to leave. The evangelist's bench poised to topple into the void. This is the birth of the realist face of Baroque art, & it doesn't get any better than seeing the works in the chapel for which they were intended. Not to be missed.
outstanding. Fantastic church, with Caravaggio paintings inside! Few steps far away from our hotel, we discovered this fabolous church. The paintings are simply outstanding!!!!!Free entrance.

Beautiful church. This French church is located between the Pantheon and the Piazza Navona. There are 3 famous Caravaggio paintings located inside the church but you should visit with attention the church, not only Caravaggio...it's very nice and particular

How many Church's can a person see..... Well as many as you can. All are quite unique and amazing and this is no exception. Do yourself a favour and visit as many as you can. They are always free.Just a reminder that I have forgotten to mention in previous reviews. Women must cover their shoulders when in a church. Some also still have issue with women showing knees, however it is not enforced as mush as the shoulders. I have seen security block women from entering a church.Guys take your hats off, or you will be told by plain clothes security.Cheers
Caravaggio !. Fabulous Caravaggio paintings which stand out from the rest of the artwork in the church. Just fabulous.

Wow. Beautiful church. Wonderful Caravaggios! And on the evening I first visited it in December there was a bright blue peanut shaped balloon clinging to the ceiling right in front of San Luigi! I enjoyed this as I've seen the ceiling many times before, but I imagine the parents of the child who lost it had to return to the Christmas Fair in Piazza Navona around the corner to replace the baloon.

Caravaggio paintings. For most people the main reason for visiting this church is to see the paintings by Caravaggio in the Contarelli Chapel. The Call of Matthew, the Martyrdom of St Matthew and St Matthew and the Angel are all outstanding - provided you have one or two euros to hand!

definitely must visit. amazing church,in the centre of the town,outside nothing special but the inside is important to see. we liked it a lot, the most remarkable is that the entrance is freee. just keep your mind in the time table schedule.

Do not miss it. It is a must in Rome, have a look at the Caravaggio's San Matthew's trittico, this is marvelous. The rest o fhe church is jus a classical baroque style church. Also nice French book store next to the church if you like reading in Moliere's language.

Caravaggio!. this amazing church ahs three Caravaggio inside, that you can admire. This is a place you can't miss!
Entrance it's for free, you will only have to pay for lighting up, but it's only 1 euro.

Caravaggio and a whole lot more. This church is definitely worth a visit, even if it is just to see Caravaggio's brilliant work but just remember you need some coins to switch the lights on (but it is worth it)
I loved this church!. Is located near Farnese square and is so huge and amazing. We took a guide to help us is out trip to this church
church to visit. beautiful church in which there are many paintings, statues, and much more..... also the area near the church is lovely with many shops etc... etc....

coins neeeded. a must for any art lover. 3 caravaggios and one of them the calling of st matthew which is considered to be one of his best. make sure to take coins to feed the lightning !! i think it was 1 euro . do read about the painter and his background first, you will enjoy his realism a lot more .
Beautiful Church. absolutely beautiful artwork in this church, it is a must see while in rome there are so many to see in rome
The French Church. We loved the interior. Having walked past the outside several times we went in. Well worth it for the Caravaggios alone!
Beautiful Caravaggio's St Matthew. Wonderful, breathtaking cycle of three Caravaggio paintings. Definitely worth a visit, may be much more so than some other popular Roman destinations.

Fantastic!. I love churches and art galleries so this was one of my favourite places I visited while in Rome. The paintings are out of this world and in such a serene setting the overall experience is very moving and not to be missed if you are a true art fan.

beautiful with roman architecture. as a matter of fact, you have time and let's go to the church to pray for goods. This one is special because it is in Rome, lots of people got there to pray for. it is a good place
3 great paintings.. definitely come here if you are a carravaggio fan. three great paintings two of which are almost never reproduced.
Hidden Caravaggio. Not to be missed-Caravaggio in the the back left of the church. A coin lights up the altar. Check the opening hours. Smack between the Piazza Navona and the Pantheon

Beautiful church. This French church is located between the Pantheon and the Piazza Narona. There are three famous Caravaggio paintings located to the left of the altar. "The Calling of Matthew" involves the tax collector Matthew, Jesus and Peter. Jesus points to Matthew to ask him to be his disciple. "The Inspiration of St. Matthew" involves Matthew and an angel. "The Martyrdom of St. Matthew" shows Matthew and his killer. Caravaggio used common lower class people as models in the paintings. The lighting on the paintings is dark until someone spends a euro for the area to be lit. An interesting way for the church to make money.The church is open from 10-12:30 and 3-7. Different hours on Sunday.

Paintings. There's a church, too.. Just... The paintings are so amazing that you do get distracted by the church itself, which is not something to ignore by itself. Just go there, look at it, stay there in awe for a few hours.

Carravaggio. It is a beautiful church with a baroque decor but the most attractive sights are the three paints by Carravaggio which are stored here. Strictly recommend for everybody who are interested in italian painting.

Not sure how this became number 1.. We go to San Luigi dei Francesi every time we are in Rome. It has three beautiful Caravaggio paintings and is a gorgeous church. The Calling of St. Mathew is a must see.That is 30 minutes, at most, of a visit for any one. St. Peters, the Forum, The Colosseum, the Dori a Pamphilj Museum and on and on. Not to be missed, but not number 1.
Beautiful paintings. This church is just around the corner from Piazza Navona and is nothing from the outside. However it is well worth a visit for the beautiful paintings - three by Caravaggio.

Caravaggio...... It is worthwhile to visit it just for the Caravaggio paintings! The church itself is not exceptional. In Rome we have much better churches to show off, but here are kept three Caravaggio paintings!
Worth a vist. Liked the sculptures, Caravaggio and other paintings, marble and structure - oh, and the opulence. Loved it.
Beautiful church. This church was not recommended in our guide but we enterred because there was lot of people coming in! This is a really beautiful place to go.
Different little church. Off the main tourist track. Small French church but with a Caravaggio altar piece. Italy never fails to impress with little things like this. Pretty little church.

Caravaggio!. The amazing thing about Rome is that it's like a living museum: it's so modern and sexy and just ROMAN -- but it exists in and around some of the world's most amazing and priceless art. Because of this, you don't ever need to set foot in a museum to see works of art: many great works are just sitting there in churches, in little side chapels. Just sitting there. Not hidden behind glass, not 50 feet away -- just right there in front of you.So it is with this church, which houses 3 very well-known Caravaggios. Even if you've never heard of Caravaggio or you don't know a thing about art, you will recognize these paintings. There's always a small group of in-the-know tourists there during open hours taking a peek and (non-flash) photos of the paintings... you can drop in some coins to activate the lights for a minute or two as well. Make a point of stopping in here and wander over to the side chapel up front, and you'll be amazed at what a Caravaggio looks like in person. Such exquisite painting that it looks like it's somehow illuminated from the inside. It's unbelievable that you're allowed to stand just a few feet away from these masterworks, which have been sitting here for hundreds of years.

Come for the Caravaggio. Some churches are must sees for everyone, such as St Peter’s Basilica. However, this one’s really just for devotees of Baroque art and religious history enthusiasts. And of course, the French.Our walking tour through the ancient centre stopped here briefly to show us Caravaggio’s three canvasses depicting the life of St Matthew, the Calling, the Inspiration, and the Martyrdom. You can also see Domenichino’s Histories of Saint Cecilia frescoes, among the works of other Baroque artists. Unfortunately for me, as a blind man, it was meaningless.And for the history nuts, this is apparently the church where Martin Luther stayed when he came to Rome for his trial. But unless you’ve got a specific interest, I probably wouldn’t waste your time.

Beautiful !. Really beautiful and ornate church with the three famous Caravaggio paintings. We were lucky to be there when there was no crowd. There were hardly 3 people in the church and the atmosphere was simply divine ! it was just so peaceful. Just when we were about to leave, a group of about 50 people walked in. So we considered ourselves very lucky to have the church all to ourselves for a good 30 mins. Wonderful experience.
The Caravaggio is worth it!. The church is not far from the beaten track...Spanish steps, Trevi fountain, piazza navona, pantheon. The Call of Matthew, by Caravaggio, is worth the stop.
Caravaggio Lovers. This is a wonderful place to see three Caravaggios. Just wander in off the street. Truly beautiful. It is also on the route between Piazza Navona and the Pantheon.
Do not miss it. Beautiful Caravaggio paintings. The church is home to the French community, Masses are held in French and sometimes Latin.
Nice half-hour stop near the Pantheon. I enjoyed seeing this very ornate church near the Pantheon. There are three Rafael paintings, not to be missed, and a beautiful ceiling fresco.
Caravaggio and Church fans only. A great place to admire the Caravaggio paintings, and the actual church and alter was just as impressive. Try going early mornings to avoid the tourists.

Caravaggio is great. The church is great (as are so many in Rome) but it is not far from the must visit piazza Navona. The 3 paintings by Caravaggio are amongst the best in Rome. Take coins to turn the lights on. One of the highlights of my Rome trip.
Nice Church. Must stop and visit it. it's one of the church you can visit in Rome but this one has an impressive decoration, painting and details.
Breath taking Caravaggio. Stunning church that is easy to get to and you will be rewarded with a Caravaggio. What more could you want?
The best Caravaggio is here !!!. A small beautiful church with the best paintings of Caravaggio. It belongs to the French community of Rome, so there's a lovely French bookstore next to it.

My favorite Church in Rome. Do you know the painter Caravaggio? This beautiful Baroque church has THREE paintings by Caravaggio. Step up to the nave, put a Euro in the box and the lights come on for a short time. Breathtaking.
The church is beautiful, too, and different from others, as it's a French church, all done in blues and golds.
Definitely a must-see.

Must See in Rome. This is one my favorite churches in Rome. Not really for the church aspect of it, but for the wonderful art there. Don't go looking for a pious experience, as it seems more like a museum. That said, the art there is breathtaking and moving, and a must see for visitors and residents of Rome.

The reviews don't lie. This is a wonderful church. To see the three Caravaggio masterpieces as they were meant to be displayed is simply breathtaking, but to sit in one of the pews and soak in the rest of the church and the unforgettable smell of incense is an experience in and of itself. The place is oozing with the former glory of Western civilization. A more personal, and for me more spiritual experience than larger, more famous churches like Saint Peter's and Saint John Lateran.

One word, Caravaggio.... St Luigi del Francesi is a beautiful church in a city of many beautiful churches, but it has 3 Caravaggio paintings on St Matthew. No other church can make that claim. If you had limited time to enjoy Rome, this is one site I would recommend.

the incredible Contarelli Chapel. The ability to see the three Caravaggio paintings in this small chapel - all relating to St matthew - at such close quarters and in such perfect light conditions is an incredible and breathtaking experience everytime one goes. One can study them for hours.
Magnificent. CARAVAGGIO painting! Beautiful high baroque small church just one block from Piazza Navona. A MUST go.
Lovely church. Lovely church and art. Too many tourists and tour guides talking for a church in my opinion. The explanations of the art at the naves are in Italian and French. ( no english)
Nice church. Definitely worth a visit. Its free, so pop in and check it out. Well recommended. It's definitely a beautiful church.
italiansmarttraveller. great paintings. unique! few people know it, many citizens don't know about it. paintings are all in the art books.

Caravaggio is the best in the world. amazing! the paintings of Caravaggio are admirable...Domenichino painted here one of his masterworks, the frescoes portraying the Histories of Saint Cecilia. we loved it and decorations
A Church Not to Miss. San Luigi dei Francesi should not be missed. The church itself is lovely and the Caravaggio painting of "The Call of Matthew should be seen. Important to check hours of opening.

Three Amazing Caravaggio Paintings. The church is hard to find, but if you are interested in Caravaggio, make the effort. A Google map helps. The three paintings depict scenes from the life of St. Matthew, each showing down-to-earth people caught as if in a dramatic moment. My favorite is his "calling." No one could look more astonished. You can almost hear the saint-to-be saying, "Who? Me?"This church can be combined with two others in the area: Santa Maria del Popolo and the Basilica di Sant' Agostino. A good plan would be to start with the Santa Maria in the Piazza del Popolo and walk down toward Piazza Navona to the other two. This could easily be a morning's excursion, but be sure to check on line for opening hours.

No crowds; Amazing art. I am glad we went a few blocks out our way to go to this church. A little desk to buy postcards, etc, which was nice. When the lights dim, a machine that takes coins will illuminate the masterpieces for you.
Great Carvaggio's. The 3 Carvaggio paintings depicting St. Matthew at small chapel on the left are special. There is beautiful marble throughout interior.
Caravaggio. Check out the painting by Carravaggio - the Call of St. Matthew. They sell copies of the picture if you are interested.
Carravagios for free. A bit of a downer as tour groups entered the church to see the paintings, but as it is free to enter it is worth going in every time you pass

Beautiful Church. This was one of the first sights we saw in Rome was very ornate and beautiful. I will say if I go back to Rome it will not be something I would see again but very worth your while for a first timer.

Don't miss . It is worth travelling to Rome just to see the three amazing Caravaggio pieces that are the focal point of this very beautiful church. It's quite central; take the time to stop and spend some time here.
Caravaggio. No crowd beautiful church, and if your a fan of Caravaggio, it's a must. Three of his paintings, including the calling of St. Matthew.

Caravaggio reigns. The three Caravaggio paintings make this a must see. Bring change to pay for lighting the pictures -I can't remember if this was 50 cents or one euro. If you visit on Sunday as we did, you may have to wait until a service concludes, so as not to interfere with the worship. The service itself is quite interesting.

Surprising find!. This was a real surprise! Three caravaggios in one church just a few minutes walk from our hotel. The church itself is stunning but the artwork was a real surprise! We loved it so much we visited a couple of times.
Caravaggio. If you enjoy Caravaggio paintings- must go. It can easily be enjoyed on the way to dinner in the Pantheon/Navona area.

A little known gem. We wouldn't have known about this French national church but for a book I was reading set in Rome. So glad we didn't miss it as it had 3 wonderful Caravaggios all dedicated to St. Matthew hanging in the fifth chapel on the left.

Must see in Rome. If you're a Caravaggio lover you must go to this church. The last chapel on the left side of the church contains three stunning Caravaggios of St. Matthew. This would be worth the visit alone, but the rest of the church is spectacular as well. One of our favorite churches on our whole Italian trip.

Gorgeous. We thought we were jaded after several days in Rome, which of course means that we had visited a lot of churches, But this one is truly a Wow! Paintings by Carvaggio were what brought us here but the church interior is amazing in itself.
Chapel of St Matthew.. This church is in the Pantheon neighborhood. It is the French church in Rome. The Chapel of St Matthew contains 3 Caravaggios and is not to be missed.

The Paintings Make it Worth the Trip. We went on a Monday in October and there were no crowds. The paintings were stunning. The images just jumped out at you. You can never get that feeling by looking at them in a photograph or a print. I am not an artistic person but in my opinion, this is a must see.

Must see, not only for art lovers. In a city where art is in every corner, the Church "Saint Luigi dei Francesi", is a real jewel, the
church in itself, plus the Caravaggio paintings. If visiting the city of Rome, go.
Not to be missed Caravaggios. Beautiful little church near Piazza Navonne. 3 stunning Caravaggios. Be sure to put your coin in the box to keep the paintings lit.

Bring change for the Carravagio's. Just a short walk from the Piazza Navona and worth it for the three St. Matthew pictures by Caravagio. Make sure that you have a .50 or 1 euro coin to light up the chapel where they are hung.
Beautiful church. Beautiful church shame there was so little to read in English. The Carvaggio paintings are wonder to behold.

You can not miss Caravaggio masterpieces!. San Luigi dei Francesi Church is a place to visit absolutely. The church itself is very nice and interesting, but the main reason to visit iot are the 2 masterpieces of Caravaggio placed in one of its chappels. You'll be delighted! and if you try to go there early morning, you'll get a fantastic experience: you and Caravaggio masterpieces all for you!

2 Caravaggio's works, not in a museum. The church was built for French troops, stationed in Rome - hence the name.It houses 2 Caravaggio's paintings: "The Inspiration of St. Matthew", "The Calling of St. Matthew" and "The Martyrdom of Saint Matthew". To get an opportunity to see them, you'll have to drop a coin in a donation box for the light.There's a statue of Joan of Arc near the entrance, easily recognizable.

Caravaggio groupies!. Before you come to Rome, do yourself a favour and watch the episode about Caravaggio from Simon Sharma's BBC series about great painters. The rock star of his era, Caravaggio was by all accounts a bit of a lad, but his paintings are mesmerising. Anywhere else in the world, paintings of this calibre would have top shelf security and cost you a bit to see. Not in Rome. Within 100 metres you can see four Caravaggios for free (take a few euro coins for the light boxes though), not to mention a Raphael and a few other not-too-shabby artists. This church is particularly beautiful. While the other paintings are "nice", you'll know when you're looking at Caravaggio's St Matthew's Vocation (3 paintings) - apart from his use of light and shade, he was unique in his inclusion of ordinary people in his scenes. Once you've finished here, head around the corner to Sant' Agostino church to see Caravaggio's "Madonna di Loreto" and a Raphael fresco (on a pillar near the rear of the hunch and not easy to spot!). Again free, but take euro coins for the light boxes and be aware the churches close for a few hours in the afternoon. For more Caravaggios, buy a ticket to the gallery at Villa Borghese and also the Capitoline Museum.
Beautiful Caravaggio paintings. A very nice church, but as fans of Caravaggio's work we went to see the paintings. Three large canvasses on the subject of St. Matthew.

very beautiful church. very beautiful church not far from Piazza Navona and pantheon you can see wonderful paintings of Caravaggio I recommended to visit it If you like the paintings of Caravaggio this church

Close to Pantheon, three Caravaggio's almost for free. Just a few blocks from the Pantheon, you can see three Caravaggio's masterpieces in this baroque church - almost for free. The three large paintings of St Mathew’s life (The Calling, The Inspiration and The Martyrdom) are located to the left from the altar in an unlit niche. If you want to see them in full light for one minute, you have to put one euro into the coin-box. If there are more interested visitors, and with some fair sharing, you can stick around to admire the paintings a little longer. Do not forget the ceilings - plenty of light there and no coin-box for the sunlight.

No words. In this little church next to "Palazzo Madama" you can see wonderful paintings of Caravaggio.Put a coin in the box, and paintings will come out of obscurity and will be illuminated for a minute that you will feel at the same time eternal and too short.Pure emotion.

Three Caravaggio Masterpieces for free. Here there are three Caravaggio Masterpieces for free: on the right wall the Martyrdom of St. Matthew, in the left Calling of St. Matthew, and the altar, St Matthew and the Angel.

"Calling Of St Matthew" by Caravagio. One of the world's great masterpieces on display. If you are lucky, you may have this painting all to yourself, which is located in one of the side altars at San Luigi. Put a euro in the coinbox to illuminate it for a few minutes and enjoy!
Splendid Caravaggios. My favourite 16th century bad boy didn't disappoint - these are vibrant, compelling paintings that will astound you.

Caravaggio!. If you like the paintings of Caravaggio this church is on the must see list. Not just one, but 2 magnificent Caravaggios. Spend a few coins to turn on the lights and you will be transported

A Trio of Caravaggios. We happened to pop into this church during our recent visit. We have gone through the churches of the city quite methodically during our visits, and Caravaggio's art is a favourite theme for us. So we were astonished that we had missed this one: an interesting church historically, in its iconography and most of all because of its artworks. It was a lucky find, especially because there seemed to be a special occasion with informative tables about all the paintings. As this is a church that served the city's prominent Frenchmen, it's no surprise that you can find Jean of Arc and other notable figures there. As always, a good guidebook is useful if you want to enjoy the place thoroughly, but remember to put the book down from time and enjoy the silence.
Some amazing art work in this church. As the title says, this church has some beautiful artwork on display. Worth the visit and the pictures you will obtain. Closed Thursdays afternoons.

Beautiful but overrated. The church is beautiful and hte Caravaggios are impressive, but to say this is the second-ranked attraction in all of Rome is a bit of a stretch.
