Most defitinitely worth a stop, and very convenient, as it's located very near Piazza Navona and the Pantheon, but don't let your expectations be overblown by the high rating and abundance of glowing reports.

Caravaggio!!!. Don't forget to visit this hidden gem, very close to Pantheon and Piazza Navona.It contains 3 of the most beautiful paintings by Caravaggio.You should remember that most churches in Rome -including this - remain closed for the public between 12:30-16:00
A gem. This is the first visit to this particular church and it is hard to see how I could have missed it out on previous visits. The Caravaggios of course are the main attraction.

Who needs a crowded, expensive museum!. Who could guess that such an anonymous looking church from the exterior could house such magnificent treasures? The interior of this church are truly awe inspiring. This church has to be one of Rome’s hidden gems, as there were very few people there when we were visiting and we were able to take our time and soak up the Caravaggio’s. A few coins in the light box and you will hear a collective gasp as the magnificent paintings are illuminated. Save time and effort queuing for expensive and crowded museums and instead spend some time in this cool, relaxing and free oasis. Bear in mind that like most churches in Rome is closes for a few hours during lunch time (think its 12:30-15:00 in this case). Remember also that the dress code calls for trousers or skirts below the knee and shoulders to be covered. I carried a light shawl with me on our visit during the summer, which I wrapped around me when entering churches.

Beautiful! Located very close to the Pantheon. I really enjoyed this church, but was a little shocked that it's #2 on TripAdvisor. Perhaps, that is partly because seeing it is so convenient. It is literally a 2 minute walk from the Pantheon. If you visit the Pantheon, you should definitely check out this church.I loved seeing the Caravaggios. I was unfamiliar with him before taking a tour of the Borghese Gallery where I learned more about his works and his life (from their audioguide). Overall, it's very convient and beautiful. I would recommend going if you visit the Pantheon.
Caravaggio. Closed Thursdays. Remember your 1 euro for the lights and avoid on Sunday's as services run and you cannot access the paintings.
Go inside!. This place looked small and normal outside but once we went inside, it was wow! Very beautiful inside, and quiet and we were very much humbled by the slience and beauty.
Beautiful art. For those interested in the arts,this place is not to be missed,Caravaggio in its full glory.The ceilings are amazing with its gold painted wood and frescos,quite mind blowing.
don't miss this one. Carravagio paintaings are worth seeing. Check the opening hours, amny churches are closed after lunch and reopen late afternoon

Amazing Chruch. We accidentally stumbled into this amazing gem of a church during our May trip to Italy. It is sort of off the tourist radar books and sites to see, but the art work and the building is a must see. It is a close walking distance from Navona square.
WOW. Abit of a hidden gem this one. Took awhile to find it only to find it was closed... did go back and it was worth the effort!!

A riot of baroque color. Caravaggios worth seeing.. We visited this church to see the Carravagios. Definitely worth seeing especially The Calling of St Matthew and the Angel and St Matthew. Most of the rest of the interior of the church was too lavishly decorated and ornate for our tastes.
CARAVAGGIO. Go there for excellent Caravaggio paintings in Rome! No fees no charges, no queues. 50 Cents only to have good lights on the three masterpieces! No photos with flash!!!

The cult of Caravaggio is alive and well. . Given that it's in Rome this church is pretty  unremarkable, strange that it scores as "no. 1 attraction."This is due of course to three paintings of Caravaggio.  The artist was certainly a most unpleasant man in real life. But it's his art that's in question so we can put aside his violent nature. As an artist anatomy is Caravaggio's weak point; he gets this badly wrong often. That said, everything else about the work is fascinating. It's place in western art and thinking undoubted. It is wonderful to find a set of three works presented as the artist intended. There's a rare authenticity about this. That the setting is less than ideal is a side point, we can take it the patrons commissioning the works didn't fully realise how important they were to be.Of the three "the calling of saint Matthew" is my favourite. Having often looked at reproductions i was very disappointed that when I eventually found time to sit in front of the original masterpiece (it is a masterpiece as I understand the word to mean) the light had to be fed euros every few minutes to keep it on - this was really irritating. As I studied the group of tax collectors trying to finally decide for myself if Matthew is pointing to himself or if he is in fact the  young guy with bowed head the light kept going off- hungry for coins. On balance,  this is worth seeing but in no way is at as fulfilling or important an experience as its rating  here might suggest. Caravaggio just isn't that rewarding despite the current fashion in lauding him.

A Shrine For Caravaggio Lovers. Three of Caravaggio's masterpieces are here: The Calling of St. Matthew, The Inspiration of St. Matthew, and The Martyrdom of St. Matthew. It is a simple little church and could be easily missed.But, and this is a big but, the church has very limited hours open to the public. Check in advance and, if in doubt, go early. We made it just before closing and saw all three Caravaggio's but just barely. As soon as closing time was announced the proprietor shut off the lights, plunging the canvases into utter darkness, and ushered everyone out. We're not complaining--they have a right to set their hours, of course--but you must plan ahead to get inside.

Check opening times for this church!. The church is in a lovely little square and is unassuming from the outside. I so wanted to see this church and its 3 Carvaggios but it is only open 2 or 3 hours in the morning and 2 in the afternoons and it is CLOSED on Thursday afternoons so plan accordingly. I was too late for the morning opening and then discovered it was a Thursday afternoon and closed. I was so disappointed, so be warned and plan better than I did.

Worth the visit for the caravaggio paintings. You will be in this area at some point anyway so take a peak at 3 of caravaggios paintings, located at the far left. Note that you may have to insert money to activate the lights (otherwise you can barely see the paintings).

Small, crowded area around the paintings. But fun to see the Carravaggios. The floor panels explaining the painting was really helpful. The probably couldn't do much about the crowding as the paintings are in this chapel. The other chapels were described in French and Italian.
Caravaggio. Grand, of course Caravaggio paintings get all the attention. It certainly deserves a second visit when we go to Rome next time.
Caravaggio. I know this is the French National Church in Rome, but you must go to the far left corner to see more magnificence of Caravaggio.
So enchanting. never get tired of this place. really wonderful Caravaggios. Try to go early in the morning before the tourist. look out for the church between piazza Navona and the Pantheon.

Church. It was very beautiful and ostentatious. The scultures and decor inside the church was magnificent. The whole structure of the building displayed the architetural competence unique to the Romans or Italians.
breathtaking artwork. There are 3 pieces of Caravaggio Art not to be missed!! Beautiful gilded ceiling and marble flooring.

biggest surprise of our stay!. i knew nothing about this church before setting off to rome earlier this month and i have to say its up there with the sistine chapel! well worth a visit and entry is free.
A Museum. Beautiful Cavavaggio paintings a couple of blocks from Piazza Navona Church closes at noon and reopens at 4pm.

nice bonus after the villa Borghese. The San Luigi dei Francesi is easy to reach in the centre of Rome, free to access and it holds a few excellent paintings. So it has a high value / (price & effort) ratio indeed. I would suggest to experience it as a bonus or appetiser to the villa Borghese and most certainly not as a substitute!

A minutes silence. A minutes silence from the hustle and bustle of the streets, light a candle and say a prayer for your loved ones, here and departed. The peace inside this place is a little bit of heaven.

An unmissable gem!. It would be easy to walk past this little church, but don't! The whole church is a delight, but the three Carravagio paintings are something evry visitor to Rome must see. This is the smae number of Carravagios as The National Gallery in London or the Louvre in Paris!

Caravaggio at his best!. Don't miss this silent and impressive experience of one of the major painters of all times. There are also other places with Caravaggio masterpieces namely a church in Piazza del Popolo and the Galleria Borgese

One of my favorites in Roma. We live in have a home in Umbria and our last couple of days we like to stay near the Pantheon because of its location to everything we like to do. With that in between the Pantheon and Piazza Navona (Right near the French embassy lies this quiet church that has a peacful feel and beautiful architecture and paitings.
Go there. Very,very nice church!i am an atheist so i look at churches from an architectural and artistic point of view,and from that point of view it's fantastic!!!

One of my favorite chapels in all of Rome. It was quaint and inviting, nothing like the immense and austere St Peter's. It was fantastic to see such wonderful paintings as well. For such a simple looking chapel on the outside, it is truly a beautiful place inside.

Beautiful. We loved the paintings inside. The church is so calm and beautiful. It's in the middle of the fast city, so close to piazza navona and the panthenon but once you walk inside you feel a sense of peace.

Go for the art. This church, in a small square near the French embassy, has free entry. More importantly, there are three works by Carravagio on display. Worth a quick stop to see some truly amazing art. Bring a few euros for while entry is free you have to pay to turn the lights on to view the paintings. Truly a small price to pay.
Great paintings. Pretty church, with amazing Caravaggio paintings! Is worth the time to see them and read the stories about them!

amazing paintings. i love how in rome the churches were like museums - and free, too! we loved the paintings in this church, especially the caravaggio! have coins handy if you want to illuminate them. nice escape from the heat, too.

One of the must-see (and free) sights in Rome.. Even if you know nothing about painting or about Saint Matthew, the large paintings in this church will astonish you. The church is located about two minutes from Piazza Navona and, in the other direction, about two minutes from the Pantheon. The church has posted good descriptions of the paintings in multiple languages. This is a working church, and it is a good idea to observe the dress code that requires that shoulders and knees be covered. You might get away with shorts or bare shoulders, but you might not.
AMAZING. Came upon this church by default as we were looking round the piazza Navona and saw people going into the church. The frescos are amazing and it is well worth a visit.
Nice church with beautiful paintings. this church isn't as crowded as some and you'll get very nice access to the beautiful Caravaggios. You need to have coins to illuminate the paintings.
Excellent Sight. This is a very beautiful church! It's well worth a visit if you're near the Pantheon. The art and architecture is amazing!

Wow!. Why go to expensive museums when you can make your way through rome's churches! They are free and breathtaking! Like most churches in Rome, I just stumbled and found the most awe inspiring Caravaggio's!

The Caravaggio is a must see. On your way to Piazza Navona make sure to stop by this church. Go inside and on the left looking at the alter in the corner is a very important Caravaggio. See it and then move on to the Piazza. It is a worthwhile stop.
3 major works by Caravaggio. Amazingly decorated church, should not be missed when visiting the Pantheon? The works by Caravaggio are excellent.
Wow!. Do not miss out on this church it is stunning! We stumbled across it and were so surprised. Literally takes your breath away when you open the door!
Incredible Caravaggio. I was mesmerized by Caravaggio's Conversion of St. Matthew. Viewing this masterpiece is free and you can get a little booklet that explains the details of the painting.
caravaggio. i really enjoyed this church because there are caravaggio's paintings there to surprise you!!! near pantheon and piazza navona - easy to find.

WORTH A VISIT. There are probably better churches in Rome but it is worth a visit here just to see the paintings from the Life of St. Matthew, by Caravaggio and the beautiful ceiling of the main church. They are very very well painted. We were lucky we visited late afternoon (not a tour party in sight). You may want to have some change with you though as you need to put money into a slot machine to illuminate the Caravaggio's. We were also lucky here as somone had just done so. Situated not far from the Pantheon and is in fact the French church in Rome.

Caravaggio paintings. The 3 Caravaggios on the last altar on the left nave are marvelous. Take coins to light up the altar, otherwise you will see nothing! (Caravaggio was a master of light and darkness, but without light you will get only the dark part :).

Don't miss the caravaggio panels!. The Contarelli Chapel is located within the church of San Luigi dei Francesi on the left - front side. It has a spell binding three panel painting featuring Saint Matthew by Caravaggio. Maybe two small blocks from the Pantheon

Worth a visit for the Caravaggios. I'd definitely recommend a short visit if you're in the area. Wonderful to see the paintings in the building they were intended to grace. Maybe it was just bad timing on my part but I went about 30 minutes before the 7pm closing and there were 2 tour groups, which spoiled the atmosphere a bit
Nice paintings inside. It is between Piazza Navona and Pantheon. Inside it has an amazing paintings and artistic ceilings. It is a must to go there and enjoy all the art inside.
Worth a look. Worth a quick visit for the Carvaggio paintings. I did not like that you have to put money into a box to illuminate the chapels with the paintings though.

Go for the Caravaggios, of course. I couldn't tell you anything much about the church of S. Luigi, other than the famous chapel with the paintings from the Life of St. Matthew, by Caravaggio. They are simply amazing, especially considering that this was Caravaggio's first big religious commission.

Better than most museums. If you want to view great art masterpieces on a budget, forget the museums with their tickets and long lines and visit the places the art was commissioned for - like this and other remarkable churches in Rome! The paintings, sculptures, and interior are incredible. There are several other sights to see right in the area, like the Pantheon and Piazza Navona, but check out the other churches as well.

Caravaggio 's here!. There is a side chapel with three paintings by Caravaggio in it. Worth the visit just for that! Between Piazza Navona and Pantheon, so it is easy to tie in to more famous sightseeing spots.
Very famous paintings.. Worth searching for as it contains Carravagio's. You cannot miss them. Not far from the Pantheon.

Caravaggios were worth the effort to visit. The Church was beautiful - took a little effort to find but the interior was worth the effort. The art was extraordinary. I was glad it was on TripAdvisor's top places in Rome.
Quite remarkable. Rivals the Sistine chapel in decoration - an amazing and unexpected find close to the Pantheon.

Not to be Missed. There are lots of free things to do in Rome and this is one of the best for art lovers. A very short walk from the Pantheon (another free site), this church contains three important works by Caravaggio. There's usually a crowd around "The Calling of St. Matthew." In addition, the interior is stunning. It's a great place to relax in the pews and contemplate beauty for a few minutes. Hours are sporadic: Friday-Wednesday 7:30-12:30 and 3:30-7; Thursday, 8-12:30, so you may find it closed. Plan ahead. I usually duck in on my way from the Pantheon to Piazza Navona as it sits on the main path between these two sites.
Very beautiful. Incredible art and statues...should not be missed!
Caravaggio. One of the best places to see Caravaggio's work and it's free!! Go early because they close at noon. Easy to find while you are strolling around the centro storico.

Caravaggio. This church holds a number of treasures... with the three Caravaggio paintings, being the most valued.. The three images of the life of St. Matthew are situated "en situ".. i.e. where they were originally were originally placed in the 17th century..... Go early ( note Church closes at noon,, re-opens at 4-4:30 until 7:00pm) as it can get crowded around these painting.. .Bring coins to to light up the paintings.. and... check "The Martyrdom of St. Matthew .... can you spot Caravaggio's self portrait within the painting. Roma has the largest collection of Caravaggio's artwork... See them all ! St. Augosito church is just a stones throw away,, featuring another "en situ" Caravaggio.
Caravaggios are great. A church always worth visiting. It's close to the Pantheon and the Caravaggios are very nice

Not to be missed. Caravaggio's 3 masterpieces on St Matthew is in the chapel closest to the altar. The church is very accessible since it is a stone throw's away from the piazza Navona. If you head west from the Pantheon, you will come across it.
WOW. one of the most beautiful church, have to see and walk inside.
Caravaggio. Magnificient paintings. Read the novel "The Lost Painting" while you are wandering around Rome. It gives the feeling of the time of Caravaggio.

Caravaggio delight. Three great Caravaggios - all St. Matthew. Right near Piazza Navona - and close to St. Ignatius and Gesu Churches - best baroque churches in Rome. Both Jesuit churches with lots of Ignatian stuff. Pantheon a 3 minute walk. Colloseum about 20 minutes. Vatican 20 minute walk.
Lovers of Caravaggio take note. Two beautiful Caravaggio paintings make this one of the churches I go back to time and again
Beautiful.. The churches in Rome are cool and relaxed. The art work was beautiful- marble is such a creative stone to work with. Well worth a vist.
Well worth a visit. Delightful church with wonderful Caravaggio paintings

A wonderful experience .... We visited this church specifically to see Caravaggio's St. Matthew Cycle. It was one of the highlights of almost three weeks in Italy. Seing these magnificent paintings in this beautiful church was both a privilege and a blessing. We spent an hour contemplating these masterworks and reading the informational materials that were provided in Italian, French, and English. It was an unforgettable experience.

Can't beat Caravaggio!. Every time I go to Rome I have to make a pilgrimage to San Luigi dei Francesi to see the three incredible Caravaggio paintings in its Contarelli Chapel. Many Italian churches have started charging admission, but this one charges only for the lights on the paintings, which is accomplished by feeding a coin into the machine. Magnificent!

Home to 2 Caravaggios, not to be missed. Most vchurches in Rome close at 12 or 12.30pm, reopen at 3.30 till 6 pm mass and then close soon after, be careful about hours. This beautiful church the French built in Rome and named after their patron saint is home to 2 of the most famous Caravaggio paintings of all time, the Vocation of St. Matthew and St. Jerome in his study, put in a coin and enjoy the amamzing paintings for a while. The church itself is very interesting, take time to see the chapels, you won't regret it.
another amazing, must-see church. Amazing architecture and art work. Worth visiting to take in the Baroque architecture
Small jewel of a church. Stop in to see three of Caravaggio's famous paintings in a small chapel in this church.
Lovely. Beautiful place. Worth the visit. Try to take time to look.

They have a Caravaggio !. Was here on a past visit to Rome, in 2007, but could not get in in May 2012, as there was a wedding at the church - and we were not invited.There is a French Language bookstore, located next to the church. Admire the early Caravaggio painting "The Calling of Saint Matthew".

cleaned and interpreted. Since our last visit, a dozen years ago, the Caravaggio paintings in the last chapel on the left have been cleaned. There is a series of panels in 3 langauges that explains the composition and meaning of the most important one, "The Calling of St. Matthew." Very well done!

Caravaggio. A beautiful church, dedicated to Saint Louis of France. Don't miss the 3 fabulous Caravaggio paintings on the left side in the Cappella Contarelli. For a small fee (deposited in a box) lights will shine on the paintings. You really can't appreciate them without lighting.
The home of the Carravagios. Such a lovely church and some of the best art outside the Uffizi in Florence. The Calling of St. Matthew by Carravagio is stunning and we spent the euro to light it up.
carravagio. 3 wondefull carravagio's to see, they are very interesting, espescialli the left one!

Very Ornate!. This church has one of the most draw jopping and best preserved interiors of any church in Rome. It is also famous for its 3 Carravaggio paintings in a side chapel in the front left side of the church. Be sure to put a coin in to see the paintings under light. Carravaggio is famous for portraying Biblical figures as everyday people and for his use of light and dark. The contrast between his art and other artists of his day is palpable. Very near Piazza Navona, so easy to visit from there.

A not-so-hidden gem.. For Renaissance art lovers - a must. For Caravaggio lovers - an absolute necessity! To enter this small church and see 3 of the most remarkable Caravaggio paintings based on the life of St. Matthew - the Martyrdom, the Calling and the Inspiration - in their true environment is an incredible experience.

Beautitful church near Navona square. We personally ranked this church as #3 of the churches we visited (after Gésu and Loyola). The ceiling and interior is fully decorated.The Calling of St Matthew, one of the 3 paintings from Caravage in the left corner, is stunning and a few explanations are provided. The church was built between 1518 and 1589, and completed through the personal intervention of Catherine de Medici. It is the national church in Rome of France.
Caravaggio. beautiful original paintings by this master of the Barocco
CV. What a wonderful chapel by Caravaggio! Smaller than we expected but exceptionally peaceful.

Nice Caravaggios. We popped in here on the way to Piazza Navona for some welcome respite from the crowds. It was a Sunday and the organist was playing. The Caravaggios in the bottom left were interesting-different from the other frescoes. The vibrancy and his use of light are why they are celebrated, I suppose. Well worth seeing.
Bit of Versailles in Rome. Beautiful, over-the-top interior for France's key church in Rome (San Luigi dei Francesi = King Louis of France!)
Great for Caravaggio!. Wasn't always open when it said it would be. But worth going back for.

Lovely and beautiful.. While not a huge church (in Rome terms, at least), this is a nice church with beautiful paintings by Caravaggio.As a lot of people tend to skip this church (for better looking ones, I assume), it is not crowded despite its central location.

A treasure!. An Italian friend told me about this church years ago and I stop by every time I am in Rome! It is on the way from the Pantheon to Trevi Fountain (or vice versa), so not out of the way at all!! It has never been crowded the times I have visited. A must if you like Caravaggio!!!

Great paintings by Caravaggio. Three famous and magnificent paintings regarding St. Matthew are located here, between the Piazza di Rotondo (Pantheon) and the Piazza Navona. I have been to this church many times to see these magnificent paintings. It is always worth another view.
Caravaggio"s the best. Find the chapel and enjoy the paintings - free of people and tickets

If you love Caravaggio - make sure you go. There is nothing like seeing a Caravaggio in person. Picture are lovely, but the real thing is breathtaking. In this Church, there are 3. They are contained in a small alcove so they are easy to find. Look for the alcove with lots of people. If you get there and find the alcove dark, drop a Euro in the box for some light or wait til someone else does. Since the 2 large paintings are on the flanking walls, it is impossible to get a great photo so don't waste the time and just buy the postcards. Enjoy the play of light through the windows in the Church and how this same angle is replicated in the paintings themselves. A little appreciated detail highlighted by my art loving daughter. There are posters located throughout the church that point out the highlights of the Caravaggio paintings, so it is worth wandering around to the rest of the church too.

My favorite church in Rome!. What a beautiful place! We kind of stumbled into it as it is somewhat in between piazza Novona and the Pantheon. It was a great find! It is also across the street from the Italian senate. They had some interesting things in their windows. As for the church, it is the national church of France in Rome, so a lot of the stuff inside is in French. Not to mention the beautiful Caravaggio paintings within! There are also frescos and other pieces of artwork that are well worth a visit. I highly recommend this church!
Caravaggio paintings. Wonderful masterworks of Caravaggio, but often full of tourists who come by the busload. The church is closed mid-day.
Only the French could do it so well!. This was my 2nd visit havering stumbled onto it last year. Just as great the 2nd time, we went back twice in the week. You can't beat Caravaggio!
masterpiece. A wonderful surprise - to see a masterpiece not in the museum , but in the "real life". It is possible only in Rome!
So Many Other Churches to See. This church has become a mecca due the (few) paintings by Caravaggio -- undoubtedly beautiful, stunning, etc., but not worth fighting the crowds.
do not miss it!. here you can enjoy the paintings of Caravaggio,is a real luck to see his drawings and his method.
Beautiful and Private. Amazing little gem of a church, off the well-beaten path. You can view the gorgeous frescoes and sculptures in relative privacy. And it's free!

A definite " Must Do" An oasis of inspiring calm....... The Church of San Luigi dei Francesci is a definite... if you only visit one church ( well, two if you include St. Peter's .. ;-) ) then head for this one.Beautiful and baroque, it's home to a triptych of Caravaggio paintings depicting the calling of St. Matthew.You don't need to be either religious to appreciate this incredible scene... but even apart from the Caravaggios this is a peaceful and calm way to spend 30 minutes or so in wonderful surroundings , before joining the outside throngs heading up to the Piazza Navona.

Caravaggio fans must. Aside from being a cool refuge on a hot day, one can enjoy a quiet moment in a church. The added attraction for me was the draw of three Caravaggios: Martirio di San Matteo; San Matteo e l'angelo; Vocazione di san Matteo. The church should be on the art fan's list.
The house for masterpieces. The church itself is one of many, but it's a treasure box, having within it's walls three paintings of Caravaggio. It's worth every minute, spent in it.
fine Carravagios. make time to see some of Carravagio's greatest paintings.

Caravaggio. If you want to see as many of C's paintings as possible, this church houses 2 that are well worth a visit. The church is very close to Piazza Navrona.There is another church nearby - at Piazza Agostina that also has a Caravaggio.Note that most churches are open to the public around 9- 9:30am but they all close at about Noon until around 3-3:30pm.

If you love Caravaggio, don't miss this church.. There are three Caravaggio paintings in this church -- most notably, one that was rejected by the patron because Caravaggio used every day people as models. Both versions of the painting are in the church. His use of light in a dark space is outstanding.

Beautiful!. What a beautiful church! You may have read about the 3 Caravaggio paintings that are housed here, but reproductions do not do them justice. See for yourself. Do remember that you are visiting a church, and keep your voice soft, and dress appropriately. Also, the corner of the church where the paintings are hung is lit with spotlights that run on a timer, so be sure you have some euro coins (50 cents, I think). Definitely worth a stop.
Great Caravaggios. Free viewing of S.Matthews lifetime paintings by Caravaggio
Limited opening hours. Loved seeing the Caravaggio paintings but had to come multiple times to find it open.

Cultural highlight. Wonderful Caravaggios well displayed and accessible. There were other visitors, but the Church was not too crowded, so that one could appreciate the art, architecture and atmosphere.

Must see for art lovers. Near the Pantheon, see 3 Carravaggio's in the church where the artist actually painted the works of art for. Explore the neighborhood where the artist actually lived. Don't miss San Augustino around the corner for more of the artist's work.
Impressive. Must it for the paintings and decor!The paintings of caraggio are so worth it
One reason. pretty little church, but its all about the Caravaggio - genius.
Bella bella Chiesa. If you love Carravaggio thisis the place for you,it is not farfrom Piazza Navonna
Three wonderful Caravaggio paintings!. The church is nice, but these three large magnificent paintings are the reason to visit!
WOW thats about all I can say.. Carvagghio paintings alone are worth seeing. Beautiful church and free entrance. Worth the trip.

Worth a stop if you're in the neighborhood. This church is worth a stop if you're in the neighborhood (Pantheon/Piazza Navonna) or a Francophile. In most cities it might qualify as a crown jewel, but in the context of Rome's churches, it is one of many
Worth seeing. Its definatley one of the beautiful churches of Rome. The paintings are great.

Pick another church - this one is too crowded!. There are a lot of fine and interesting churches in Rome. For some reason this one has become very popular on Trip Advisor and instead of a quite and beautiful place for contemplation and appreciation of art has become a tourist nightmare with hundreds of idiots walking around taking pictures (with flash of course which probably damages the pictures). Do yourself a favor and pick another church from the hundreds available.
Caravaggio. Three wonderful paintings of Caravaggio! Use the light and enjoy!Maybe best time to visit early in the morning or end of the day. Can become pretty crowded in the high season.
You will be delighted by the beauty. What to say, it's not easy to walk around and enter in a church and be surprised by Caravaggio!
nice paintings. Nice paintings but also nice ceiling with a lot of gilts. Silence required (a guy say shhh! all the time).
This is a very nice church to visit and only takes ten minutes to see. Not a place that is a must see but if you are in the vicinity then why not. Just pop in and take a look around.
great!. but not diferent from others in terms of architecture, decoration and so on. In other words and Roman Imperial Temple converted into a church

3 fantastic paintings by Caravaggio. The three paintings of St. Matthew are wonderful examples of Caravaggio's light and shadow style. I particularly like The Calling of St Matthew; the colours are amazing even now, more than 400 years on. The viewing conditions aren't great; the church is cold and dark, but you can plug in a few coins to illuminate the paintings for a few minutes at a time.We kept going back to visit and found that we saw more in the paintings each time. If you go when the crowds are small, you can have a few moments to study.

This local French church is home to 3 wonderful Caravaggio paintings which are not to be missed.. If you're an art lover it's a must see, plus it's easy to find being next to Palazzo Madama (the Italian Senate), and near Piazza Navona.
wow, add to you must see list. plan to spend some time sitting in this magnificent church contemplating the beautiful surroundings.,
Can't miss the Caravaggios here. Beautiful church but the Caravaggio paintings are the main attraction. You can pay a bit to illuminate.

Greet Art but sadly church nor treated with respect. Loved the church, make a nore of the limited opening hours though. But the noise inside was terrible espeicallyu around the paintings, tour guides seemed to be the worse culprits

This sweet church has 3 amazing Caravaggios on display!. Sweet church with 3 great Caravaggios on display - including the Calling of St. Matthew, the Inspiration of St. Mathew and the Martyrdom of St. Mathew!

Outstanding Church with Caravaggio masterpieces. Beautiful Church with outstanding artworks. We joined the throngs of visitors waiting to see the 3 Caravaggio murals of St Matthew. Guides tend to spend a long time at this Chapel to explain everything to their groups. This holds up the other viewers of the Caravaggio masterpiece. A little patience on one's part will be well-rewarded!
Superb. Exceptional. Magnificent. incredible. The marbles, the paintings. A must see
Nice church. All nice inside the church! Nice painting also? You don't have to pay any money to get inside this church.
Caravaggio paints. the two Paints of Caravaggio are amazing and the location between Piazza Navona and Piazza del Pantheon is perfect for the tourist
Caravaggio. Last chapel on your left, 3 Caravaggio's with explanation about the symbolism in the paintings.
superb!. If tourists come mostly for the Cavereggios in the church, it is a very nice one (well there are many others!)

Caravaggio won't disappoint!. Have to pay to light up the paintings but with three caravaggios in one place with free entrance who's complaining. The rest of the church is equally stunning considering it's relatively small size.
You must see it.. The ceiling is brilliant nd beautiful.You must see it.

Why?. Caravaggio - the calling of St Matthew.
Wonderful.
Nothing to dislike. For heavens sake. It's a CHURCH!
History & Beauty. The Church is like a museum, so much art, history and beauty!

My second favorite artist. ...after Bernini, of course! In this church there are three paintings of Caravaggio, all gathered in the same small crypt. They are just amazing, and although we had to put a coin every minute to keep the lights on, we have been there for half a hour! ahahah! go see it
Hidden Art Treasures. Give the big art mueums a miss if you dont have much time, and nip into this church and find the hidden Caravaggios
great Caravaggio's. our guide Max of Easitalytours pointed at the amazing painting in this church, which we didn't know about, very much worth the visit
Caravaggio. I always stop at Chiesa San Luigi dei Francesi to meditate and to view the 3 Caravaggio's of St Matthew in the Contarelli Chapel.

Amazing Caravaggio!. Love it! The only place to really appreciate Caravaggio. Last chapel on the left (as you come in), you'll find three of them, so a great place to really get a feeling for his full genius. Unfortunately you have to endure throngs of tourist... but you're in the centre of Rome, what did you expect?
Rome. Rome is amazing place and you will always find something attractive. I found nice black and white photos http://www.jp2love.com/gallery,5,JP2-Places.html
beautiful paintings, take your time, so much to see. Such history! it was surreal knowing how old those paintings and the church are.

Amazed by Caravaggio. My 4th visit to Rome and finally stopped by Caravaggio! Definitely no regrets for time spent here. It`s worth going there. Captions and stories of how these masterpieces were created made us stay here about an hour! But - take some spare change as they charge for lighting!
Amazing Caravaggios. A small treasure house with 3 wonderful Caravaggio paintings on the life aand death of St Mathew. This church is between the Piazza Navona and the Pantheon. It was not crowded
Caravaggio, above all.... 3 paintings of Caravaggio you mustn't miss -it's also on the walkway Pantheon-Piazza Navona.
Must see. See the paintings of San Matteo by Caravaggio, amazing!
Great History. Not the best for little children. But very interesting for hstory buffs
Church - good to see. When in Rome see as much as possible. This church was very nice and well worth the visit.

Come to pray -- and see the Carravaggios. This is the French church in Rome. Artistically, the highlight is the St. Matthew chapel with the three paintings by Caravaggio. They are some of his best works, especially The Calling of St. Matthew, as it evokes Michaelangelo's image of thebcreation of man on the ceiling in the Sistine chapel. There is also a small French bookstore next to the Church.
Caravaggio. Heres the place to see Caravaggio - three paintings in a side altar

Caravaggio 1,2,3. I live in Rome but don't often have a chance to just walk around in the historic center. But when I do, I love to make the round of churches to visit my old friends, the paintings by Caravaggio. San Luigi dei Francesi has no less than three painting by this Master. And they are gorgeous. I could look at them for hours. Look for the self portrait in the background of "The martyrdom of St Matthew"!

Caravaggio Triptych!. A beautiful church containing a stunning set of Caravaggio paintings and monuments to a number of french painters and sculptors. They charge for lighting them so take some change. The church is closed from 21.30 till 3pm and opens at 10. Gypsies beg on the steps.

Caravaggio at his best. If you really want to understand what a great painter is about, visit this church and take a look at the magnificent paintings from Caravaggio. When you will walk out, you will ask yourself how could someone paint in this way, with such strength!
Easy art. Art is displayed nicely and easy to get to. Carravaggio close up for free.
very intresting. I learned a lot about this old church and took good pictures inside and outside.

A must for Caravaggio lovers. We've visited the Church of San Luigi dei Francesi on a few occasions on our visits to Rome and will never get tired of it. This is some of Caravaggio's most powerful work. Remarkable. A must see for Caravaggio lovers. Truly another great example that Rome really is a living museum.

Deep down in history. The church is excellent with the old choir brought up from the older basilica below - which you can go down and visit. Under the church you can see the old basilicas (or whats left of them), some artwork and feel how it is to walk in ancient Rome. Worth a visit!

If you like Caravaggio.... This old church features three magnificent paintings by Caravaggio, en situ.... i.e. exactly as they were originally hung...
Note Carvaggio self portrait in the third picture,, the Martyrdom of St. Matthew...

il Capello di San Matteo. Whenever I'm in Rome, I make a point of slipping in her to see Carravagio's masterpiece and his very human St. Matthew wrestling to the end with the implications and consequences of responding to his calling.
exquisite church. The sculptures by some of the world's greatest artists make this church a must-see....breathtaking!
Wonderful. Just slip past the gypsy woman begging out front and come see some wonderful artwork. Drop your coin donations in the slot to illuminate the Caravaggio paintings. Breath taking.

Wonderful masterpieces, take note of Church hours. What beautiful works of art by a master. If you love Caravaggio, you must go here.Church hours should be noted as it is closed midday. Also, take note of when mass occurs. I went close to 5pm when mass was going to start. So 5 minutues before 5pm, they moved visitors away. Returned at 6pm after mass was done to get a final glimpse.
Caravaggio's Genius. If you love what Caravaggio did to the painting, dark moods, special light, then this is your place. Watch and prepare to be amazed.

The world goes here to see the Caravaggio paintings, specifically the "Calling of St. Matthew". While you're here, you are only a very short distance from the church of S. Agostino, where there is another first-rate Caravaggio, and no crowds at all. S. Luigi dei Francesi gets all the crowds, S. Agostino nobody.
3 Caravaggios in one chapel. Just steps from Navona, duck into this church and see Caravaggio's St. Matthew cycle.

Fantastic Caravaggio. I could not believe my eyes, a beautiful chapel with original painting by Caravaggio, the divine painter of the barocco. the light that comes right one of the characters of the majestic painting is the expression of. how ths painter doomed and perfect was gifted and sensbile. Not to be missed.

Fabulous Caravaggios. Baroque, atmospheric after nightfall, but the reason to visit is to see Caravaggio's three paintings of the life of St Matthew. These are amongst his greatest works, and rather easier to see ,and perhaps greater, than the more well known works in S Maria Del Popolo

Oh Caravaggio!. 3 amaaaaaazing Caravaggio paitings are 3 good reasons for a visit. The admission is free but be prepared to drop a coin to switch on the lights on the paitings (or to wait for someone else to do it!) and to go "wooooh!" at every single one of them. Be aware of the opening hours and be prepared for some special event to have the church closed!
french. an interesting spot for the french also concerts are being offered
Must go for Caravaggio. If nothing else moves you, you must see the Caravaggio paintings in Rome, and this Church is one of the places where you get to see them. Not to be missed, no matter what.

The church is like a museum (Caravaggio are great!). Rome’s churches are like museums, and San Luigi dei Francesi is no different. We sought out this church for its Caravaggio paintings, and it did not disappoint. The paintings in Caravaggio’s signature chiaroscuro style are located in the Contarerlli chapel to the left of the altar (as you are facing the altar). The paintings are The Martyrdom of Saint Matthew, Calling of St. Matthew, and The Inspiration of St. Matthew.Unlike Santa Maria del Popolo church that has it’s own Caravaggio paintings inside a chapel, this church did not impose on people not to take pictures of the paintings. Be sure you put coins inside the light machine to turn the light on in the chapel so you can view the paintings. The church itself is absolutely a work of art and worth the visit even without the Caravaggio paintings.

Stunning Caravaggio paintings. This church has a beautiful Baroque interior but the three paintings by Caravaggio, still in their original position in a side chapel to the left of the main altar, are the real reason to visit. Be careful when you visit. Like so many churches it closes for several hours in the middle of the day.

Nice Church. Beautiful church but the light was not enought to apreciate the paintings on the sidewalls. Magnificent plafond and beautiful columns and floor in marble.Bonita igreja dedicada aos franceses na italia (seus santos e personalidades), mas com iluminação insuficiente para apreciar das pinturas das paredes laterais. Cúpula magnífica e bonitas colunas e piso em marmore.

Another testimonial to Carravagio. I don't mean to beat a dead horse here but the other reviewers are right - this church is worth it just to see the Carravagios. I absolutely loved my experience in this sacred house of art, religion and history.
The genius of Caravaggio. The three Caravaggio's. Of course I'd go back again and again and again

The Caravaggio's are wonderful. There is one major reason to go to this church: the 3 Caravaggio paintings all of Saint Matthew--one of his selection, in my opinion one of the greatest paintings in the Western world with its revolutionary use of light and shadow, one his crucifixion, perhaps the most traditional of the three and one of the visit of an angel.
Beautiful. The church has zoo much character as all the churches in europe

Caravaggio fans, don't miss this!. This church of St. Louis (Louis IX) of the French is a can't miss for artlovers, and especially Caravaggio fans. The painter was the first to actually paint light, and the foremost example of this is his "The Calling of St. Mathew", one of a trilogy of huge paintings housed in this historic church. Do not, like the herd, rush up to these, but enjoy each chapel painted by Guido Reni, Domenichino, etc. Then, get bathed in Caravaggio's genius.

Worth a Wait. We had been to Rome several times but never found the church open or along our path. Our last trip it was on our bucket list. The Carravaggio masterpiece chapel is the star, but enjoy the rest of this wonderful baroque, and unashamedly French, church as well. The outside belies the briliance within. And you needn't go out of you way, except to check when the church is open, It is located in the heart of old Rome and close to many other churches housing magnificent works of art. Our visit was well worth the time it took to finally see this gem.
see the Caravaggios. Right by the Piazza Navona, don't miss the three incredible Caravaggios on display in one of the side chapels- better than most museums and FREE ADMISSION!
Caravaggio frescoes. 'hidden' Caravaggio frescoes in this church, worth the visit, but not much else to see

The Calling of St. Matthew. The French Church in Rome, located near Piazza Navonna, contains 3 exceptional Caravaggio paintings in the Contarelli chapel, The Calling of Saint Matthew, St Matthew and the Angel and The Martyrdom of St Matthew. Admission is free. A coin will light the chapel to view the paintings. Note the exceptional use of light in The Calling of St. Matthew. This is a must see for any Caravaggio fan.

this is a real treasure. We were able to sneak in on this beautiful church with just a few minutes to spare before it closed for mid-day. It's an interesting example of church architecture that we hadn't thought about; an elaboratre facade on an ordinary building. BUT, inside the art was magnificient and the architecture of light and shadow and natural illumination was amazing. Not to be missed.

A must for any lovers of Caravaggio. Whatever other attractions this church has they outshone by these 3 exquisite pictures of St Matthew and during a previous visit for the Caravaggio exhibition in the Quirinale, a visit here was our compensation for being unable to gain access to the main exhibition. This is a church that should be high on everybody's must visit list. Go early to avoid being trampled by tour parties who march in surround the paintings and march out!

Caravaggio Lovers. This church, not far from the Pantheon is a must visit for Caravaggio lovers. The selection is limited but fascinating. The light in this church seems to accentuate the light that Caravaggio played with in this painting. Search this place out.

INCREDIBLE!!. We were lucky to stumble upon this church, not knowing what was inside...well....WOW!!...DOUBLE WOW!!!..TRIPLE WOW!!! Make sure to put this one on your list...church is near Piazza Navona...if your are near Piazza Navona, just ask someone for directions to this church...We found Romans very helpful and willing to try to point us in the right direction when we needed help.......Our experience was JUST INCREDIBLE. .... it was a bit crowded around the Caravaggio paintings, but be patient & work your way up front to see them...you will remember these awesome paintings forever.
Caravaggio at his best. If you like paintings, do not miss the Contarelli chapel.Here you'll find 3 of Caravaggio's best works, put in the original context, something you do not find in museums !

Carivaggiotastic. The Calling of St Matthew in the Contarelli chapel blew me away. I sobbed unable to explain my tears to my bemused wife. I had, of course, seen many prints of the work. Seeing it in the chapel was very different from studying a print. For a start it is on the side wall, so the perspective is totally different. Opposite is the drama of St Matthew's matyrdom, whilst the "face on" centre piece is the calmer "Inpsiration of St Matthew". I was unprepared for the way the light came out of the painting. The other tourists and visitors crowding round to view the painting seemed to become part of the tableau. The hand of Jesus (or is it the hand of Michelangelo's Adam?) points at St Matthew....but we become part of the grimy scene. Bathed in the light of divine love, we also ask "who me?"

Worth more than one visit. This church is centrally located near Piazza Navona and well worth seeing. The three paintings are well described and the entire church is fantastically beautiful. A real bonus is that it is rarely crowded and a welcomed respite from the hussle of tourists in this area. We visited several times as we stayed nearby and came close on our walks from our hotel to other sites. IT IS CLOSED ON THURSDAYS but in October it was open all posted times.

Required Stop For Caravaggio Fans. Don't miss this (somewhat) hidden treasure, especially if you are a fan of Caravaggio. But even those who know nothing about the man or his work, should take a few minutes to view these 3 incredible paintings dedicated to Saint Matthew the Evangelist that are grouped together at the last altar to the left of the Cathedral's main altar. You'll be glad you did!!(Its located only a short walk away from the Piazza Novana). Even better, you can see them free of charge--just bring a few Euro coins to operate the lamps to see the paintings better, and you may want to make a small donation to the church itself. The incredibly moving (and personal to Caravaggio--the priceless look on Matthew's face capturing his indecision and struggle about whether he should renounce his dissolute life and follow Jesus out the door recalls the painter's own extremely turbulent personal life) "Calling of St. Matthew" is probably my favorite painting of all-time, the gut-wrenching 'martyrdom of St Matthew', and the humourous 'St Matthew and the Angel" are also enchanting. Try not to Miss it!!!

So beautiful, we visited twice!. We stumbled across this church dedicated to St. Louis, the French monarch, while waiting for the soccer game ticket vendor to open. The interior was very dark and there was a lot of scaffolding for conservation work. But tucked away in a side chapel at the left rear of the church are the 3 Caravaggio paintings! Exquisite! Be sure to put some coins in the little box that controls the lights - then you can really see why these paintings are such masterpieces.

Takes some luck!. The trio of Caravaggio paintings are definitely worth seeing, the church is easy to find, just off the Piazza Navona right in the heart of the city...but it takes a bit of luck to actually find it OPEN! It was not until my third attempt on my third trip (having failed to find the doors unlocked on two previous trips) before we actually gained admittance to San Luigi! Oh, hours were posted and we arrived in that time-frame, but no luck! Or we arrived on the one day the hours stated they were closed. Or, it was just closed for no apparent reason. But it's Rome and that's how it goes sometimes...it's not the first time that's happened to us and won't be the last. We've learned to just stroll on to the next place of interest or enjoy a gelato instead. BUT, if you happen to be in luck and find the church doors open...by all means take advantage and rush in to behold the Caravaggio masterpieces! Bella.
